description.para:
<indexterm>
              <primary>BIT data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>BIT</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">BIT[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>)]</literal>

A bit-value type. <replaceable>M</replaceable> indicates the
            number of bits per value, from 1 to 64. The default is 1 if
            <replaceable>M</replaceable> is omitted.

<indexterm>
              <primary>TINYINT data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>TINYINT</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">TINYINT[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>)]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>

A very small integer. The signed range is
            <literal>-128</literal> to <literal>127</literal>. The
            unsigned range is <literal>0</literal> to
            <literal>255</literal>.

<indexterm>
              <primary>BOOLEAN data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>BOOL data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>BOOLEAN</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>BOOL</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">BOOL</literal>,
            <literal role="type">BOOLEAN</literal>

These types are synonyms for
            <literal role="type">TINYINT(1)</literal>. A value of zero
            is considered false. Nonzero values are considered true:

However, the values <literal>TRUE</literal> and
            <literal>FALSE</literal> are merely aliases for
            <literal>1</literal> and <literal>0</literal>, respectively,
            as shown here:

The last two statements display the results shown because
            <literal>2</literal> is equal to neither
            <literal>1</literal> nor <literal>0</literal>.

<indexterm>
              <primary>SMALLINT data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>SMALLINT</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">SMALLINT[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>)]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>

A small integer. The signed range is
            <literal>-32768</literal> to <literal>32767</literal>. The
            unsigned range is <literal>0</literal> to
            <literal>65535</literal>.

<indexterm>
              <primary>MEDIUMINT data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>MEDIUMINT</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">MEDIUMINT[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>)]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>

A medium-sized integer. The signed range is
            <literal>-8388608</literal> to <literal>8388607</literal>.
            The unsigned range is <literal>0</literal> to
            <literal>16777215</literal>.

<indexterm>
              <primary>INT data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>INT</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">INT[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>)]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>

A normal-size integer. The signed range is
            <literal>-2147483648</literal> to
            <literal>2147483647</literal>. The unsigned range is
            <literal>0</literal> to <literal>4294967295</literal>.

<indexterm>
              <primary>INTEGER data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>INTEGER</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">INTEGER[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>)]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>

This type is a synonym for
            <literal role="type">INT</literal>.

<indexterm>
              <primary>BIGINT data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>BIGINT</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>SERIAL</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">BIGINT[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>)]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>

A large integer. The signed range is
            <literal>-9223372036854775808</literal> to
            <literal>9223372036854775807</literal>. The unsigned range
            is <literal>0</literal> to
            <literal>18446744073709551615</literal>.

<literal>SERIAL</literal> is an alias for <literal>BIGINT
            UNSIGNED NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT UNIQUE</literal>.

<indexterm>
              <primary>DECIMAL data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>DECIMAL</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">DECIMAL[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>[,<replaceable>D</replaceable>])]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>

A packed <quote>exact</quote> fixed-point number.
            <replaceable>M</replaceable> is the total number of digits
            (the precision) and <replaceable>D</replaceable> is the
            number of digits after the decimal point (the scale). The
            decimal point and (for negative numbers) the
            <literal>-</literal> sign are not counted in
            <replaceable>M</replaceable>. If
            <replaceable>D</replaceable> is 0, values have no decimal
            point or fractional part. The maximum number of digits
            (<replaceable>M</replaceable>) for
            <literal role="type">DECIMAL</literal> is 65. The maximum
            number of supported decimals (<replaceable>D</replaceable>)
            is 30. If <replaceable>D</replaceable> is omitted, the
            default is 0. If <replaceable>M</replaceable> is omitted,
            the default is 10.

<literal>UNSIGNED</literal>, if specified, disallows
            negative values.

All basic calculations (<literal>+, -, *, /</literal>) with
            <literal role="type">DECIMAL</literal> columns are done with
            a precision of 65 digits.

<indexterm>
              <primary>DEC data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>NUMERIC data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>FIXED data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>DEC</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>NUMERIC</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>FIXED</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">DEC[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>[,<replaceable>D</replaceable>])]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>,
            <literal role="type">NUMERIC[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>[,<replaceable>D</replaceable>])]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>,
            <literal role="type">FIXED[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>[,<replaceable>D</replaceable>])]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>

These types are synonyms for
            <literal role="type">DECIMAL</literal>. The
            <literal role="type">FIXED</literal> synonym is available
            for compatibility with other database systems.

<indexterm>
              <primary>FLOAT data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>FLOAT</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">FLOAT[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>,<replaceable>D</replaceable>)]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>

A small (single-precision) floating-point number.
            Permissible values are <literal>-3.402823466E+38</literal>
            to <literal>-1.175494351E-38</literal>,
            <literal>0</literal>, and <literal>1.175494351E-38</literal>
            to <literal>3.402823466E+38</literal>. These are the
            theoretical limits, based on the IEEE standard. The actual
            range might be slightly smaller depending on your hardware
            or operating system.

<replaceable>M</replaceable> is the total number of digits
            and <replaceable>D</replaceable> is the number of digits
            following the decimal point. If <replaceable>M</replaceable>
            and <replaceable>D</replaceable> are omitted, values are
            stored to the limits permitted by the hardware. A
            single-precision floating-point number is accurate to
            approximately 7 decimal places.

<literal>FLOAT(<replaceable>M</replaceable>,<replaceable>D</replaceable>)</literal>
            is a nonstandard MySQL extension.

<literal>UNSIGNED</literal>, if specified, disallows
            negative values.

Using <literal role="type">FLOAT</literal> might give you
            some unexpected problems because all calculations in MySQL
            are done with double precision. See
            <xref linkend="no-matching-rows" />.

<indexterm>
              <primary>DOUBLE data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>FLOAT data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>DOUBLE</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>FLOAT</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">DOUBLE[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>,<replaceable>D</replaceable>)]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>

A normal-size (double-precision) floating-point number.
            Permissible values are
            <literal>-1.7976931348623157E+308</literal> to
            <literal>-2.2250738585072014E-308</literal>,
            <literal>0</literal>, and
            <literal>2.2250738585072014E-308</literal> to
            <literal>1.7976931348623157E+308</literal>. These are the
            theoretical limits, based on the IEEE standard. The actual
            range might be slightly smaller depending on your hardware
            or operating system.

<replaceable>M</replaceable> is the total number of digits
            and <replaceable>D</replaceable> is the number of digits
            following the decimal point. If <replaceable>M</replaceable>
            and <replaceable>D</replaceable> are omitted, values are
            stored to the limits permitted by the hardware. A
            double-precision floating-point number is accurate to
            approximately 15 decimal places.

<literal>DOUBLE(<replaceable>M</replaceable>,<replaceable>D</replaceable>)</literal>
            is a nonstandard MySQL extension.

<literal>UNSIGNED</literal>, if specified, disallows
            negative values.

<indexterm>
              <primary>DOUBLE PRECISION data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>REAL data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>DOUBLE PRECISION</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>REAL</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">DOUBLE
            PRECISION[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>,<replaceable>D</replaceable>)]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>,
            <literal role="type">REAL[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>,<replaceable>D</replaceable>)]
            [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]</literal>

These types are synonyms for
            <literal role="type">DOUBLE</literal>. Exception: If the
            <literal role="sqlmode">REAL_AS_FLOAT</literal> SQL mode is
            enabled, <literal role="type">REAL</literal> is a synonym
            for <literal role="type">FLOAT</literal> rather than
            <literal role="type">DOUBLE</literal>.

<indexterm>
              <primary>DATE data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>DATE</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">DATE</literal>

A date. The supported range is
            <literal>'1000-01-01'</literal> to
            <literal>'9999-12-31'</literal>. MySQL displays
            <literal role="type">DATE</literal> values in
            <literal>'YYYY-MM-DD'</literal> format, but permits
            assignment of values to <literal role="type">DATE</literal>
            columns using either strings or numbers.

<indexterm>
              <primary>DATETIME data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>DATETIME</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">DATETIME[(<replaceable>fsp</replaceable>)]</literal>

A date and time combination. The supported range is
            <literal>'1000-01-01 00:00:00.000000'</literal> to
            <literal>'9999-12-31 23:59:59.999999'</literal>. MySQL
            displays <literal role="type">DATETIME</literal> values in
            <literal>'<replaceable>YYYY-MM-DD
            hh:mm:ss</replaceable>[.<replaceable>fraction</replaceable>]'</literal>
            format, but permits assignment of values to
            <literal role="type">DATETIME</literal> columns using either
            strings or numbers.

An optional <replaceable>fsp</replaceable> value in the
            range from 0 to 6 may be given to specify fractional seconds
            precision. A value of 0 signifies that there is no
            fractional part. If omitted, the default precision is 0.

Automatic initialization and updating to the current date
            and time for <literal role="type">DATETIME</literal> columns
            can be specified using <literal>DEFAULT</literal> and
            <literal>ON UPDATE</literal> column definition clauses, as
            described in <xref linkend="timestamp-initialization" />.

<indexterm>
              <primary>TIMESTAMP data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>TIMESTAMP</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP[(<replaceable>fsp</replaceable>)]</literal>

A timestamp. The range is <literal>'1970-01-01
            00:00:01.000000'</literal> UTC to <literal>'2038-01-19
            03:14:07.999999'</literal> UTC.
            <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> values are stored
            as the number of seconds since the epoch
            (<literal>'1970-01-01 00:00:00'</literal> UTC). A
            <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> cannot represent
            the value <literal>'1970-01-01 00:00:00'</literal> because
            that is equivalent to 0 seconds from the epoch and the value
            0 is reserved for representing <literal>'0000-00-00
            00:00:00'</literal>, the <quote>zero</quote>
            <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> value.

An optional <replaceable>fsp</replaceable> value in the
            range from 0 to 6 may be given to specify fractional seconds
            precision. A value of 0 signifies that there is no
            fractional part. If omitted, the default precision is 0.

The way the server handles <literal>TIMESTAMP</literal>
            definitions depends on the value of the
            <literal role="sysvar">explicit_defaults_for_timestamp</literal>
            system variable (see
            <xref linkend="server-system-variables" />).

If
            <literal role="sysvar">explicit_defaults_for_timestamp</literal>
            is enabled, there is no automatic assignment of the
            <literal>DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP</literal> or <literal>ON
            UPDATE CURRENT_TIMESTAMP</literal> attributes to any
            <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> column. They must
            be included explicitly in the column definition. Also, any
            <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> not explicitly
            declared as <literal>NOT NULL</literal> permits
            <literal>NULL</literal> values.

If
            <literal role="sysvar">explicit_defaults_for_timestamp</literal>
            is disabled, the server handles <literal>TIMESTAMP</literal>
            as follows:

Unless specified otherwise, the first
            <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> column in a table
            is defined to be automatically set to the date and time of
            the most recent modification if not explicitly assigned a
            value. This makes <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal>
            useful for recording the timestamp of an
            <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> or
            <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> operation. You can
            also set any <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> column
            to the current date and time by assigning it a
            <literal>NULL</literal> value, unless it has been defined
            with the <literal>NULL</literal> attribute to permit
            <literal>NULL</literal> values.

Automatic initialization and updating to the current date
            and time can be specified using <literal>DEFAULT
            CURRENT_TIMESTAMP</literal> and <literal>ON UPDATE
            CURRENT_TIMESTAMP</literal> column definition clauses. By
            default, the first <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal>
            column has these properties, as previously noted. However,
            any <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> column in a
            table can be defined to have these properties.

<indexterm>
              <primary>TIME data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>TIME</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">TIME[(<replaceable>fsp</replaceable>)]</literal>

A time. The range is <literal>'-838:59:59.000000'</literal>
            to <literal>'838:59:59.000000'</literal>. MySQL displays
            <literal role="type">TIME</literal> values in
            <literal>'<replaceable>hh:mm:ss</replaceable>[.<replaceable>fraction</replaceable>]'</literal>
            format, but permits assignment of values to
            <literal role="type">TIME</literal> columns using either
            strings or numbers.

An optional <replaceable>fsp</replaceable> value in the
            range from 0 to 6 may be given to specify fractional seconds
            precision. A value of 0 signifies that there is no
            fractional part. If omitted, the default precision is 0.

<indexterm>
              <primary>YEAR data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>YEAR</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">YEAR[(4)]</literal>

A year in 4-digit format. MySQL displays
            <literal role="type">YEAR</literal> values in
            <literal>YYYY</literal> format, but permits assignment of
            values to <literal role="type">YEAR</literal> columns using
            either strings or numbers. Values display as
            <literal>1901</literal> to <literal>2155</literal>, or
            <literal>0000</literal>.

For additional information about
            <literal role="type">YEAR</literal> display format and
            interpretation of input values, see <xref linkend="year" />.

<indexterm>
              <primary>CHAR data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>NATIONAL CHAR data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>NCHAR data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>CHARACTER data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>CHAR</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>NATIONAL CHAR</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>NCHAR</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>CHARACTER</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal>[NATIONAL] CHAR[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>)]
            [CHARACTER SET <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>]
            [COLLATE
            <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>]</literal>

A fixed-length string that is always right-padded with
            spaces to the specified length when stored.
            <replaceable>M</replaceable> represents the column length in
            characters. The range of <replaceable>M</replaceable> is 0
            to 255. If <replaceable>M</replaceable> is omitted, the
            length is 1.

The <literal role="type">CHAR BYTE</literal> data type is an
            alias for the <literal role="type">BINARY</literal> data
            type. This is a compatibility feature.

<indexterm>
              <primary>VARCHAR data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>CHARACTER VARYING data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>CHAR VARYING data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>VARCHARACTER data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>NATIONAL VARCHAR data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>NVARCHAR data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>VARCHAR</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>CHARACTER VARYING</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>CHAR VARYING</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>VARCHARACTER</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>NATIONAL VARCHAR</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>NVARCHAR</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal>[NATIONAL] VARCHAR(<replaceable>M</replaceable>)
            [CHARACTER SET <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>]
            [COLLATE
            <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>]</literal>

A variable-length string. <replaceable>M</replaceable>
            represents the maximum column length in characters. The
            range of <replaceable>M</replaceable> is 0 to 65,535. The
            effective maximum length of a
            <literal role="type">VARCHAR</literal> is subject to the
            maximum row size (65,535 bytes, which is shared among all
            columns) and the character set used. For example,
            <literal>utf8</literal> characters can require up to three
            bytes per character, so a
            <literal role="type">VARCHAR</literal> column that uses the
            <literal>utf8</literal> character set can be declared to be
            a maximum of 21,844 characters. See
            <xref linkend="column-count-limit" />.

MySQL stores <literal role="type">VARCHAR</literal> values
            as a 1-byte or 2-byte length prefix plus data. The length
            prefix indicates the number of bytes in the value. A
            <literal role="type">VARCHAR</literal> column uses one
            length byte if values require no more than 255 bytes, two
            length bytes if values may require more than 255 bytes.

<literal role="type">VARCHAR</literal> is shorthand for
            <literal role="type">CHARACTER VARYING</literal>.
            <literal role="type">NATIONAL VARCHAR</literal> is the
            standard SQL way to define that a
            <literal role="type">VARCHAR</literal> column should use
            some predefined character set. MySQL uses
            <literal>utf8</literal> as this predefined character set.
            <xref linkend="charset-national" />.
            <literal role="type">NVARCHAR</literal> is shorthand for
            <literal role="type">NATIONAL VARCHAR</literal>.

<indexterm>
              <primary>BINARY data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>BINARY</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">BINARY[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>)]</literal>

The <literal role="type">BINARY</literal> type is similar to
            the <literal role="type">CHAR</literal> type, but stores
            binary byte strings rather than nonbinary character strings.
            An optional length <replaceable>M</replaceable> represents
            the column length in bytes. If omitted,
            <replaceable>M</replaceable> defaults to 1.

<indexterm>
              <primary>VARBINARY data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>VARBINARY</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">VARBINARY(<replaceable>M</replaceable>)</literal>

The <literal role="type">VARBINARY</literal> type is similar
            to the <literal role="type">VARCHAR</literal> type, but
            stores binary byte strings rather than nonbinary character
            strings. <replaceable>M</replaceable> represents the maximum
            column length in bytes.

<indexterm>
              <primary>TINYBLOB data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>TINYBLOB</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">TINYBLOB</literal>

A <literal role="type">BLOB</literal> column with a maximum
            length of 255 (2<superscript>8</superscript> minus 1)
            bytes. Each <literal role="type">TINYBLOB</literal> value is
            stored using a 1-byte length prefix that indicates the
            number of bytes in the value.

<indexterm>
              <primary>TINYTEXT data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>TINYTEXT</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal condition="tinytext" role="type">TINYTEXT
            [CHARACTER SET <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>]
            [COLLATE
            <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>]</literal>

A <literal role="type">TEXT</literal> column with a maximum
            length of 255 (2<superscript>8</superscript> minus 1)
            characters. The effective maximum length is less if the
            value contains multibyte characters. Each
            <literal role="type">TINYTEXT</literal> value is stored
            using a 1-byte length prefix that indicates the number of
            bytes in the value.

<indexterm>
              <primary>BLOB data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>BLOB</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">BLOB[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>)]</literal>

A <literal role="type">BLOB</literal> column with a maximum
            length of 65,535 (2<superscript>16</superscript> minus 1)
            bytes. Each <literal role="type">BLOB</literal> value is
            stored using a 2-byte length prefix that indicates the
            number of bytes in the value.

An optional length <replaceable>M</replaceable> can be given
            for this type. If this is done, MySQL creates the column as
            the smallest <literal role="type">BLOB</literal> type large
            enough to hold values <replaceable>M</replaceable> bytes
            long.

<indexterm>
              <primary>TEXT data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>TEXT</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">TEXT[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>)]
            [CHARACTER SET <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>]
            [COLLATE
            <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>]</literal>

A <literal role="type">TEXT</literal> column with a maximum
            length of 65,535 (2<superscript>16</superscript> minus 1)
            characters. The effective maximum length is less if the
            value contains multibyte characters. Each
            <literal role="type">TEXT</literal> value is stored using a
            2-byte length prefix that indicates the number of bytes in
            the value.

An optional length <replaceable>M</replaceable> can be given
            for this type. If this is done, MySQL creates the column as
            the smallest <literal role="type">TEXT</literal> type large
            enough to hold values <replaceable>M</replaceable>
            characters long.

<indexterm>
              <primary>MEDIUMBLOB data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>MEDIUMBLOB</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">MEDIUMBLOB</literal>

A <literal role="type">BLOB</literal> column with a maximum
            length of 16,777,215 (2<superscript>24</superscript> minus
            1) bytes. Each <literal role="type">MEDIUMBLOB</literal>
            value is stored using a 3-byte length prefix that indicates
            the number of bytes in the value.

<indexterm>
              <primary>MEDIUMTEXT data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>MEDIUMTEXT</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal condition="tinytext" role="type">MEDIUMTEXT
            [CHARACTER SET <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>]
            [COLLATE
            <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>]</literal>

A <literal role="type">TEXT</literal> column with a maximum
            length of 16,777,215 (2<superscript>24</superscript> minus
            1) characters. The effective maximum length is less if the
            value contains multibyte characters. Each
            <literal role="type">MEDIUMTEXT</literal> value is stored
            using a 3-byte length prefix that indicates the number of
            bytes in the value.

<indexterm>
              <primary>LONGBLOB data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>LONGBLOB</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">LONGBLOB</literal>

A <literal role="type">BLOB</literal> column with a maximum
            length of 4,294,967,295 or 4GB
            (2<superscript>32</superscript> minus 1) bytes. The
            effective maximum length of
            <literal role="type">LONGBLOB</literal> columns depends on
            the configured maximum packet size in the client/server
            protocol and available memory. Each
            <literal role="type">LONGBLOB</literal> value is stored
            using a 4-byte length prefix that indicates the number of
            bytes in the value.

<indexterm>
              <primary>LONGTEXT data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>LONGTEXT</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal condition="tinytext" role="type">LONGTEXT
            [CHARACTER SET <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>]
            [COLLATE
            <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>]</literal>

A <literal role="type">TEXT</literal> column with a maximum
            length of 4,294,967,295 or 4GB
            (2<superscript>32</superscript> minus 1) characters. The
            effective maximum length is less if the value contains
            multibyte characters. The effective maximum length of
            <literal condition="blob" role="type">LONGTEXT</literal>
            columns also depends on the configured maximum packet size
            in the client/server protocol and available memory. Each
            <literal condition="blob" role="type">LONGTEXT</literal>
            value is stored using a 4-byte length prefix that indicates
            the number of bytes in the value.

<indexterm>
              <primary>ENUM data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>ENUM</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">ENUM('<replaceable>value1</replaceable>','<replaceable>value2</replaceable>',...)
            [CHARACTER SET <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>]
            [COLLATE
            <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>]</literal>

An enumeration. A string object that can have only one
            value, chosen from the list of values
            <literal>'<replaceable>value1</replaceable>'</literal>,
            <literal>'<replaceable>value2</replaceable>'</literal>,
            <literal>...</literal>, <literal>NULL</literal> or the
            special <literal>''</literal> error value.
            <literal role="type">ENUM</literal> values are represented
            internally as integers.

An <literal role="type">ENUM</literal> column can have a
            maximum of 65,535 distinct elements. (The practical limit is
            less than 3000.) A table can have no more than 255 unique
            element list definitions among its
            <literal role="type">ENUM</literal> and
            <literal role="type">SET</literal> columns considered as a
            group. For more information on these limits, see
            <xref linkend="limits-frm-file" />.

<indexterm>
              <primary>SET data type</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>data type</primary>
              <secondary>SET</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="type">SET('<replaceable>value1</replaceable>','<replaceable>value2</replaceable>',...)
            [CHARACTER SET <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>]
            [COLLATE
            <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>]</literal>

A set. A string object that can have zero or more values,
            each of which must be chosen from the list of values
            <literal>'<replaceable>value1</replaceable>'</literal>,
            <literal>'<replaceable>value2</replaceable>'</literal>,
            <literal>...</literal> <literal role="type">SET</literal>
            values are represented internally as integers.

A <literal role="type">SET</literal> column can have a
            maximum of 64 distinct members. A table can have no more
            than 255 unique element list definitions among its
            <literal role="type">ENUM</literal> and
            <literal role="type">SET</literal> columns considered as a
            group. For more information on this limit, see
            <xref linkend="limits-frm-file" />.

A <literal>BLOB</literal> is a binary large object that can hold
        a variable amount of data. The four <literal>BLOB</literal>
        types are <literal>TINYBLOB</literal>, <literal>BLOB</literal>,
        <literal>MEDIUMBLOB</literal>, and <literal>LONGBLOB</literal>.
        These differ only in the maximum length of the values they can
        hold. The four <literal>TEXT</literal> types are
        <literal>TINYTEXT</literal>, <literal>TEXT</literal>,
        <literal>MEDIUMTEXT</literal>, and <literal>LONGTEXT</literal>.
        These correspond to the four <literal>BLOB</literal> types and
        have the same maximum lengths and storage requirements. See
        <xref linkend="storage-requirements" />.

<literal>Geometry</literal> is the base class. It is an
          abstract class. The instantiable subclasses of
          <literal>Geometry</literal> are restricted to zero-, one-, and
          two-dimensional geometric objects that exist in
          two-dimensional coordinate space. All instantiable geometry
          classes are defined so that valid instances of a geometry
          class are topologically closed (that is, all defined
          geometries include their boundary).

The base <literal>Geometry</literal> class has subclasses for
          <literal>Point</literal>, <literal>Curve</literal>,
          <literal>Surface</literal>, and
          <literal>GeometryCollection</literal>:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>Point</literal> represents zero-dimensional
              objects.

<literal>Curve</literal> represents one-dimensional
              objects, and has subclass <literal>LineString</literal>,
              with sub-subclasses <literal>Line</literal> and
              <literal>LinearRing</literal>.

<literal>Surface</literal> is designed for two-dimensional
              objects and has subclass <literal>Polygon</literal>.

<literal>GeometryCollection</literal> has specialized
              zero-, one-, and two-dimensional collection classes named
              <literal>MultiPoint</literal>,
              <literal>MultiLineString</literal>, and
              <literal>MultiPolygon</literal> for modeling geometries
              corresponding to collections of <literal>Points</literal>,
              <literal>LineStrings</literal>, and
              <literal>Polygons</literal>, respectively.
              <literal>MultiCurve</literal> and
              <literal>MultiSurface</literal> are introduced as abstract
              superclasses that generalize the collection interfaces to
              handle <literal>Curves</literal> and
              <literal>Surfaces</literal>.

description.para:
<literal>Geometry</literal>, <literal>Curve</literal>,
          <literal>Surface</literal>, <literal>MultiCurve</literal>, and
          <literal>MultiSurface</literal> are defined as noninstantiable
          classes. They define a common set of methods for their
          subclasses and are included for extensibility.

<literal>Point</literal>, <literal>LineString</literal>,
          <literal>Polygon</literal>,
          <literal>GeometryCollection</literal>,
          <literal>MultiPoint</literal>,
          <literal>MultiLineString</literal>, and
          <literal>MultiPolygon</literal> are instantiable classes.

Its <emphasis role="bold">MBR</emphasis> (minimum bounding
              rectangle), or envelope. This is the bounding geometry,
              formed by the minimum and maximum (X,Y) coordinates:

MySQL provides a standard way of creating spatial columns for
        geometry types, for example, with <literal role="stmt">CREATE
        TABLE</literal> or <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal>.
        Spatial columns are supported for
        <literal role="se">MyISAM</literal>,
        <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal>,
        <literal role="se">NDB</literal>, and
        <literal role="se">ARCHIVE</literal> tables. See also the notes
        about spatial indexes under
        <xref linkend="creating-spatial-indexes" />.

For <literal>InnoDB</literal> and <literal>MyISAM</literal>
        tables, MySQL can create spatial indexes using syntax similar to
        that for creating regular indexes, but using the
        <literal>SPATIAL</literal> keyword. Columns in spatial indexes
        must be declared <literal>NOT NULL</literal>. The following
        examples demonstrate how to create spatial indexes:

itemizedlist.para: With <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal>:

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
CREATE TABLE geom (g GEOMETRY NOT NULL, SPATIAL INDEX(g));

itemizedlist.para: With <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal>:
With <literal role="stmt">CREATE INDEX</literal>:

description.para:
<literal>SPATIAL INDEX</literal> creates an R-tree index. For
        storage engines that support nonspatial indexing of spatial
        columns, the engine creates a B-tree index. A B-tree index on
        spatial values is useful for exact-value lookups, but not for
        range scans.

For more information on indexing spatial columns, see
        <xref linkend="create-index" />.

To drop spatial indexes, use <literal role="stmt">ALTER
        TABLE</literal> or <literal role="stmt">DROP INDEX</literal>:

itemizedlist.para: With <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal>:

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
ALTER TABLE geom DROP INDEX g;

itemizedlist.para: With <literal role="stmt">DROP INDEX</literal>:

description.para:
Example: Suppose that a table <literal>geom</literal> contains
        more than 32,000 geometries, which are stored in the column
        <literal>g</literal> of type <literal>GEOMETRY</literal>. The
        table also has an <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> column
        <literal>fid</literal> for storing object ID values.

Equal:

<literal>NULL</literal>-safe equal. This operator performs
            an equality comparison like the
            <literal condition="equal" role="op">=</literal> operator,
            but returns <literal>1</literal> rather than
            <literal>NULL</literal> if both operands are
            <literal>NULL</literal>, and <literal>0</literal> rather
            than <literal>NULL</literal> if one operand is
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

The
            <literal condition="equal-to" role="op"><=></literal>
            operator is equivalent to the standard SQL <literal>IS NOT
            DISTINCT FROM</literal> operator.
Not equal:

description.para: Greater than:

If <replaceable>expr</replaceable> is greater than or equal
            to <replaceable>min</replaceable> and
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable> is less than or equal to
            <replaceable>max</replaceable>,
            <literal role="op">BETWEEN</literal> returns
            <literal>1</literal>, otherwise it returns
            <literal>0</literal>. This is equivalent to the expression
            <literal>(<replaceable>min</replaceable> <=
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable> AND
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable> <=
            <replaceable>max</replaceable>)</literal> if all the
            arguments are of the same type. Otherwise type conversion
            takes place according to the rules described in
            <xref linkend="type-conversion" />, but applied to all the
            three arguments.

This is the same as <literal>NOT
            (<replaceable>expr</replaceable> BETWEEN
            <replaceable>min</replaceable> AND
            <replaceable>max</replaceable>)</literal>.

syntax.para:
<indexterm>
              <primary>NOT BETWEEN</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal condition="not-between" role="op"><replaceable>expr</replaceable>
            NOT BETWEEN <replaceable>min</replaceable> AND
            <replaceable>max</replaceable></literal>

description.para:
Returns the first non-<literal>NULL</literal> value in the
            list, or <literal>NULL</literal> if there are no
            non-<literal>NULL</literal> values.

The return type of <literal role="func">COALESCE()</literal>
            is the aggregated type of the argument types.

With two or more arguments, returns the largest
            (maximum-valued) argument. The arguments are compared using
            the same rules as for
            <literal role="func">LEAST()</literal>.

Returns <literal>1</literal> (true) if
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable> is equal to any of the
            values in the <literal>IN()</literal> list, else returns
            <literal>0</literal> (false).

Type conversion takes place according to the rules described
            in <xref linkend="type-conversion" />, applied to all the
            arguments. If no type conversion is needed for the values in
            the <literal>IN()</literal> list, they are all constants of
            the same type, and <replaceable>expr</replaceable> can be
            compared to each of them as a value of the same type
            (possibly after type conversion), an optimization takes
            place. The values the list are sorted and the search for
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable> is done using a binary
            search, which makes the <literal>IN()</literal> operation
            very quick.

This is the same as <literal>NOT
            (<replaceable>expr</replaceable> IN
            (<replaceable>value</replaceable>,...))</literal>.

Returns <literal>0</literal> if <replaceable>N</replaceable>
            < <replaceable>N1</replaceable>, <literal>1</literal> if
            <replaceable>N</replaceable> <
            <replaceable>N2</replaceable> and so on or
            <literal>-1</literal> if <replaceable>N</replaceable> is
            <literal>NULL</literal>. All arguments are treated as
            integers. It is required that <replaceable>N1</replaceable>
            < <replaceable>N2</replaceable> <
            <replaceable>N3</replaceable> < <literal>...</literal>
            < <replaceable>Nn</replaceable> for this function to work
            correctly. This is because a binary search is used (very
            fast).

Tests a value against a boolean value, where
            <replaceable>boolean_value</replaceable> can be
            <literal>TRUE</literal>, <literal>FALSE</literal>, or
            <literal>UNKNOWN</literal>.

              <primary>TRUE</primary>

            </indexterm>

description.para:
If <replaceable>expr</replaceable> is
            <literal>NULL</literal>,
            <literal role="func">ISNULL()</literal> returns
            <literal>1</literal>, otherwise it returns
            <literal>0</literal>.

With two or more arguments, returns the smallest
            (minimum-valued) argument. The arguments are compared using
            the following rules:

itemizedlist.para:
If any argument is <literal>NULL</literal>, the result
                is <literal>NULL</literal>. No comparison is needed.

If all arguments are integer-valued, they are compared
                as integers.

If at least one argument is double precision, they are
                compared as double-precision values. Otherwise, if at
                least one argument is a
                <literal role="type">DECIMAL</literal> value, they are
                compared as <literal role="type">DECIMAL</literal>
                values.

If the arguments comprise a mix of numbers and strings,
                they are compared as numbers.

If any argument is a nonbinary (character) string, the
                arguments are compared as nonbinary strings.

In all other cases, the arguments are compared as binary
                strings.

description.para:
The return type of <literal role="func">LEAST()</literal> is
            the aggregated type of the comparison argument types.

Logical NOT. Evaluates to <literal>1</literal> if the
            operand is <literal>0</literal>, to <literal>0</literal> if
            the operand is nonzero, and <literal>NOT NULL</literal>
            returns <literal>NULL</literal>.

Logical AND. Evaluates to <literal>1</literal> if all
            operands are nonzero and not <literal>NULL</literal>, to
            <literal>0</literal> if one or more operands are
            <literal>0</literal>, otherwise <literal>NULL</literal> is
            returned.

Logical OR. When both operands are
            non-<literal>NULL</literal>, the result is
            <literal>1</literal> if any operand is nonzero, and
            <literal>0</literal> otherwise. With a
            <literal>NULL</literal> operand, the result is
            <literal>1</literal> if the other operand is nonzero, and
            <literal>NULL</literal> otherwise. If both operands are
            <literal>NULL</literal>, the result is
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

Logical XOR. Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if either
            operand is <literal>NULL</literal>. For
            non-<literal>NULL</literal> operands, evaluates to
            <literal>1</literal> if an odd number of operands is
            nonzero, otherwise <literal>0</literal> is returned.

Assignment operator. Causes the user variable on the left
            hand side of the operator to take on the value to its right.
            The value on the right hand side may be a literal value,
            another variable storing a value, or any legal expression
            that yields a scalar value, including the result of a query
            (provided that this value is a scalar value). You can
            perform multiple assignments in the same
            <literal condition="set-variable" role="stmt">SET</literal>
            statement. You can perform multiple assignments in the same
            statement.

Unlike
            <literal condition="assign-equal" role="op">=</literal>, the
            <literal condition="assign-value" role="op">:=</literal>
            operator is never interpreted as a comparison operator. This
            means you can use
            <literal condition="assign-value" role="op">:=</literal> in
            any valid SQL statement (not just in
            <literal condition="set-variable" role="stmt">SET</literal>
            statements) to assign a value to a variable.

This operator is used to perform value assignments in two
            cases, described in the next two paragraphs.

Within a
            <literal condition="set-variable" role="stmt">SET</literal>
            statement, <literal>=</literal> is treated as an assignment
            operator that causes the user variable on the left hand side
            of the operator to take on the value to its right. (In other
            words, when used in a
            <literal condition="set-variable" role="stmt">SET</literal>
            statement, <literal>=</literal> is treated identically to
            <literal condition="assign-value" role="op">:=</literal>.)
            The value on the right hand side may be a literal value,
            another variable storing a value, or any legal expression
            that yields a scalar value, including the result of a query
            (provided that this value is a scalar value). You can
            perform multiple assignments in the same
            <literal condition="set-variable" role="stmt">SET</literal>
            statement.

In the <literal>SET</literal> clause of an
            <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> statement,
            <literal>=</literal> also acts as an assignment operator; in
            this case, however, it causes the column named on the left
            hand side of the operator to assume the value given to the
            right, provided any <literal>WHERE</literal> conditions that
            are part of the <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> are
            met. You can make multiple assignments in the same
            <literal>SET</literal> clause of an
            <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> statement.

In any other context, <literal>=</literal> is treated as a
            <link linkend="operator_equal">comparison operator</link>.

syntax.para:
<indexterm>
              <primary>= (assignment operator)</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>assignment operator</primary>
              <secondary>=</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <indexterm>
              <primary>SET statement</primary>
              <secondary>assignment operator</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal condition="assign-equal" role="op">=</literal>

description.para:
The first <literal role="op">CASE</literal> syntax returns the
          <replaceable>result</replaceable> for the first
          <literal><replaceable>value</replaceable>=<replaceable>compare_value</replaceable></literal>
          comparison that is true. The second syntax returns the result
          for the first condition that is true. If no comparison or
          condition is true, the result after <literal>ELSE</literal> is
          returned, or <literal>NULL</literal> if there is no
          <literal>ELSE</literal> part.

The return type of a <literal role="op">CASE</literal>
          expression result is the aggregated type of all result values.

syntax.para:
<indexterm>
            <primary>CASE</primary>
          </indexterm>

          <literal condition="case" role="op">CASE
          <replaceable>value</replaceable> WHEN
          [<replaceable>compare_value</replaceable>] THEN
          <replaceable>result</replaceable> [WHEN
          [<replaceable>compare_value</replaceable>] THEN
          <replaceable>result</replaceable> ...] [ELSE
          <replaceable>result</replaceable>] END</literal>

<literal condition="case" role="op">CASE WHEN
          [<replaceable>condition</replaceable>] THEN
          <replaceable>result</replaceable> [WHEN
          [<replaceable>condition</replaceable>] THEN
          <replaceable>result</replaceable> ...] [ELSE
          <replaceable>result</replaceable>] END</literal>

description.para:
If <replaceable>expr1</replaceable> is <literal>TRUE</literal>
          (<literal><replaceable>expr1</replaceable> <>
          0</literal> and <literal><replaceable>expr1</replaceable>
          <> NULL</literal>), <literal role="func">IF()</literal>
          returns <replaceable>expr2</replaceable>. Otherwise, it
          returns <replaceable>expr3</replaceable>.

If only one of <replaceable>expr2</replaceable> or
          <replaceable>expr3</replaceable> is explicitly
          <literal>NULL</literal>, the result type of the
          <literal role="func">IF()</literal> function is the type of
          the non-<literal>NULL</literal> expression.

The default return type of <literal role="func">IF()</literal>
          (which may matter when it is stored into a temporary table) is
          calculated as follows:

itemizedlist.para:
If <replaceable>expr2</replaceable> or
              <replaceable>expr3</replaceable> produce a string, the
              result is a string.

If <replaceable>expr2</replaceable> and
              <replaceable>expr3</replaceable> are both strings, the
              result is case-sensitive if either string is case
              sensitive.

If <replaceable>expr2</replaceable> or
              <replaceable>expr3</replaceable> produce a floating-point
              value, the result is a floating-point value.

If <replaceable>expr2</replaceable> or
              <replaceable>expr3</replaceable> produce an integer, the
              result is an integer.

description.para:
If <replaceable>expr1</replaceable> is not
          <literal>NULL</literal>,
          <literal role="func">IFNULL()</literal> returns
          <replaceable>expr1</replaceable>; otherwise it returns
          <replaceable>expr2</replaceable>.

Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if
          <literal><replaceable>expr1</replaceable> =
          <replaceable>expr2</replaceable></literal> is true, otherwise
          returns <replaceable>expr1</replaceable>. This is the same as
          <literal condition="case" role="op">CASE WHEN
          <replaceable>expr1</replaceable> =
          <replaceable>expr2</replaceable> THEN NULL ELSE
          <replaceable>expr1</replaceable> END</literal>.
The return value has the same type as the first argument.

Returns the numeric value of the leftmost character of the
          string <replaceable>str</replaceable>. Returns
          <literal>0</literal> if <replaceable>str</replaceable> is the
          empty string. Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> is <literal>NULL</literal>.
          <literal role="func">ASCII()</literal> works for 8-bit
          characters.

Returns a string representation of the binary value of
          <replaceable>N</replaceable>, where
          <replaceable>N</replaceable> is a longlong
          (<literal role="type">BIGINT</literal>) number. This is
          equivalent to
          <literal role="func">CONV(<replaceable>N</replaceable>,10,2)</literal>.
          Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if
          <replaceable>N</replaceable> is <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the length of the string
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> in bits.

By default, <literal role="func">CHAR()</literal> returns a
          binary string. To produce a string in a given character set,
          use the optional <literal>USING</literal> clause:

If <literal>USING</literal> is given and the result string is
          illegal for the given character set, a warning is issued.
          Also, if strict SQL mode is enabled, the result from
          <literal role="func">CHAR()</literal> becomes
          <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the length of the string
          <replaceable>str</replaceable>, measured in characters. A
          multibyte character counts as a single character. This means
          that for a string containing five 2-byte characters,
          <literal role="func">LENGTH()</literal> returns
          <literal>10</literal>, whereas
          <literal role="func">CHAR_LENGTH()</literal> returns
          <literal>5</literal>.

<literal role="func">CHARACTER_LENGTH()</literal> is a synonym
          for <literal role="func">CHAR_LENGTH()</literal>.

Returns the string that results from concatenating the
          arguments. May have one or more arguments. If all arguments
          are nonbinary strings, the result is a nonbinary string. If
          the arguments include any binary strings, the result is a
          binary string. A numeric argument is converted to its
          equivalent nonbinary string form.

<literal role="func">CONCAT()</literal> returns
          <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>.

<literal role="func">CONCAT_WS()</literal> stands for
          Concatenate With Separator and is a special form of
          <literal role="func">CONCAT()</literal>. The first argument is
          the separator for the rest of the arguments. The separator is
          added between the strings to be concatenated. The separator
          can be a string, as can the rest of the arguments. If the
          separator is <literal>NULL</literal>, the result is
          <literal>NULL</literal>.

<literal role="func">ELT()</literal> returns the
          <replaceable>N</replaceable>th element of the list of strings:
          <replaceable>str1</replaceable> if
          <replaceable>N</replaceable> = <literal>1</literal>,
          <replaceable>str2</replaceable> if
          <replaceable>N</replaceable> = <literal>2</literal>, and so
          on. Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if
          <replaceable>N</replaceable> is less than <literal>1</literal>
          or greater than the number of arguments.
          <literal role="func">ELT()</literal> is the complement of
          <literal role="func">FIELD()</literal>.

Returns a string such that for every bit set in the value
          <replaceable>bits</replaceable>, you get an
          <replaceable>on</replaceable> string and for every bit not set
          in the value, you get an <replaceable>off</replaceable>
          string. Bits in <replaceable>bits</replaceable> are examined
          from right to left (from low-order to high-order bits).
          Strings are added to the result from left to right, separated
          by the <replaceable>separator</replaceable> string (the
          default being the comma character <literal>,</literal>). The
          number of bits examined is given by
          <replaceable>number_of_bits</replaceable>, which has a default
          of 64 if not specified.
          <replaceable>number_of_bits</replaceable> is silently clipped
          to 64 if larger than 64. It is treated as an unsigned integer,
          so a value of minus1 is effectively the same as 64.

Returns the index (position) of <replaceable>str</replaceable>
          in the <replaceable>str1</replaceable>,
          <replaceable>str2</replaceable>,
          <replaceable>str3</replaceable>, <literal>...</literal> list.
          Returns <literal>0</literal> if <replaceable>str</replaceable>
          is not found.

If all arguments to <literal role="func">FIELD()</literal> are
          strings, all arguments are compared as strings. If all
          arguments are numbers, they are compared as numbers.
          Otherwise, the arguments are compared as double.

If <replaceable>str</replaceable> is <literal>NULL</literal>,
          the return value is <literal>0</literal> because
          <literal>NULL</literal> fails equality comparison with any
          value. <literal role="func">FIELD()</literal> is the
          complement of <literal role="func">ELT()</literal>.

Returns a value in the range of 1 to
          <replaceable>N</replaceable> if the string
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> is in the string list
          <replaceable>strlist</replaceable> consisting of
          <replaceable>N</replaceable> substrings. A string list is a
          string composed of substrings separated by
          <literal>,</literal> characters. If the first argument is a
          constant string and the second is a column of type
          <literal role="type">SET</literal>, the
          <literal role="func">FIND_IN_SET()</literal> function is
          optimized to use bit arithmetic. Returns <literal>0</literal>
          if <replaceable>str</replaceable> is not in
          <replaceable>strlist</replaceable> or if
          <replaceable>strlist</replaceable> is the empty string.
          Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if either argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>. This function does not work properly
          if the first argument contains a comma (<literal>,</literal>)
          character.

Formats the number <replaceable>X</replaceable> to a format
          like <literal>'#,###,###.##'</literal>, rounded to
          <replaceable>D</replaceable> decimal places, and returns the
          result as a string. If <replaceable>D</replaceable> is
          <literal>0</literal>, the result has no decimal point or
          fractional part.

The optional third parameter enables a locale to be specified
          to be used for the result number's decimal point, thousands
          separator, and grouping between separators. Permissible locale
          values are the same as the legal values for the
          <literal role="sysvar">lc_time_names</literal> system variable
          (see <xref linkend="locale-support" />). If no locale is
          specified, the default is <literal>'en_US'</literal>.

Takes a string encoded with the base-64 encoded rules used by
          <literal role="func">TO_BASE64()</literal> and returns the
          decoded result as a binary string. The result is
          <literal>NULL</literal> if the argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal> or not a valid base-64 string. See the
          description of <literal role="func">TO_BASE64()</literal> for
          details about the encoding and decoding rules.

For a string argument <replaceable>str</replaceable>,
          <literal role="func">HEX()</literal> returns a hexadecimal
          string representation of <replaceable>str</replaceable> where
          each byte of each character in <replaceable>str</replaceable>
          is converted to two hexadecimal digits. (Multibyte characters
          therefore become more than two digits.) The inverse of this
          operation is performed by the
          <literal role="func">UNHEX()</literal> function.

For a numeric argument <replaceable>N</replaceable>,
          <literal role="func">HEX()</literal> returns a hexadecimal
          string representation of the value of
          <replaceable>N</replaceable> treated as a longlong
          (<literal role="type">BIGINT</literal>) number. This is
          equivalent to
          <literal role="func">CONV(<replaceable>N</replaceable>,10,16)</literal>.
          The inverse of this operation is performed by
          <literal role="func">CONV(HEX(<replaceable>N</replaceable>),16,10)</literal>.

Returns the string <replaceable>str</replaceable>, with the
          substring beginning at position <replaceable>pos</replaceable>
          and <replaceable>len</replaceable> characters long replaced by
          the string <replaceable>newstr</replaceable>. Returns the
          original string if <replaceable>pos</replaceable> is not
          within the length of the string. Replaces the rest of the
          string from position <replaceable>pos</replaceable> if
          <replaceable>len</replaceable> is not within the length of the
          rest of the string. Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if any
          argument is <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the position of the first occurrence of substring
          <replaceable>substr</replaceable> in string
          <replaceable>str</replaceable>. This is the same as the
          two-argument form of <literal role="func">LOCATE()</literal>,
          except that the order of the arguments is reversed.

<literal role="func">LCASE()</literal> is a synonym for
          <literal role="func">LOWER()</literal>.

Returns the leftmost <replaceable>len</replaceable> characters
          from the string <replaceable>str</replaceable>, or
          <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the length of the string
          <replaceable>str</replaceable>, measured in bytes. A multibyte
          character counts as multiple bytes. This means that for a
          string containing five 2-byte characters,
          <literal role="func">LENGTH()</literal> returns
          <literal>10</literal>, whereas
          <literal role="func">CHAR_LENGTH()</literal> returns
          <literal>5</literal>.

Reads the file and returns the file contents as a string. To
          use this function, the file must be located on the server
          host, you must specify the full path name to the file, and you
          must have the <literal role="priv">FILE</literal> privilege.
          The file must be readable by all and its size less than
          <literal role="sysvar">max_allowed_packet</literal> bytes. If
          the <literal role="sysvar">secure_file_priv</literal> system
          variable is set to a nonempty directory name, the file to be
          loaded must be located in that directory.

If the file does not exist or cannot be read because one of
          the preceding conditions is not satisfied, the function
          returns <literal>NULL</literal>.

The <literal role="sysvar">character_set_filesystem</literal>
          system variable controls interpretation of file names that are
          given as literal strings.

The first syntax returns the position of the first occurrence
          of substring <replaceable>substr</replaceable> in string
          <replaceable>str</replaceable>. The second syntax returns the
          position of the first occurrence of substring
          <replaceable>substr</replaceable> in string
          <replaceable>str</replaceable>, starting at position
          <replaceable>pos</replaceable>. Returns <literal>0</literal>
          if <replaceable>substr</replaceable> is not in
          <replaceable>str</replaceable>. Returns
          <literal>NULL</literal> if <replaceable>substr</replaceable>
          or <replaceable>str</replaceable> is <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the string <replaceable>str</replaceable> with all
          characters changed to lowercase according to the current
          character set mapping. The default is
          <literal>latin1</literal> (cp1252 West European).

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT LOWER('QUADRATICALLY');</userinput>
        -> 'quadratically'

description.para:
<literal role="func">LOWER()</literal> (and
          <literal role="func">UPPER()</literal>) are ineffective when
          applied to binary strings
          (<literal role="type">BINARY</literal>,
          <literal role="type">VARBINARY</literal>,
          <literal role="type">BLOB</literal>). To perform lettercase
          conversion, convert the string to a nonbinary string:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SET @str = BINARY 'New York';</userinput>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT LOWER(@str), LOWER(CONVERT(@str USING latin1));</userinput>
+-------------+-----------------------------------+
| LOWER(@str) | LOWER(CONVERT(@str USING latin1)) |
+-------------+-----------------------------------+
| New York    | new york                          |
+-------------+-----------------------------------+

description.para:
For collations of Unicode character sets,
          <literal role="func">LOWER()</literal> and
          <literal role="func">UPPER()</literal> work according to the
          Unicode Collation Algorithm (UCA) version in the collation
          name, if there is one, and UCA 4.0.0 if no version is
          specified. For example, <literal>utf8_unicode_520_ci</literal>
          works according to UCA 5.2.0, whereas
          <literal>utf8_unicode_ci</literal> works according to UCA
          4.0.0. See <xref linkend="charset-unicode-sets" />.

Returns the string <replaceable>str</replaceable>, left-padded
          with the string <replaceable>padstr</replaceable> to a length
          of <replaceable>len</replaceable> characters. If
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> is longer than
          <replaceable>len</replaceable>, the return value is shortened
          to <replaceable>len</replaceable> characters.

Returns the string <replaceable>str</replaceable> with leading
          space characters removed.

Returns a set value (a string containing substrings separated
          by <literal>,</literal> characters) consisting of the strings
          that have the corresponding bit in
          <replaceable>bits</replaceable> set.
          <replaceable>str1</replaceable> corresponds to bit 0,
          <replaceable>str2</replaceable> to bit 1, and so on.
          <literal>NULL</literal> values in
          <replaceable>str1</replaceable>,
          <replaceable>str2</replaceable>, <literal>...</literal> are
          not appended to the result.

<literal role="func">MID(<replaceable>str</replaceable>,<replaceable>pos</replaceable>,<replaceable>len</replaceable>)</literal>
          is a synonym for
          <literal role="func">SUBSTRING(<replaceable>str</replaceable>,<replaceable>pos</replaceable>,<replaceable>len</replaceable>)</literal>.

Returns a string representation of the octal value of
          <replaceable>N</replaceable>, where
          <replaceable>N</replaceable> is a longlong
          (<literal role="type">BIGINT</literal>) number. This is
          equivalent to
          <literal role="func">CONV(<replaceable>N</replaceable>,10,8)</literal>.
          Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if
          <replaceable>N</replaceable> is <literal>NULL</literal>.

<literal role="func">OCTET_LENGTH()</literal> is a synonym for
          <literal role="func">LENGTH()</literal>.

If the leftmost character of the string
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> is a multibyte character,
          returns the code for that character, calculated from the
          numeric values of its constituent bytes using this formula:

description.programlisting:
>
  (1st byte code)
+ (2nd byte code * 256)
+ (3rd byte code * 256^2) ...

description.para:
If the leftmost character is not a multibyte character,
          <literal role="func">ORD()</literal> returns the same value as
          the <literal role="func">ASCII()</literal> function.

<literal role="func">POSITION(<replaceable>substr</replaceable>
          IN <replaceable>str</replaceable>)</literal> is a synonym for
          <literal role="func">LOCATE(<replaceable>substr</replaceable>,<replaceable>str</replaceable>)</literal>.

Quotes a string to produce a result that can be used as a
          properly escaped data value in an SQL statement. The string is
          returned enclosed by single quotation marks and with each
          instance of backslash (<literal>\</literal>), single quote
          (<literal>'</literal>), ASCII <literal>NUL</literal>, and
          Control+Z preceded by a backslash. If the argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>, the return value is the word
          <quote>NULL</quote> without enclosing single quotation marks.

Returns a string consisting of the string
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> repeated
          <replaceable>count</replaceable> times. If
          <replaceable>count</replaceable> is less than 1, returns an
          empty string. Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> or
          <replaceable>count</replaceable> are <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the string <replaceable>str</replaceable> with all
          occurrences of the string <replaceable>from_str</replaceable>
          replaced by the string <replaceable>to_str</replaceable>.
          <literal role="func">REPLACE()</literal> performs a
          case-sensitive match when searching for
          <replaceable>from_str</replaceable>.

Returns the string <replaceable>str</replaceable> with the
          order of the characters reversed.

Returns the rightmost <replaceable>len</replaceable>
          characters from the string <replaceable>str</replaceable>, or
          <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the string <replaceable>str</replaceable>,
          right-padded with the string <replaceable>padstr</replaceable>
          to a length of <replaceable>len</replaceable> characters. If
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> is longer than
          <replaceable>len</replaceable>, the return value is shortened
          to <replaceable>len</replaceable> characters.

Returns the string <replaceable>str</replaceable> with
          trailing space characters removed.

Returns a soundex string from <replaceable>str</replaceable>.
          Two strings that sound almost the same should have identical
          soundex strings. A standard soundex string is four characters
          long, but the <literal role="func">SOUNDEX()</literal>
          function returns an arbitrarily long string. You can use
          <literal role="func">SUBSTRING()</literal> on the result to
          get a standard soundex string. All nonalphabetic characters in
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> are ignored. All international
          alphabetic characters outside the A-Z range are treated as
          vowels.

itemizedlist.para:
This function, as currently implemented, is intended to
              work well with strings that are in the English language
              only. Strings in other languages may not produce reliable
              results.

This function is not guaranteed to provide consistent
              results with strings that use multibyte character sets,
              including <literal>utf-8</literal>. See Bug #22638 for
              more information.

description.para:
This is the same as
          <literal role="func">SOUNDEX(<replaceable>expr1</replaceable>)
          = SOUNDEX(<replaceable>expr2</replaceable>)</literal>.

Returns a string consisting of <replaceable>N</replaceable>
          space characters.

<literal role="func">SUBSTR()</literal> is a synonym for
          <literal role="func">SUBSTRING()</literal>.

The forms without a <replaceable>len</replaceable> argument
          return a substring from string <replaceable>str</replaceable>
          starting at position <replaceable>pos</replaceable>. The forms
          with a <replaceable>len</replaceable> argument return a
          substring <replaceable>len</replaceable> characters long from
          string <replaceable>str</replaceable>, starting at position
          <replaceable>pos</replaceable>. The forms that use
          <literal>FROM</literal> are standard SQL syntax. It is also
          possible to use a negative value for
          <replaceable>pos</replaceable>. In this case, the beginning of
          the substring is <replaceable>pos</replaceable> characters
          from the end of the string, rather than the beginning. A
          negative value may be used for <replaceable>pos</replaceable>
          in any of the forms of this function. A value of 0 for
          <replaceable>pos</replaceable> returns an empty string.

For all forms of <literal role="func">SUBSTRING()</literal>,
          the position of the first character in the string from which
          the substring is to be extracted is reckoned as
          <literal>1</literal>.

Returns the substring from string
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> before
          <replaceable>count</replaceable> occurrences of the delimiter
          <replaceable>delim</replaceable>. If
          <replaceable>count</replaceable> is positive, everything to
          the left of the final delimiter (counting from the left) is
          returned. If <replaceable>count</replaceable> is negative,
          everything to the right of the final delimiter (counting from
          the right) is returned.
          <literal role="func">SUBSTRING_INDEX()</literal> performs a
          case-sensitive match when searching for
          <replaceable>delim</replaceable>.

Converts the string argument to base-64 encoded form and
          returns the result as a character string with the connection
          character set and collation. If the argument is not a string,
          it is converted to a string before conversion takes place. The
          result is <literal>NULL</literal> if the argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>. Base-64 encoded strings can be
          decoded using the <literal role="func">FROM_BASE64()</literal>
          function.

Returns the string <replaceable>str</replaceable> with all
          <replaceable>remstr</replaceable> prefixes or suffixes
          removed. If none of the specifiers <literal>BOTH</literal>,
          <literal>LEADING</literal>, or <literal>TRAILING</literal> is
          given, <literal>BOTH</literal> is assumed.
          <replaceable>remstr</replaceable> is optional and, if not
