Returns the character set of the string argument.

Returns the collation coercibility value of the string
          argument.
Returns the collation of the string argument.

Returns the connection ID (thread ID) for the connection.
          Every connection has an ID that is unique among the set of
          currently connected clients.

The value returned by
          <literal role="func">CONNECTION_ID()</literal> is the same
          type of value as displayed in the <literal>ID</literal> column
          of the
          <literal role="is">INFORMATION_SCHEMA.PROCESSLIST</literal>
          table, the <literal>Id</literal> column of
          <literal role="stmt">SHOW PROCESSLIST</literal> output, and
          the <literal>PROCESSLIST_ID</literal> column of the
          Performance Schema <literal role="ps">threads</literal> table.

Returns the user name and host name combination for the MySQL
          account that the server used to authenticate the current
          client. This account determines your access privileges. The
          return value is a string in the <literal>utf8</literal>
          character set.

The value of <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER()</literal> can
          differ from the value of
          <literal role="func">USER()</literal>.

Returns the default (current) database name as a string in the
          <literal>utf8</literal> character set. If there is no default
          database, <literal role="func">DATABASE()</literal> returns
          <literal>NULL</literal>. Within a stored routine, the default
          database is the database that the routine is associated with,
          which is not necessarily the same as the database that is the
          default in the calling context.

A <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement may include
          a <literal>LIMIT</literal> clause to restrict the number of
          rows the server returns to the client. In some cases, it is
          desirable to know how many rows the statement would have
          returned without the <literal>LIMIT</literal>, but without
          running the statement again. To obtain this row count, include
          an <literal>SQL_CALC_FOUND_ROWS</literal> option in the
          <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement, and then
          invoke <literal role="func">FOUND_ROWS()</literal> afterward:

With no argument,
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> returns a
          <literal>BIGINT UNSIGNED</literal> (64-bit) value representing
          the first automatically generated value successfully inserted
          for an <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> column as a result of
          the most recently executed
          <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> statement. The value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> remains
          unchanged if no rows are successfully inserted.

With an argument,
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> returns an
          unsigned integer.

For example, after inserting a row that generates an
          <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> value, you can get the value
          like this:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT LAST_INSERT_ID();</userinput>
        -> 195

description.para:
The currently executing statement does not affect the value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal>. Suppose that
          you generate an <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> value with
          one statement, and then refer to
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> in a
          multiple-row <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> statement
          that inserts rows into a table with its own
          <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> column. The value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> will remain
          stable in the second statement; its value for the second and
          later rows is not affected by the earlier row insertions.
          (However, if you mix references to
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> and
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID(<replaceable>expr</replaceable>)</literal>,
          the effect is undefined.)

If the previous statement returned an error, the value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> is undefined.
          For transactional tables, if the statement is rolled back due
          to an error, the value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> is left
          undefined. For manual
          <literal condition="commit" role="stmt">ROLLBACK</literal>,
          the value of <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal>
          is not restored to that before the transaction; it remains as
          it was at the point of the
          <literal condition="commit" role="stmt">ROLLBACK</literal>.

Prior to MySQL 5.7.3, this function was not replicated
          correctly if replication filtering rules were in use. (Bug
          #17234370, Bug #69861)

Within the body of a stored routine (procedure or function) or
          a trigger, the value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> changes the
          same way as for statements executed outside the body of these
          kinds of objects. The effect of a stored routine or trigger
          upon the value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> that is seen
          by following statements depends on the kind of routine:

itemizedlist.para:
If a stored procedure executes statements that change the
              value of <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal>,
              the changed value is seen by statements that follow the
              procedure call.

For stored functions and triggers that change the value,
              the value is restored when the function or trigger ends,
              so following statements will not see a changed value.

description.para: <literal>ROW_COUNT()</literal> returns a value as follows:

itemizedlist.para:
DDL statements: 0. This applies to statements such as
              <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal> or
              <literal role="stmt">DROP TABLE</literal>.

DML statements other than
              <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal>: The number of
              affected rows. This applies to statements such as
              <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal>,
              <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal>, or
              <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> (as before), but now
              also to statements such as <literal role="stmt">ALTER
              TABLE</literal> and <literal role="stmt">LOAD
              DATA</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal>: -1 if the statement
              returns a result set, or the number of rows
              <quote>affected</quote> if it does not. For example, for
              <literal>SELECT * FROM t1</literal>,
              <literal role="func">ROW_COUNT()</literal> returns -1. For
              <literal>SELECT * FROM t1 INTO OUTFILE
              '<replaceable>file_name</replaceable>'</literal>,
              <literal role="func">ROW_COUNT()</literal> returns the
              number of rows written to the file.
<literal role="stmt">SIGNAL</literal> statements: 0.

description.para:
For <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> statements, the
          affected-rows value by default is the number of rows actually
          changed. If you specify the
          <literal>CLIENT_FOUND_ROWS</literal> flag to
          <literal role="cfunc">mysql_real_connect()</literal> when
          connecting to <command>mysqld</command>, the affected-rows
          value is the number of rows <quote>found</quote>; that is,
          matched by the <literal>WHERE</literal> clause.

For <literal role="stmt">REPLACE</literal> statements, the
          affected-rows value is 2 if the new row replaced an old row,
          because in this case, one row was inserted after the duplicate
          was deleted.

For
          <literal condition="insert-on-duplicate" role="stmt">INSERT
          ... ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE</literal> statements, the
          affected-rows value per row is 1 if the row is inserted as a
          new row, 2 if an existing row is updated, and 0 if an existing
          row is set to its current values. If you specify the
          <literal>CLIENT_FOUND_ROWS</literal> flag, the affected-rows
          value is 1 (not 0) if an existing row is set to its current
          values.

The <literal role="func">ROW_COUNT()</literal> value is
          similar to the value from the
          <literal role="cfunc">mysql_affected_rows()</literal> C API
          function and the row count that the <command>mysql</command>
          client displays following statement execution.

This function is a synonym for
          <literal role="func">DATABASE()</literal>.

<literal role="func">SESSION_USER()</literal> is a synonym for
          <literal role="func">USER()</literal>.

<literal role="func">SYSTEM_USER()</literal> is a synonym for
          <literal role="func">USER()</literal>.

Returns the current MySQL user name and host name as a string
          in the <literal>utf8</literal> character set.

Returns a string that indicates the MySQL server version. The
          string uses the <literal>utf8</literal> character set. The
          value might have a suffix in addition to the version number.
          See the description of the
          <literal role="sysvar">version</literal> system variable in
          <xref linkend="server-system-variables" />.

Given two sets of global transaction IDs
          <replaceable>set1</replaceable> and
          <replaceable>set2</replaceable>, returns true if all GTIDs in
          <replaceable>set1</replaceable> are also in
          <replaceable>set2</replaceable>. Returns false otherwise.

Given two sets of global transaction IDs
          <replaceable>set1</replaceable> and
          <replaceable>set2</replaceable>, returns only those GTIDs from
          <replaceable>set1</replaceable> that are not in
          <replaceable>set2</replaceable>.

Wait until the server has applied all of the transactions
          whose global transaction identifiers are contained in
          <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>; that is, until the
          condition GTID_SUBSET(<replaceable>gtid_subset</replaceable>,
          <literal>@@GLOBAL.gtid_executed</literal>) holds. See
          <xref linkend="replication-gtids-concepts" /> for a definition
          of GTID sets.

If a timeout is specified, and
          <replaceable>timeout</replaceable> seconds elapse before all
          of the transactions in the GTID set have been applied, the
          function stops waiting. <replaceable>timeout</replaceable> is
          optional, and the default timeout is 0 seconds, in which case
          the function always waits until all of the transactions in the
          GTID set have been applied.

<literal>WAIT_FOR_EXECUTED_GTID_SET()</literal> monitors all
          the GTIDs that are applied on the server, including
          transactions that arrive from all replication channels and
          user clients. It does not take into account whether
          replication channels have been started or stopped.
For more information, see <xref linkend="replication-gtids" />.

<literal>WAIT_UNTIL_SQL_THREAD_AFTER_GTIDS()</literal> is
          similar to <literal>WAIT_FOR_EXECUTED_GTID_SET()</literal> in
          that it waits until all of the transactions whose global
          transaction identifiers are contained in
          <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable> have been applied, or
          until <replaceable>timeout</replaceable> seconds have elapsed,
          whichever occurs first. However,
          <literal>WAIT_UNTIL_SQL_THREAD_AFTER_GTIDS()</literal> applies
          to a specific replication channel, and stops only after the
          transactions have been applied on the specified channel, for
          which the applier must be running. In contrast,
          <literal>WAIT_FOR_EXECUTED_GTID_SET()</literal> stops after
          the transactions have been applied, regardless of where they
          were applied (on any replication channel or any user client),
          and whether or not any replication channels are running.

The <replaceable>channel</replaceable> option names which
          replication channel the function applies to. If no channel is
          named and no channels other than the default replication
          channel exist, the function applies to the default replication
          channel. If multiple replication channels exist, you must
          specify a channel as otherwise it is not known which
          replication channel the function applies to. See
          <xref linkend="replication-channels" /> for more
          information on replication channels.

GTID sets used with
          <literal>WAIT_UNTIL_SQL_THREAD_AFTER_GTIDS()</literal> are
          represented as strings and must be quoted in the same way as
          for <literal>WAIT_FOR_EXECUTED_GTID_SET()</literal>. For
          <literal>WAIT_UNTIL_SQL_THREAD_AFTER_GTIDS()</literal>, the
          return value for the function is an arbitrary positive number.
          If GTID-based replication is not active (that is, if the value
          of the <literal role="sysvar">gtid_mode</literal> variable is
          OFF), then this value is undefined and
          <literal>WAIT_UNTIL_SQL_THREAD_AFTER_GTIDS()</literal> returns
          NULL. If the slave is not running then the function also
          returns NULL.

<literal role="sysvar">gtid_mode</literal> cannot be changed
          to OFF while any client is using this function to wait for
          GTIDs to be applied.

Decrypts an encrypted string using the given algorithm and
            key string, and returns the resulting plaintext as a binary
            string. If decryption fails, the result is
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

<replaceable>key_str</replaceable> must be a valid key
            string in PEM format. For successful decryption, it must be
            the public or private key string corresponding to the
            private or public key string used with
            <literal role="func">ASYMMETRIC_ENCRYPT()</literal> to
            produce the encrypted string.
            <replaceable>algorithm</replaceable> indicates the
            encryption algorithm used to create the key.

Supported <replaceable>algorithm</replaceable> values:
            <literal>'RSA'</literal>

For a usage example, see the description of
            <literal role="func">ASYMMETRIC_ENCRYPT()</literal>.

Derives a symmetric key using the private key of one party
            and the public key of another, and returns the resulting key
            as a binary string. If key derivation fails, the result is
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

<replaceable>pub_key_str</replaceable> and
            <replaceable>priv_key_str</replaceable> must be valid key
            strings in PEM format. They must be created using the DH
            algorithm.
Suppose that you have two pairs of public and private keys:

Suppose further that you use the private key from one pair
            and the public key from the other pair to create a symmetric
            key string. Then this symmetric key identity relationship
            holds:

description.programlisting:
>
ASYMMETRIC_DERIVE(@pub1, @priv2) = ASYMMETRIC_DERIVE(@pub2, @priv1)

description.para:
Encrypts a string using the given algorithm and key string,
            and returns the resulting ciphertext as a binary string. If
            encryption fails, the result is <literal>NULL</literal>.

The <replaceable>str</replaceable> length cannot be greater
            than the <replaceable>key_str</replaceable> length minus
            11, in bytes

<replaceable>key_str</replaceable> must be a valid key
            string in PEM format. <replaceable>algorithm</replaceable>
            indicates the encryption algorithm used to create the key.

Supported <replaceable>algorithm</replaceable> values:
            <literal>'RSA'</literal>

To encrypt a string, pass a private or public key string to
            <literal role="func">ASYMMETRIC_ENCRYPT()</literal>. To
            recover the original unencrypted string, pass the encrypted
            string to
            <literal role="func">ASYMMETRIC_DECRYPT()</literal>, along
            with the public or private key string correponding to the
            private or public key string used for encryption.

Signs a digest string using a private key string, and
            returns the signature as a binary string. If signing fails,
            the result is <literal>NULL</literal>.

<replaceable>digest_str</replaceable> is the digest string.
            It can be generated by calling
            <literal role="func">CREATE_DIGEST()</literal>.
            <replaceable>digest_type</replaceable> indicates the digest
            algorithm used to generate the digest string.

<replaceable>priv_key_str</replaceable> is the private key
            string to use for signing the digest string. It must be a
            valid key string in PEM format.
            <replaceable>algorithm</replaceable> indicates the
            encryption algorithm used to create the key.

Supported <replaceable>algorithm</replaceable> values:
            <literal>'RSA'</literal>, <literal>'DSA'</literal>

Supported <replaceable>digest_type</replaceable> values:
            <literal>'SHA224'</literal>, <literal>'SHA256'</literal>,
            <literal>'SHA384'</literal>, <literal>'SHA512'</literal>

For a usage example, see the description of
            <literal role="func">ASYMMETRIC_VERIFY()</literal>.

Verifies whether the signature string matches the digest
            string, and returns 1 or 0 to indicate whether verification
            succeeded or failed.

<replaceable>digest_str</replaceable> is the digest string.
            It can be generated by calling
            <literal role="func">CREATE_DIGEST()</literal>.
            <replaceable>digest_type</replaceable> indicates the digest
            algorithm used to generate the digest string.

<replaceable>sig_str</replaceable> is the signature string.
            It can be generated by calling
            <literal role="func">ASYMMETRIC_SIGN()</literal>.

<replaceable>pub_key_str</replaceable> is the public key
            string of the signer. It corresponds to the private key
            passed to <literal role="func">ASYMMETRIC_SIGN()</literal>
            to generate the signature string and must be a valid key
            string in PEM format. <replaceable>algorithm</replaceable>
            indicates the encryption algorithm used to create the key.

Supported <replaceable>algorithm</replaceable> values:
            <literal>'RSA'</literal>, <literal>'DSA'</literal>

Supported <replaceable>digest_type</replaceable> values:
            <literal>'SHA224'</literal>, <literal>'SHA256'</literal>,
            <literal>'SHA384'</literal>, <literal>'SHA512'</literal>

Creates a private key using the given algorithm and key
            length or DH secret, and returns the key as a binary string
            in PEM format. If key generation fails, the result is
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

Supported <replaceable>algorithm</replaceable> values:
            <literal>'RSA'</literal>, <literal>'DSA'</literal>,
            <literal>'DH'</literal>

Supported <replaceable>key_len</replaceable> values: The
            minimum key length in bits is 1,024. The maximum key length
            depends on the algorithm: 16,384 for RSA and 10,000 for DSA.
            These key-length limits are constraints imposed by OpenSSL.
            Server administrators can impose additional limits on
            maximum key length by setting environment variables. See
            <xref linkend="enterprise-encryption-usage" />.

For DH keys, pass a shared DH secret instead of a key
            length. To create the secret, pass the key length to
            <literal role="func">CREATE_DH_PARAMETERS()</literal>.

Derives a public key from the given private key using the
            given algorithm, and returns the key as a binary string in
            PEM format. If key derivation fails, the result is
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

<replaceable>priv_key_str</replaceable> must be a valid key
            string in PEM format. <replaceable>algorithm</replaceable>
            indicates the encryption algorithm used to create the key.

Supported <replaceable>algorithm</replaceable> values:
            <literal>'RSA'</literal>, <literal>'DSA'</literal>,
            <literal>'DH'</literal>

For a usage example, see the description of
            <literal role="func">CREATE_ASYMMETRIC_PRIV_KEY()</literal>.

<indexterm>
              <primary>CREATE_DH_PARAMETERS()</primary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal role="func">CREATE_DH_PARAMETERS(<replaceable>key_len</replaceable>)</literal>

Creates a shared secret for generating a DH private/public
            key pair and returns a binary string that can be passed to
            <literal role="func">CREATE_ASYMMETRIC_PRIV_KEY()</literal>.
            If secret generation fails, the result is null.

Supported <replaceable>key_len</replaceable> values: The
            minimum and maximum key lengths in bits are 1,024 and
            10,000. These key-length limits are constraints imposed by
            OpenSSL. Server administrators can impose additional limits
            on maximum key length by setting environment variables. See
            <xref linkend="enterprise-encryption-usage" />.

For an example showing how to use the return value for
            generating symmetric keys, see the description of
            <literal role="func">ASYMMETRIC_DERIVE()</literal>.

Creates a digest from the given string using the given
            digest type, and returns the digest as a binary string. If
            digest generation fails, the result is
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

Supported <replaceable>digest_type</replaceable> values:
            <literal>'SHA224'</literal>, <literal>'SHA256'</literal>,
            <literal>'SHA384'</literal>, <literal>'SHA512'</literal>

Returns the average value of
            <literal><replaceable>expr</replaceable></literal>. The
            <literal>DISTINCT</literal> option can be used to return the
            average of the distinct values of
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable>.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">AVG()</literal> returns
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the bitwise <literal>AND</literal> of all bits in
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable>. The calculation is
            performed with 64-bit
            (<literal role="type">BIGINT</literal>) precision.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">BIT_AND()</literal> returns a neutral
            value (all bits set to 1).

Returns the bitwise <literal>OR</literal> of all bits in
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable>. The calculation is
            performed with 64-bit
            (<literal role="type">BIGINT</literal>) precision.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">BIT_OR()</literal> returns a neutral
            value (all bits set to 0).

Returns the bitwise <literal role="op">XOR</literal> of all
            bits in <replaceable>expr</replaceable>. The calculation is
            performed with 64-bit
            (<literal role="type">BIGINT</literal>) precision.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">BIT_XOR()</literal> returns a neutral
            value (all bits set to 0).

Returns a count of the number of non-<literal>NULL</literal>
            values of <replaceable>expr</replaceable> in the rows
            retrieved by a <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal>
            statement. The result is a
            <literal role="type">BIGINT</literal> value.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">COUNT()</literal> returns
            <literal>0</literal>.

Returns a count of the number of rows with different
            non-<literal>NULL</literal> <replaceable>expr</replaceable>
            values.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">COUNT(DISTINCT)</literal> returns
            <literal>0</literal>.

This function returns a string result with the concatenated
            non-<literal>NULL</literal> values from a group. It returns
            <literal>NULL</literal> if there are no
            non-<literal>NULL</literal> values. The full syntax is as
            follows:

description.programlisting:
>
GROUP_CONCAT([DISTINCT] <replaceable>expr</replaceable> [,<replaceable>expr</replaceable> ...]
             [ORDER BY {<replaceable>unsigned_integer</replaceable> | <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> | <replaceable>expr</replaceable>}
                 [ASC | DESC] [,<replaceable>col_name</replaceable> ...]]
             [SEPARATOR <replaceable>str_val</replaceable>])

description.para:
Aggregates a result set as a single
            <literal role="type">JSON</literal> array whose elements
            consist of the rows. The order of elements in this array is
            undefined. The function acts on a column or an expression
            that evaluates to a single value. Returns
            <literal>NULL</literal> if the result contains no rows, or
            in the event of an error.

Takes two column names or expressions as arguments, the
            first of these being used as a key and the second as a
            value, and returns a JSON object containing key-value pairs.
            Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if the result contains no
            rows, or in the event of an error. An error occurs if any
            key name is <literal>NULL</literal> or the number of
            arguments is not equal to 2.

Returns the maximum value of
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable>.
            <literal role="func">MAX()</literal> may take a string
            argument; in such cases, it returns the maximum string
            value. See <xref linkend="mysql-indexes" />. The
            <literal>DISTINCT</literal> keyword can be used to find the
            maximum of the distinct values of
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable>, however, this produces the
            same result as omitting <literal>DISTINCT</literal>.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">MAX()</literal> returns
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the minimum value of
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable>.
            <literal role="func">MIN()</literal> may take a string
            argument; in such cases, it returns the minimum string
            value. See <xref linkend="mysql-indexes" />. The
            <literal>DISTINCT</literal> keyword can be used to find the
            minimum of the distinct values of
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable>, however, this produces the
            same result as omitting <literal>DISTINCT</literal>.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">MIN()</literal> returns
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the population standard deviation of
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable>.
            <literal role="func">STD()</literal> is a synonym for the
            standard SQL function
            <literal role="func">STDDEV_POP()</literal>, provided as a
            MySQL extension.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">STD()</literal> returns
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the population standard deviation of
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable>.
            <literal role="func">STDDEV()</literal> is a synonym for the
            standard SQL function
            <literal role="func">STDDEV_POP()</literal>, provided for
            compatibility with Oracle.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">STDDEV()</literal> returns
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the population standard deviation of
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable> (the square root of
            <literal role="func">VAR_POP()</literal>). You can also use
            <literal role="func">STD()</literal> or
            <literal role="func">STDDEV()</literal>, which are
            equivalent but not standard SQL.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">STDDEV_POP()</literal> returns
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the sample standard deviation of
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable> (the square root of
            <literal role="func">VAR_SAMP()</literal>.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">STDDEV_SAMP()</literal> returns
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the sum of <replaceable>expr</replaceable>. If the
            return set has no rows, <literal role="func">SUM()</literal>
            returns <literal>NULL</literal>. The
            <literal>DISTINCT</literal> keyword can be used to sum only
            the distinct values of <replaceable>expr</replaceable>.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">SUM()</literal> returns
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the population standard variance of
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable>. It considers rows as the
            whole population, not as a sample, so it has the number of
            rows as the denominator. You can also use
            <literal role="func">VARIANCE()</literal>, which is
            equivalent but is not standard SQL.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">VAR_POP()</literal> returns
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the sample variance of
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable>. That is, the denominator is
            the number of rows minus one.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">VAR_SAMP()</literal> returns
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns the population standard variance of
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable>.
            <literal role="func">VARIANCE()</literal> is a synonym for
            the standard SQL function
            <literal role="func">VAR_POP()</literal>, provided as a
            MySQL extension.

If there are no matching rows,
            <literal role="func">VARIANCE()</literal> returns
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

<indexterm>
            <primary>ANY_VALUE()</primary>
          </indexterm>

          <literal role="func">ANY_VALUE(<replaceable>arg</replaceable>)</literal>

This function is useful for <literal>GROUP BY</literal>
          queries when the
          <literal role="sqlmode">ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY</literal> SQL mode
          is enabled, for cases when MySQL rejects a query that you know
          is valid for reasons that MySQL cannot determine. The function
          return value and type are the same as the return value and
          type of its argument, but the function result is not checked
          for the <literal role="sqlmode">ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY</literal>
          SQL mode.

For example, if <literal>name</literal> is a nonindexed
          column, the following query fails with
          <literal role="sqlmode">ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY</literal> enabled:

description.programlisting:
>

mysql> <userinput>SELECT name, address, MAX(age) FROM t GROUP BY name;</userinput>
ERROR 1055 (42000): Expression #2 of SELECT list is not in GROUP
BY clause and contains nonaggregated column 'mydb.t.address' which
is not functionally dependent on columns in GROUP BY clause; this
is incompatible with sql_mode=only_full_group_by

description.para:
The failure occurs because <literal>address</literal> is a
          nonaggregated column that is neither named among
          <literal>GROUP BY</literal> columns nor functionally dependent
          on them. As a result, the <literal>address</literal> value for
          rows within each <literal>name</literal> group is
          nondeterministic. There are multiple ways to cause MySQL to
          accept the query:

itemizedlist.para:
Alter the table to make <literal>name</literal> a primary
              key or a unique <literal>NOT NULL</literal> column. This
              enables MySQL to determine that <literal>address</literal>
              is functionally dependent on <literal>name</literal>; that
              is, <literal>address</literal> is uniquely determined by
              <literal>name</literal>. (This technique is inapplicable
              if <literal>NULL</literal> must be permitted as a valid
              <literal>name</literal> value.)

Use <literal role="func">ANY_VALUE()</literal> to refer to
              <literal>address</literal>:

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
SELECT name, ANY_VALUE(address), MAX(age) FROM t GROUP BY name;

itemizedlist.para:
In this case, MySQL ignores the nondeterminism of
              <literal>address</literal> values within each
              <literal>name</literal> group and accepts the query. This
              may be useful if you simply do not care which value of a
              nonaggregated column is chosen for each group.
              <literal role="func">ANY_VALUE()</literal> is not an
              aggregate function, unlike functions such as
              <literal role="func">SUM()</literal> or
              <literal role="func">COUNT()</literal>. It simply acts to
              suppress the test for nondeterminism.

Disable
              <literal role="sqlmode">ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY</literal>. This
              is equivalent to using
              <literal role="func">ANY_VALUE()</literal> with
              <literal role="sqlmode">ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY</literal>
              enabled, as described in the previous item.

description.para:
<literal role="func">ANY_VALUE()</literal> is also useful if
          functional dependence exists between columns but MySQL cannot
          determine it. The following query is valid because
          <literal>age</literal> is functionally dependent on the
          grouping column <literal>age-1</literal>, but MySQL cannot
          tell that and rejects the query with
          <literal role="sqlmode">ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY</literal> enabled:

description.programlisting:
>
SELECT age FROM t GROUP BY age-1;

description.para:
To cause MySQL to accept the query, use
          <literal role="func">ANY_VALUE()</literal>:

description.programlisting:
>
SELECT ANY_VALUE(age) FROM t GROUP BY age-1;

description.para:
<literal role="func">ANY_VALUE()</literal> can be used for
          queries that refer to aggregate functions in the absence of a
          <literal>GROUP BY</literal> clause:

description.programlisting:
>

mysql> <userinput>SELECT name, MAX(age) FROM t;</userinput>
ERROR 1140 (42000): In aggregated query without GROUP BY, expression
#1 of SELECT list contains nonaggregated column 'mydb.t.name'; this
is incompatible with sql_mode=only_full_group_by

description.para:
Without <literal>GROUP BY</literal>, there is a single group
          and it is nondeterministic which <literal>name</literal> value
          to choose for the group.
          <literal role="func">ANY_VALUE()</literal> tells MySQL to
          accept the query:

description.programlisting:
>
SELECT ANY_VALUE(name), MAX(age) FROM t;

description.para:
It may be that, due to some property of a given data set, you
          know that a selected nonaggregated column is effectively
          functionally dependent on a <literal>GROUP BY</literal>
          column. For example, an application may enforce uniqueness of
          one column with respect to another. In this case, using
          <literal role="func">ANY_VALUE()</literal> for the effectively
          functionally dependent column may make sense.

For additional discussion, see
          <xref linkend="group-by-handling" />.

Returns the default value for a table column. An error results
          if the column has no default value.

Given the dotted-quad representation of an IPv4 network
          address as a string, returns an integer that represents the
          numeric value of the address in network byte order (big
          endian). <literal role="func">INET_ATON()</literal> returns
          <literal>NULL</literal> if it does not understand its
          argument.

Given a numeric IPv4 network address in network byte order,
          returns the dotted-quad string representation of the address
          as a string in the connection character set.
          <literal role="func">INET_NTOA()</literal> returns
          <literal>NULL</literal> if it does not understand its
          argument.

Given an IPv6 or IPv4 network address as a string, returns a
          binary string that represents the numeric value of the address
          in network byte order (big endian). Because numeric-format
          IPv6 addresses require more bytes than the largest integer
          type, the representation returned by this function has the
          <literal role="type">VARBINARY</literal> data type:
          <literal role="type">VARBINARY(16)</literal> for IPv6
          addresses and <literal role="type">VARBINARY(4)</literal> for
          IPv4 addresses. If the argument is not a valid address,
          <literal role="func">INET6_ATON()</literal> returns
          <literal>NULL</literal>.

Given an IPv6 or IPv4 network address represented in numeric
          form as a binary string, returns the string representation of
          the address as a string in the connection character set. If
          the argument is not a valid address,
          <literal role="func">INET6_NTOA()</literal> returns
          <literal>NULL</literal>.

<literal role="func">INET6_NTOA()</literal> has these
          properties:

itemizedlist.para:
It does not use operating system functions to perform
              conversions, thus the output string is platform
              independent.

The return string has a maximum length of 39 (4 x 8 + 7).
              Given this statement:

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
CREATE TABLE t AS SELECT INET6_NTOA(<replaceable>expr</replaceable>) AS c1;

itemizedlist.para: The resulting table would have this definition:

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
CREATE TABLE t (c1 VARCHAR(39) CHARACTER SET utf8 DEFAULT NULL);

itemizedlist.para:
The return string uses lowercase letters for IPv6
              addresses.

description.para:
Returns 1 if the argument is a valid IPv4 address specified as
          a string, 0 otherwise.

This function takes an IPv6 address represented in numeric
          form as a binary string, as returned by
          <literal role="func">INET6_ATON()</literal>. It returns 1 if
          the argument is a valid IPv4-compatible IPv6 address, 0
          otherwise. IPv4-compatible addresses have the form
          <literal>::<replaceable>ipv4_address</replaceable></literal>.

This function takes an IPv6 address represented in numeric
          form as a binary string, as returned by
          <literal role="func">INET6_ATON()</literal>. It returns 1 if
          the argument is a valid IPv4-mapped IPv6 address, 0 otherwise.
          IPv4-mapped addresses have the form
          <literal>::ffff:<replaceable>ipv4_address</replaceable></literal>.

Returns 1 if the argument is a valid IPv6 address specified as
          a string, 0 otherwise. This function does not consider IPv4
          addresses to be valid IPv6 addresses.

This function is useful for control of master/slave
          synchronization. It blocks until the slave has read and
          applied all updates up to the specified position in the master
          log. The return value is the number of log events the slave
          had to wait for to advance to the specified position. The
          function returns <literal>NULL</literal> if the slave SQL
          thread is not started, the slave's master information is not
          initialized, the arguments are incorrect, or an error occurs.
          It returns <literal>-1</literal> if the timeout has been
          exceeded. If the slave SQL thread stops while
          <literal role="func">MASTER_POS_WAIT()</literal> is waiting,
          the function returns <literal>NULL</literal>. If the slave is
          past the specified position, the function returns immediately.

On a multithreaded slave, the function waits until expiry of
          the limit set by the
          <literal role="sysvar">slave_checkpoint_group</literal> or
          <literal role="sysvar">slave_checkpoint_period</literal>
          system variable, when the checkpoint operation is called to
          update the status of the slave. Depending on the setting for
          the system variables, the function might therefore return some
          time after the specified position was reached.

If a <replaceable>timeout</replaceable> value is specified,
          <literal role="func">MASTER_POS_WAIT()</literal> stops waiting
          when <replaceable>timeout</replaceable> seconds have elapsed.
          <replaceable>timeout</replaceable> must be greater than 0; a
          zero or negative <replaceable>timeout</replaceable> means no
          timeout.

The optional <replaceable>channel</replaceable> value enables
          you to name which replication channel the function applies to.
          See <xref linkend="replication-channels" /> for more
          information.

Returns the given value. When used to produce a result set
          column, <literal role="func">NAME_CONST()</literal> causes the
          column to have the given name. The arguments should be
          constants.

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT NAME_CONST('myname', 14);</userinput>
+--------+
| myname |
+--------+
|     14 |
+--------+

description.para:
Sleeps (pauses) for the number of seconds given by the
          <replaceable>duration</replaceable> argument, then returns 0.
          The duration may have a fractional part. If the argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal> or negative,
          <literal role="func">SLEEP()</literal> produces a warning, or
          an error in strict SQL mode.

When sleep returns normally (without interruption), it returns
          0:

When <literal role="func">SLEEP()</literal> is the only thing
          invoked by a query that is interrupted, it returns 1 and the
          query itself returns no error. This is true whether the query
          is killed or times out:

itemizedlist.para: This statement is interrupted by timing out:

description.para:
When <literal role="func">SLEEP()</literal> is only part of a
          query that is interrupted, the query returns an error:

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT 1 FROM t1 WHERE SLEEP(1000);</userinput>
ERROR 1317 (70100): Query execution was interrupted

itemizedlist.para: This statement is interrupted by timing out:

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT /*+ MAX_EXECUTION_TIME(1000) */ 1 FROM t1 WHERE SLEEP(1000);</userinput>
ERROR 3024 (HY000): Query execution was interrupted, maximum statement
execution time exceeded

description.para:
Returns a Universal Unique Identifier (UUID) generated
          according to RFC 4122, <quote>A Universally Unique IDentifier
          (UUID) URN Namespace</quote>
          (<ulink url="http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4122.txt" />).

A UUID is designed as a number that is globally unique in
          space and time. Two calls to
          <literal role="func">UUID()</literal> are expected to generate
          two different values, even if these calls are performed on two
          separate devices not connected to each other.

<literal role="func">UUID()</literal> returns a value that
          conforms to UUID version 1 as described in RFC 4122. The value
          is a 128-bit number represented as a <literal>utf8</literal>
          string of five hexadecimal numbers in
          <literal>aaaaaaaa-bbbb-cccc-dddd-eeeeeeeeeeee</literal>
          format:

itemizedlist.para:
The first three numbers are generated from the low,
              middle, and high parts of a timestamp. The high part also
              includes the UUID version number.

The fourth number preserves temporal uniqueness in case
              the timestamp value loses monotonicity (for example, due
              to daylight saving time).

The fifth number is an IEEE 802 node number that provides
              spatial uniqueness. A random number is substituted if the
              latter is not available (for example, because the host
              device has no Ethernet card, or it is unknown how to find
              the hardware address of an interface on the host operating
              system). In this case, spatial uniqueness cannot be
              guaranteed. Nevertheless, a collision should have
              <emphasis>very</emphasis> low probability.

The MAC address of an interface is taken into account only
              on FreeBSD, Linux, and Windows. On other operating
              systems, MySQL uses a randomly generated 48-bit number.

description.para:
Returns a <quote>short</quote> universal identifier as a
          64-bit unsigned integer. Values returned by
          <literal role="func">UUID_SHORT()</literal> differ from the
          string-format 128-bit identifiers returned by the
          <literal role="func">UUID()</literal> function and have
          different uniqueness properties. The value of
          <literal role="func">UUID_SHORT()</literal> is guaranteed to
          be unique if the following conditions hold:

itemizedlist.para:
The <literal role="sysvar">server_id</literal> value of
              the current server is between 0 and 255 and is unique
              among your set of master and slave servers

You do not set back the system time for your server host
              between <command>mysqld</command> restarts

You invoke <literal role="func">UUID_SHORT()</literal> on
              average fewer than 16 million times per second between
              <command>mysqld</command> restarts

description.para:
The <literal role="func">UUID_SHORT()</literal> return value
          is constructed this way:

description.programlisting:
>
  (server_id & 255) << 56
+ (server_startup_time_in_seconds << 24)
+ incremented_variable++;

description.para:
In an
          <literal condition="insert-on-duplicate" role="stmt">INSERT
          ... ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE</literal> statement, you can use
          the
          <literal>VALUES(<replaceable>col_name</replaceable>)</literal>
          function in the <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> clause
          to refer to column values from the
          <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> portion of the
          statement. In other words,
          <literal>VALUES(<replaceable>col_name</replaceable>)</literal>
          in the <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> clause refers to
          the value of <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> that would be
          inserted, had no duplicate-key conflict occurred. This
          function is especially useful in multiple-row inserts. The
          <literal role="func">VALUES()</literal> function is meaningful
          only in the <literal>ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE</literal> clause
          of <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> statements and
          returns <literal>NULL</literal> otherwise. See
          <xref linkend="insert-on-duplicate" />.

Evaluates a (possibly empty) list of values and returns a JSON
          array containing those values.

Evaluates a (possibly empty) list of key-value pairs and
          returns a JSON object containing those pairs. An error occurs
          if any key name is <literal>NULL</literal> or the number of
          arguments is odd.

Quotes a string as a JSON value by wrapping it with double
          quote characters and escaping interior quote and other
          characters, then returning the result as a
          <literal>utf8mb4</literal> string. Returns
          <literal>NULL</literal> if the argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>.

This function is typically used to produce a valid JSON string
          literal for inclusion within a JSON document.

Certain special characters are escaped with backslashes per
          the escape sequences shown in
          <xref linkend="json-unquote-character-escape-sequences" />.

Indicates by returning 1 or 0 whether a given
          <replaceable>candidate</replaceable> JSON document is
          contained within a <replaceable>target</replaceable> JSON
          document, ormdashif a <replaceable>path</replaceable>
          argument was suppliedmdashwhether the candidate is found at
          a specific path within the target. Returns
          <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>, or if the path argument does not
          identify a section of the target document. An error occurs if
          <replaceable>target</replaceable> or
          <replaceable>candidate</replaceable> is not a valid JSON
          document, or if the <replaceable>path</replaceable> argument
          is not a valid path expression or contains a
          <literal>*</literal> or <literal>**</literal> wildcard.

To check only whether any data exists at the path, use
          <literal role="func">JSON_CONTAINS_PATH()</literal> instead.
The following rules define containment:

itemizedlist.para:
A candidate scalar is contained in a target scalar if and
              only if they are comparable and are equal. Two scalar
              values are comparable if they have the same
              <literal role="func">JSON_TYPE()</literal> types, with the
              exception that values of types <literal>INTEGER</literal>
              and <literal>DECIMAL</literal> are also comparable to each
              other.

A candidate array is contained in a target array if and
              only if every element in the candidate is contained in
              some element of the target.

A candidate nonarray is contained in a target array if and
              only if the candidate is contained in some element of the
              target.

A candidate object is contained in a target object if and
              only if for each key in the candidate there is a key with
              the same name in the target and the value associated with
              the candidate key is contained in the value associated
              with the target key.

description.para:
Otherwise, the candidate value is not contained in the target
          document.

Returns 0 or 1 to indicate whether a JSON document contains
          data at a given path or paths. Returns <literal>NULL</literal>
          if any argument is <literal>NULL</literal>. An error occurs if
          the <replaceable>json_doc</replaceable> argument is not a
          valid JSON document, any <replaceable>path</replaceable>
          argument is not a valid path expression, or
          <replaceable>one_or_all</replaceable> is not
          <literal>'one'</literal> or <literal>'all'</literal>.

To check for a specific value at a path, use
          <literal role="func">JSON_CONTAINS()</literal> instead.

The return value is 0 if no specified path exists within the
          document. Otherwise, the return value depends on the
          <replaceable>one_or_all</replaceable> argument:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>'one'</literal>: 1 if at least one path exists
              within the document, 0 otherwise.

<literal>'all'</literal>: 1 if all paths exist within the
              document, 0 otherwise.

description.para:
Returns data from a JSON document, selected from the parts of
          the document matched by the <replaceable>path</replaceable>
          arguments. Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal> or no paths locate a value in the
          document. An error occurs if the
          <replaceable>json_doc</replaceable> argument is not a valid
          JSON document or any <replaceable>path</replaceable> argument
          is not a valid path expression.

The return value consists of all values matched by the
          <replaceable>path</replaceable> arguments. If it is possible
          that those arguments could return multiple values, the matched
          values are autowrapped as an array, in the order corresponding
          to the paths that produced them. Otherwise, the return value
          is the single matched value.

In MySQL 5.7.9 and later, the
          <literal condition="json-column-path" role="op">-></literal>
          operator serves as an alias for the
          <literal role="func">JSON_EXTRACT()</literal> function when
          used with two arguments, a column identifier on the left and a
          JSON path on the right that is evaluated against the JSON
          document (the column value). You can use such expressions in
          place of column identifiers wherever they occur in SQL
          statements.

This is an improved, unquoting extraction operator available
          in MySQL 5.7.13 and later. Whereas the
          <literal>-></literal> operator simply extracts a value, the
          <literal>->></literal> operator in addition unquotes the
          extracted result. In other words, given a
          <literal role="type">JSON</literal> column value
          <replaceable>column</replaceable> and a path expression
          <replaceable>path</replaceable>, the following three
          expressions return the same value:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal role="func">JSON_UNQUOTE(</literal>
              <literal role="func">JSON_EXTRACT(<replaceable>column</replaceable>,
              <replaceable>path</replaceable>) )</literal>

<literal>JSON_UNQUOTE(<replaceable>column</replaceable></literal>
              <literal condition="json-column-path" role="op">-></literal>
              <literal><replaceable>path</replaceable>)</literal>
<literal><replaceable>column</replaceable>->><replaceable>path</replaceable></literal>

description.para:
The <literal>->></literal> operator can be used wherever
          <literal>JSON_UNQUOTE(JSON_EXTRACT())</literal> would be
          allowed. This includes (but is not limited to)
          <literal>SELECT</literal> lists, <literal>WHERE</literal> and
          <literal>HAVING</literal> clauses, and <literal>ORDER
          BY</literal> and <literal>GROUP BY</literal> clauses.

Returns the keys from the top-level value of a JSON object as
          a JSON array, or, if a <replaceable>path</replaceable>
          argument is given, the top-level keys from the selected path.
          Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>, the
          <replaceable>json_doc</replaceable> argument is not an object,
          or <replaceable>path</replaceable>, if given, does not locate
          an object. An error occurs if the
          <replaceable>json_doc</replaceable> argument is not a valid
          JSON document or the <replaceable>path</replaceable> argument
          is not a valid path expression or contains a
          <literal>*</literal> or <literal>**</literal> wildcard.

The result array is empty if the selected object is empty. If
          the top-level value has nested subobjects, the return value
          does not include keys from those subobjects.

Returns the path to the given string within a JSON document.
          Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if any of the
          <replaceable>json_doc</replaceable>,
          <replaceable>search_str</replaceable>, or
          <replaceable>path</replaceable> arguments are
          <literal>NULL</literal>; no <replaceable>path</replaceable>
          exists within the document; or
          <replaceable>search_str</replaceable> is not found. An error
          occurs if the <replaceable>json_doc</replaceable> argument is
          not a valid JSON document, any <replaceable>path</replaceable>
          argument is not a valid path expression,
          <replaceable>one_or_all</replaceable> is not
          <literal>'one'</literal> or <literal>'all'</literal>, or
          <replaceable>escape_char</replaceable> is not a constant
          expression.

The <replaceable>one_or_all</replaceable> argument affects the
          search as follows:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>'one'</literal>: The search terminates after the
              first match and returns one path string. It is undefined
              which match is considered first.

<literal>'all'</literal>: The search returns all matching
              path strings such that no duplicate paths are included. If
              there are multiple strings, they are autowrapped as an
              array. The order of the array elements is undefined.

description.para:
Within the <replaceable>search_str</replaceable> search string
          argument, the <literal>%</literal> and <literal>_</literal>
          characters work as for the <literal role="op">LIKE</literal>
          operator: <literal>%</literal> matches any number of
          characters (including zero characters), and
          <literal>_</literal> matches exactly one character.

To specify a literal <literal>%</literal> or
          <literal>_</literal> character in the search string, precede
          it by the escape character. The default is
          <literal>\</literal> if the
          <replaceable>escape_char</replaceable> argument is missing or
          <literal>NULL</literal>. Otherwise,
          <replaceable>escape_char</replaceable> must be a constant that
          is empty or one character.

For more information about matching and escape character
          behavior, see the description of
          <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> in
          <xref linkend="string-comparison-functions" />. For escape
          character handling, a difference from the
          <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> behavior is that the escape
          character for <literal role="func">JSON_SEARCH()</literal>
          must evaluate to a constant at compile time, not just at
          execution time. For example, if
          <literal role="func">JSON_SEARCH()</literal> is used in a
          prepared statement and the
          <replaceable>escape_char</replaceable> argument is supplied
          using a <literal>?</literal> parameter, the parameter value
          might be constant at execution time, but is not at compile
          time.

Appends values to the end of the indicated arrays within a
          JSON document and returns the result. This function was
          renamed to <literal role="func">JSON_ARRAY_APPEND()</literal>
          in MySQL 5.7.9; the alias <literal>JSON_APPEND()</literal> is
          now deprecated in MySQL 5.7, and is removed in MySQL 8.0.

Appends values to the end of the indicated arrays within a
          JSON document and returns the result. Returns
          <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>. An error occurs if the
          <replaceable>json_doc</replaceable> argument is not a valid
          JSON document or any <replaceable>path</replaceable> argument
          is not a valid path expression or contains a
          <literal>*</literal> or <literal>**</literal> wildcard.

The path-value pairs are evaluated left to right. The document
          produced by evaluating one pair becomes the new value against
          which the next pair is evaluated.

If a path selects a scalar or object value, that value is
          autowrapped within an array and the new value is added to that
          array. Pairs for which the path does not identify any value in
          the JSON document are ignored.

Updates a JSON document, inserting into an array within the
          document and returning the modified document. Returns
          <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>. An error occurs if the
          <replaceable>json_doc</replaceable> argument is not a valid
          JSON document or any <replaceable>path</replaceable> argument
          is not a valid path expression or contains a
          <literal>*</literal> or <literal>**</literal> wildcard or does
          not end with an array element identifier.

The path-value pairs are evaluated left to right. The document
          produced by evaluating one pair becomes the new value against
          which the next pair is evaluated.

Pairs for which the path does not identify any array in the
          JSON document are ignored. If a path identifies an array
          element, the corresponding value is inserted at that element
          position, shifting any following values to the right. If a
          path identifies an array position past the end of an array,
          the value is inserted at the end of the array.

Inserts data into a JSON document and returns the result.
          Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>. An error occurs if the
          <replaceable>json_doc</replaceable> argument is not a valid
          JSON document or any <replaceable>path</replaceable> argument
          is not a valid path expression or contains a
          <literal>*</literal> or <literal>**</literal> wildcard.

The path-value pairs are evaluated left to right. The document
          produced by evaluating one pair becomes the new value against
          which the next pair is evaluated.

A path-value pair for an existing path in the document is
          ignored and does not overwrite the existing document value. A
          path-value pair for a nonexisting path in the document adds
          the value to the document if the path identifies one of these
          types of values:

itemizedlist.para:
A member not present in an existing object. The member is
              added to the object and associated with the new value.

A position past the end of an existing array. The array is
              extended with the new value. If the existing value is not
              an array, it is autowrapped as an array, then extended
              with the new value.

description.para:
Otherwise, a path-value pair for a nonexisting path in the
          document is ignored and has no effect.

For a comparison of
          <literal role="func">JSON_INSERT()</literal>,
          <literal role="func">JSON_REPLACE()</literal>, and
          <literal role="func">JSON_SET()</literal>, see the discussion
          of <literal role="func">JSON_SET()</literal>.

Merges two or more JSON documents. Synonym for
          <literal>JSON_MERGE_PRESERVE()</literal>; deprecated in MySQL
          5.7.22 and subject to removal in a future release.

Performs an
          <ulink url="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7396">RFC
          7396</ulink> compliant merge of two or more JSON documents and
          returns the merged result, without preserving members having
          duplicate keys. Raises an error if at least one of the
          documents passed as arguments to this function is not valid.

<literal>JSON_MERGE_PATCH()</literal> performs a merge as
          follows:

For additional information, see
          <xref linkend="json-normalization" />.

Merges two or more JSON documents and returns the merged
          result. Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>. An error occurs if any argument is
          not a valid JSON document.

Merging takes place according to the following rules. For
          additional information, see
          <xref linkend="json-normalization" />.

itemizedlist.para: Adjacent arrays are merged to a single array.
Adjacent objects are merged to a single object.

A scalar value is autowrapped as an array and merged as an
              array.

An adjacent array and object are merged by autowrapping
              the object as an array and merging the two arrays.

description.para:
Removes data from a JSON document and returns the result.
          Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>. An error occurs if the
          <replaceable>json_doc</replaceable> argument is not a valid
          JSON document or any <replaceable>path</replaceable> argument
          is not a valid path expression or is <literal>$</literal> or
          contains a <literal>*</literal> or <literal>**</literal>
          wildcard.

The <replaceable>path</replaceable> arguments are evaluated
          left to right. The document produced by evaluating one path
          becomes the new value against which the next path is
          evaluated.

It is not an error if the element to be removed does not exist
          in the document; in that case, the path does not affect the
          document.

Replaces existing values in a JSON document and returns the
          result. Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>. An error occurs if the
          <replaceable>json_doc</replaceable> argument is not a valid
          JSON document or any <replaceable>path</replaceable> argument
          is not a valid path expression or contains a
          <literal>*</literal> or <literal>**</literal> wildcard.

The path-value pairs are evaluated left to right. The document
          produced by evaluating one pair becomes the new value against
          which the next pair is evaluated.

A path-value pair for an existing path in the document
          overwrites the existing document value with the new value. A
          path-value pair for a nonexisting path in the document is
          ignored and has no effect.

For a comparison of
          <literal role="func">JSON_INSERT()</literal>,
          <literal role="func">JSON_REPLACE()</literal>, and
          <literal role="func">JSON_SET()</literal>, see the discussion
          of <literal role="func">JSON_SET()</literal>.

Inserts or updates data in a JSON document and returns the
          result. Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal> or <replaceable>path</replaceable>, if
          given, does not locate an object. An error occurs if the
          <replaceable>json_doc</replaceable> argument is not a valid
          JSON document or any <replaceable>path</replaceable> argument
          is not a valid path expression or contains a
          <literal>*</literal> or <literal>**</literal> wildcard.

The path-value pairs are evaluated left to right. The document
          produced by evaluating one pair becomes the new value against
          which the next pair is evaluated.

A path-value pair for an existing path in the document
          overwrites the existing document value with the new value. A
          path-value pair for a nonexisting path in the document adds
          the value to the document if the path identifies one of these
          types of values:

itemizedlist.para:
A member not present in an existing object. The member is
              added to the object and associated with the new value.

A position past the end of an existing array. The array is
              extended with the new value. If the existing value is not
              an array, it is autowrapped as an array, then extended
              with the new value.

description.para:
Otherwise, a path-value pair for a nonexisting path in the
          document is ignored and has no effect.

The <literal role="func">JSON_SET()</literal>,
          <literal role="func">JSON_INSERT()</literal>, and
          <literal role="func">JSON_REPLACE()</literal> functions are
          related:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal role="func">JSON_SET()</literal> replaces
              existing values and adds nonexisting values.

<literal role="func">JSON_INSERT()</literal> inserts
              values without replacing existing values.

<literal role="func">JSON_REPLACE()</literal> replaces
              <emphasis>only</emphasis> existing values.

description.para:
Unquotes JSON value and returns the result as a
          <literal>utf8mb4</literal> string. Returns
          <literal>NULL</literal> if the argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>. An error occurs if the value starts
          and ends with double quotes but is not a valid JSON string
          literal.

Returns the maximum depth of a JSON document. Returns
          <literal>NULL</literal> if the argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>. An error occurs if the argument is
          not a valid JSON document.

An empty array, empty object, or scalar value has depth 1. A
          nonempty array containing only elements of depth 1 or nonempty
          object containing only member values of depth 1 has depth 2.
          Otherwise, a JSON document has depth greater than 2.

Returns the length of a JSON document, or, if a
          <replaceable>path</replaceable> argument is given, the length
          of the value within the document identified by the path.
          Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if any argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal> or the <replaceable>path</replaceable>
          argument does not identify a value in the document. An error
          occurs if the <replaceable>json_doc</replaceable> argument is
          not a valid JSON document or the
          <replaceable>path</replaceable> argument is not a valid path
          expression or contains a <literal>*</literal> or
          <literal>**</literal> wildcard.
The length of a document is determined as follows:

itemizedlist.para: The length of a scalar is 1.
The length of an array is the number of array elements.
The length of an object is the number of object members.

The length does not count the length of nested arrays or
              objects.

description.para:
Returns a <literal>utf8mb4</literal> string indicating the
          type of a JSON value. This can be an object, an array, or a
          scalar type, as shown here:

<literal role="func">JSON_TYPE()</literal> returns
          <literal>NULL</literal> if the argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT JSON_TYPE(NULL);</userinput>
+-----------------+
| JSON_TYPE(NULL) |
+-----------------+
| NULL            |
+-----------------+

description.para: An error occurs if the argument is not a valid JSON value:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT JSON_TYPE(1);</userinput>
ERROR 3146 (22032): Invalid data type for JSON data in argument 1
to function json_type; a JSON string or JSON type is required.

description.para:
For a non-<literal>NULL</literal>, non-error result, the
          following list describes the possible
          <literal role="func">JSON_TYPE()</literal> return values:

itemizedlist.para: Purely JSON types:
<literal>OBJECT</literal>: JSON objects
<literal>ARRAY</literal>: JSON arrays

<literal>BOOLEAN</literal>: The JSON true and false
                  literals
<literal>NULL</literal>: The JSON null literal
Numeric types:

<literal>INTEGER</literal>: MySQL
                  <literal role="type">TINYINT</literal>,
                  <literal role="type">SMALLINT</literal>,
                  <literal role="type">MEDIUMINT</literal> and
                  <literal role="type">INT</literal> and
                  <literal role="type">BIGINT</literal> scalars

<literal>DOUBLE</literal>: MySQL
                  <literal role="type">DOUBLE</literal>
                  <literal role="type">FLOAT</literal> scalars

<literal>DECIMAL</literal>: MySQL
                  <literal role="type">DECIMAL</literal> and
                  <literal role="type">NUMERIC</literal> scalars
Temporal types:

<literal>DATETIME</literal>: MySQL
                  <literal role="type">DATETIME</literal> and
                  <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> scalars

<literal>DATE</literal>: MySQL
                  <literal role="type">DATE</literal> scalars

<literal>TIME</literal>: MySQL
                  <literal role="type">TIME</literal> scalars
String types:

<literal>STRING</literal>: MySQL
                  <literal>utf8</literal> character type scalars:
                  <literal role="type">CHAR</literal>,
                  <literal role="type">VARCHAR</literal>,
                  <literal role="type">TEXT</literal>,
                  <literal role="type">ENUM</literal>, and
                  <literal role="type">SET</literal>
Binary types:

<literal>BLOB</literal>: MySQL binary type scalars:
                  <literal role="type">BINARY</literal>,
                  <literal role="type">VARBINARY</literal>,
                  <literal role="type">BLOB</literal>

<literal>BIT</literal>: MySQL
                  <literal role="type">BIT</literal> scalars
All other types:
<literal>OPAQUE</literal> (raw bits)

description.para:
Returns 0 or 1 to indicate whether a value is valid JSON.
          Returns <literal>NULL</literal> if the argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>.

<indexterm>
            <primary>JSON_PRETTY()</primary>
          </indexterm>

          <literal role="func">JSON_PRETTY(<replaceable>json_val</replaceable>)</literal>

Provides pretty-printing of JSON values similar to that
          implemented in PHP and by other languages and database
          systems. The value supplied must be a JSON value or a valid
          string representation of a JSON value. Extraneous whitespaces
          and newlines present in this value have no effect on the
          output. For a <literal>NULL</literal> value, the function
          returns <literal>NULL</literal>. If the value is not a JSON
          document, or if it cannot be parsed as one, the function fails
          with an error.

Formatting of the output from this function adheres to the
          following rules:

itemizedlist.para:
Each array element or object member appears on a separate
              line, indented by one additional level as compared to its
              parent.
Each level of indentation adds two leading spaces.

A comma separating individual array elements or object
              members is printed before the newline that separates the
              two elements or members.

The key and the value of an object member are separated by
              a colon followed by a space ('<literal>: </literal>').

An empty object or array is printed on a single line. No
              space is printed between the opening and closing brace.

Special characters in string scalars and key names are
              escaped employing the same rules used by the
              <literal role="func">JSON_QUOTE()</literal> function.

description.para:
<indexterm>
            <primary>JSON_STORAGE_SIZE()</primary>
          </indexterm>

          <literal role="func">JSON_STORAGE_SIZE(<replaceable>json_val</replaceable>)</literal>

This function returns the number of bytes used to store the
          binary representation of a JSON document. When the argument is
          a <literal>JSON</literal> column, this is the space used to
          store the JSON document. <replaceable>json_val</replaceable>
          must be a valid JSON document or a string which can be parsed
          as one. In the case where it is string, the function returns
          the amount of storage space in the JSON binary representation
          that is created by parsing the string as JSON and converting
          it to binary. It returns <literal>NULL</literal> if the
          argument is <literal>NULL</literal>.

An error results when <replaceable>json_val</replaceable> is
          not <literal>NULL</literal>, and is notmdashor cannot be
          successfully parsed asmdasha JSON document.

The constants <literal>TRUE</literal> and
        <literal>FALSE</literal> evaluate to <literal>1</literal> and
        <literal>0</literal>, respectively. The constant names can be
        written in any lettercase.

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT TRUE, true, FALSE, false;</userinput>
        -> 1, 1, 0, 0

description.para:
<literal>ANALYSE()</literal> examines the result from a query
          and returns an analysis of the results that suggests optimal
          data types for each column that may help reduce table sizes.
          To obtain this analysis, append <literal>PROCEDURE
          ANALYSE</literal> to the end of a
          <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement:

description.programlisting:
>
SELECT ... FROM ... WHERE ... PROCEDURE ANALYSE([<replaceable>max_elements</replaceable>,[<replaceable>max_memory</replaceable>]])

description.para: For example:

description.programlisting:
>
SELECT col1, col2 FROM table1 PROCEDURE ANALYSE(10, 2000);

description.para:
The results show some statistics for the values returned by
          the query, and propose an optimal data type for the columns.
          This can be helpful for checking your existing tables, or
          after importing new data. You may need to try different
          settings for the arguments so that <literal>PROCEDURE
          ANALYSE()</literal> does not suggest the
          <literal role="type">ENUM</literal> data type when it is not
          appropriate.
The arguments are optional and are used as follows:

itemizedlist.para:
<replaceable>max_elements</replaceable> (default 256) is
              the maximum number of distinct values that
              <literal>ANALYSE()</literal> notices per column. This is
              used by <literal>ANALYSE()</literal> to check whether the
              optimal data type should be of type
              <literal role="type">ENUM</literal>; if there are more
              than <replaceable>max_elements</replaceable> distinct
              values, then <literal role="type">ENUM</literal> is not a
              suggested type.

<replaceable>max_memory</replaceable> (default 8192) is
              the maximum amount of memory that
              <literal>ANALYSE()</literal> should allocate per column
              while trying to find all distinct values.

description.para:
A <literal>PROCEDURE</literal> clause is not permitted in a
          <literal role="stmt">UNION</literal> statement.

You can defragment the query cache to better utilize its
          memory with the <literal role="stmt">FLUSH QUERY
          CACHE</literal> statement. The statement does not remove any
          queries from the cache.

The <literal>RESET QUERY CACHE</literal> statement removes all
          query results from the query cache. The
          <literal role="stmt">FLUSH TABLES</literal> statement also
          does this.

<indexterm>
            <primary>GeomCollFromText()</primary>
          </indexterm>

          <indexterm>

          </indexterm>

          <literal role="func">GeomCollFromText(<replaceable>wkt</replaceable>[,
          <replaceable>srid</replaceable>])</literal>,

          <replaceable>srid</replaceable>])</literal>

<literal role="func">ST_GeomCollFromText()</literal>,
          <literal condition="st-geomcollfromtext" role="func">ST_GeometryCollectionFromText()</literal>,
          <literal condition="st-geomcollfromtext" role="func">ST_GeomCollFromTxt()</literal>,
          <literal role="func">GeomCollFromText()</literal>, and
          <literal condition="geomcollfromtext" role="func">GeometryCollectionFromText()</literal>
          are synonyms. For more information, see the description of

<indexterm>
            <primary>GeomFromText()</primary>
