        constraint is defined on the child table.

The essential syntax for a defining a foreign key constraint in
        a <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal> or
        <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal> statement includes
        the following:

description.programlisting:
>
[CONSTRAINT [<replaceable>symbol</replaceable>]] FOREIGN KEY
    [<replaceable>index_name</replaceable>] (<replaceable>col_name</replaceable>, ...)
    REFERENCES <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> (<replaceable>col_name</replaceable>,...)
    [ON DELETE <replaceable>reference_option</replaceable>]
    [ON UPDATE <replaceable>reference_option</replaceable>]

<replaceable>reference_option</replaceable>:
    RESTRICT | CASCADE | SET NULL | NO ACTION | SET DEFAULT

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal> creates a table with
      the given name. You must have the
      <literal role="priv">CREATE</literal> privilege for the table.

By default, tables are created in the default database, using the
      <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal> storage engine. An error
      occurs if the table exists, if there is no default database, or if
      the database does not exist.

MySQL has no limit on the number of tables. The underlying file
      system may have a limit on the number of files that represent
      tables. Individual storage engines may impose engine-specific
      constraints. <literal>InnoDB</literal> permits up to 4 billion
      tables.

For information about the physical representation of a table, see
      <xref linkend="create-table-files" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
CREATE [TEMPORARY] TABLE [IF NOT EXISTS] <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    (<replaceable>create_definition</replaceable>,...)
    [<replaceable>table_options</replaceable>]
    [<replaceable>partition_options</replaceable>]

CREATE [TEMPORARY] TABLE [IF NOT EXISTS] <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    [(<replaceable>create_definition</replaceable>,...)]
    [<replaceable>table_options</replaceable>]
    [<replaceable>partition_options</replaceable>]
    [IGNORE | REPLACE]
    [AS] <replaceable>query_expression</replaceable>

CREATE [TEMPORARY] TABLE [IF NOT EXISTS] <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    { LIKE <replaceable>old_tbl_name</replaceable> | (LIKE <replaceable>old_tbl_name</replaceable>) }

<replaceable>create_definition</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> <replaceable>column_definition</replaceable>
  | {INDEX|KEY} [<replaceable>index_name</replaceable>] [<replaceable>index_type</replaceable>] (<replaceable>key_part</replaceable>,...)
      [<replaceable>index_option</replaceable>] ...
  | {FULLTEXT|SPATIAL} [INDEX|KEY] [<replaceable>index_name</replaceable>] (<replaceable>key_part</replaceable>,...)
      [<replaceable>index_option</replaceable>] ...
  | [CONSTRAINT [<replaceable>symbol</replaceable>]] PRIMARY KEY
      [<replaceable>index_type</replaceable>] (<replaceable>key_part</replaceable>,...)
      [<replaceable>index_option</replaceable>] ...
  | [CONSTRAINT [<replaceable>symbol</replaceable>]] UNIQUE [INDEX|KEY]
      [<replaceable>index_name</replaceable>] [<replaceable>index_type</replaceable>] (<replaceable>key_part</replaceable>,...)
      [<replaceable>index_option</replaceable>] ...
  | [CONSTRAINT [<replaceable>symbol</replaceable>]] FOREIGN KEY
      [<replaceable>index_name</replaceable>] (<replaceable>col_name</replaceable>,...)
      <replaceable>reference_definition</replaceable>
  | CHECK (<replaceable>expr</replaceable>)

<replaceable>column_definition</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>data_type</replaceable> [NOT NULL | NULL] [DEFAULT <replaceable>default_value</replaceable>]
      [AUTO_INCREMENT] [UNIQUE [KEY]] [[PRIMARY] KEY]
      [COMMENT '<replaceable>string</replaceable>']
      [COLLATE <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>]
      [COLUMN_FORMAT {FIXED|DYNAMIC|DEFAULT}]
      [STORAGE {DISK|MEMORY}]
      [<replaceable>reference_definition</replaceable>]
  | <replaceable>data_type</replaceable>
      [COLLATE <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>]
      [GENERATED ALWAYS] AS (<replaceable>expr</replaceable>)
      [VIRTUAL | STORED] [NOT NULL | NULL]
      [UNIQUE [KEY]] [[PRIMARY] KEY]
      [COMMENT '<replaceable>string</replaceable>']
      [<replaceable>reference_definition</replaceable>]

<replaceable>data_type</replaceable>:
    (see <xref linkend="data-types" />)

<replaceable>key_part</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> [(<replaceable>length</replaceable>)] [ASC | DESC]

<replaceable>index_type</replaceable>:
    USING {BTREE | HASH}

<replaceable>index_option</replaceable>:
    KEY_BLOCK_SIZE [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | <replaceable>index_type</replaceable>
  | WITH PARSER <replaceable>parser_name</replaceable>
  | COMMENT '<replaceable>string</replaceable>'

<replaceable>reference_definition</replaceable>:
    REFERENCES <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> (<replaceable>key_part</replaceable>,...)
      [MATCH FULL | MATCH PARTIAL | MATCH SIMPLE]
      [ON DELETE <replaceable>reference_option</replaceable>]
      [ON UPDATE <replaceable>reference_option</replaceable>]

<replaceable>reference_option</replaceable>:
    RESTRICT | CASCADE | SET NULL | NO ACTION | SET DEFAULT

<replaceable>table_options</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>table_option</replaceable> [[,] <replaceable>table_option</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>table_option</replaceable>:
    AUTO_INCREMENT [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | AVG_ROW_LENGTH [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | [DEFAULT] CHARACTER SET [=] <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>
  | CHECKSUM [=] {0 | 1}
  | [DEFAULT] COLLATE [=] <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>
  | COMMENT [=] '<replaceable>string</replaceable>'
  | COMPRESSION [=] {'ZLIB'|'LZ4'|'NONE'}
  | CONNECTION [=] '<replaceable>connect_string</replaceable>'
  | {DATA|INDEX} DIRECTORY [=] '<replaceable>absolute path to directory</replaceable>'
  | DELAY_KEY_WRITE [=] {0 | 1}
  | ENCRYPTION [=] {'Y' | 'N'}
  | ENGINE [=] <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable>
  | INSERT_METHOD [=] { NO | FIRST | LAST }
  | KEY_BLOCK_SIZE [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | MAX_ROWS [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | MIN_ROWS [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | PACK_KEYS [=] {0 | 1 | DEFAULT}
  | PASSWORD [=] '<replaceable>string</replaceable>'
  | ROW_FORMAT [=] {DEFAULT|DYNAMIC|FIXED|COMPRESSED|REDUNDANT|COMPACT}
  | STATS_AUTO_RECALC [=] {DEFAULT|0|1}
  | STATS_PERSISTENT [=] {DEFAULT|0|1}
  | STATS_SAMPLE_PAGES [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | TABLESPACE <replaceable>tablespace_name</replaceable> [STORAGE {DISK|MEMORY}]
  | UNION [=] (<replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>[,<replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>]...)

<replaceable>partition_options</replaceable>:
    PARTITION BY
        { [LINEAR] HASH(<replaceable>expr</replaceable>)
        | [LINEAR] KEY [ALGORITHM={1|2}] (<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>)
        | RANGE{(<replaceable>expr</replaceable>) | COLUMNS(<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>)}
        | LIST{(<replaceable>expr</replaceable>) | COLUMNS(<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>)} }
    [PARTITIONS <replaceable>num</replaceable>]
    [SUBPARTITION BY
        { [LINEAR] HASH(<replaceable>expr</replaceable>)
        | [LINEAR] KEY [ALGORITHM={1|2}] (<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>) }
      [SUBPARTITIONS <replaceable>num</replaceable>]
    ]
    [(<replaceable>partition_definition</replaceable> [, <replaceable>partition_definition</replaceable>] ...)]

<replaceable>partition_definition</replaceable>:
    PARTITION <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable>
        [VALUES
            {LESS THAN {(<replaceable>expr</replaceable> | <replaceable>value_list</replaceable>) | MAXVALUE}
            |
            IN (<replaceable>value_list</replaceable>)}]
        [[STORAGE] ENGINE [=] <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable>]
        [COMMENT [=] '<replaceable>string</replaceable>' ]
        [DATA DIRECTORY [=] '<filename><replaceable>data_dir</replaceable></filename>']
        [INDEX DIRECTORY [=] '<filename><replaceable>index_dir</replaceable></filename>']
        [MAX_ROWS [=] <replaceable>max_number_of_rows</replaceable>]
        [MIN_ROWS [=] <replaceable>min_number_of_rows</replaceable>]
        [TABLESPACE [=] tablespace_name]
        [(<replaceable>subpartition_definition</replaceable> [, <replaceable>subpartition_definition</replaceable>] ...)]

<replaceable>subpartition_definition</replaceable>:
    SUBPARTITION <replaceable>logical_name</replaceable>
        [[STORAGE] ENGINE [=] <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable>]
        [COMMENT [=] '<replaceable>string</replaceable>' ]
        [DATA DIRECTORY [=] '<filename><replaceable>data_dir</replaceable></filename>']
        [INDEX DIRECTORY [=] '<filename><replaceable>index_dir</replaceable></filename>']
        [MAX_ROWS [=] <replaceable>max_number_of_rows</replaceable>]
        [MIN_ROWS [=] <replaceable>min_number_of_rows</replaceable>]
        [TABLESPACE [=] tablespace_name]

<replaceable>query_expression:</replaceable>
    SELECT ...   (<replaceable>Some valid select or union statement</replaceable>)

description.para:
This statement is used to create a tablespace. The precise syntax
      and semantics depend on the storage engine used. In standard MySQL
      5.7 releases, this is always an
      <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal> tablespace. MySQL NDB Cluster
      7.5 also supports tablespaces using the
      <literal role="se">NDB</literal> storage engine in addition to
      those using <literal>InnoDB</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLESPACE</literal> syntax is used to
      create general tablespaces. A general tablespace is a shared
      tablespace. It can hold multiple tables, and supports all table
      row formats. General tablespaces can be created in a location
      relative to or independent of the data directory.

After creating an <literal>InnoDB</literal> general tablespace,
      you can use <literal condition="create-table" role="stmt">CREATE
      TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> ... TABLESPACE [=]
      <replaceable>tablespace_name</replaceable></literal> or
      <literal condition="alter-table" role="stmt">ALTER TABLE
      <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> TABLESPACE [=]
      <replaceable>tablespace_name</replaceable></literal> to add tables
      to the tablespace. For more information, see
      <xref linkend="general-tablespaces" />.

This statement is used to create a tablespace, which can contain
      one or more data files, providing storage space for NDB Cluster
      Disk Data tables (see <xref linkend="mysql-cluster-disk-data" />).
      One data file is created and added to the tablespace using this
      statement. Additional data files may be added to the tablespace by
      using the <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLESPACE</literal>
      statement (see <xref linkend="alter-tablespace" />).

A log file group of one or more <literal>UNDO</literal> log files
      must be assigned to the tablespace to be created with the
      <literal>USE LOGFILE GROUP</literal> clause.
      <replaceable>logfile_group</replaceable> must be an existing log
      file group created with <literal role="stmt">CREATE LOGFILE
      GROUP</literal> (see <xref linkend="create-logfile-group" />).
      Multiple tablespaces may use the same log file group for
      <literal>UNDO</literal> logging.

When setting <literal>EXTENT_SIZE</literal> or
      <literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal>, you may optionally follow the
      number with a one-letter abbreviation for an order of magnitude,
      similar to those used in <filename>my.cnf</filename>. Generally,
      this is one of the letters <literal>M</literal> (for megabytes) or
      <literal>G</literal> (for gigabytes).

<literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> and <literal>EXTENT_SIZE</literal>
      are subject to rounding as follows:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>EXTENT_SIZE</literal> is rounded up to the nearest
          whole multiple of 32K.

<literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> is rounded
          <emphasis>down</emphasis> to the nearest whole multiple of
          32K; this result is rounded up to the nearest whole multiple
          of <literal>EXTENT_SIZE</literal> (after any rounding).

description.para:
The rounding just described is done explicitly, and a warning is
      issued by the MySQL Server when any such rounding is performed.
      The rounded values are also used by the NDB kernel for calculating
      <literal role="is">INFORMATION_SCHEMA.FILES</literal> column
      values and other purposes. However, to avoid an unexpected result,
      we suggest that you always use whole multiples of 32K in
      specifying these options.

When <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLESPACE</literal> is used with
      <literal>ENGINE [=] NDB</literal>, a tablespace and associated
      data file are created on each Cluster data node. You can verify
      that the data files were created and obtain information about them
      by querying the
      <literal role="is">INFORMATION_SCHEMA.FILES</literal> table. (See
      the example later in this section.)
(See <xref linkend="files-table" />.)

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>ADD DATAFILE</literal>: Defines the name of a
          tablespace data file; this option is always required. An
          <literal>InnoDB</literal> tablespace supports only a single
          data file, whose name must include a <literal>.ibd</literal>
          extension. An NDB Cluster tablespace supports multiple data
          files which can have any legal file names; more data files can
          be added to an NDB Cluster tablespace following its creation
          by using an <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLESPACE</literal>
          statement.

To place the data file in a location outside of the data
          directory (<literal role="sysvar">datadir</literal>), include
          an absolute directory path or a path relative to the data
          directory. If you do not specify a path, the tablespace is
          created in the data directory. An
          <link linkend="glos_isl_file">isl</link> file is created in
          the data directory when an <literal>InnoDB</literal>
          tablespace is created outside of the data directory.

To avoid conflicts with implicitly created file-per-table
          tablespaces, creating a general tablespace in a subdirectory
          under the data directory is not supported. When creating a
          general tablespace outside of the data directory, the
          directory must exist prior to creating the tablespace.

The <literal><replaceable>file_name</replaceable></literal>,
          including any specified path, must be quoted with single or
          double quotations marks. File names (not counting the file
          extension) and directory names must be at least one byte in
          length. Zero length file names and directory names are not
          supported.

<literal>FILE_BLOCK_SIZE</literal>: This optionmdashwhich is
          specific to <literal>InnoDB</literal>, and is ignored by
          <literal>NDB</literal>mdashdefines the block size for the
          tablespace data file. Values can be specified in bytes or
          kilobytes. For example, an 8 kilobyte file block size can be
          specified as 8192 or 8K. If you do not specify this option,
          <literal>FILE_BLOCK_SIZE</literal> defaults to the
          <literal role="sysvar">innodb_page_size</literal> value.
          <literal>FILE_BLOCK_SIZE</literal> is required when you intend
          to use the tablespace for storing compressed
          <literal>InnoDB</literal> tables
          (<literal>ROW_FORMAT=COMPRESSED</literal>). In this case, you
          must define the tablespace <literal>FILE_BLOCK_SIZE</literal>
          when creating the tablespace.

itemizedlist.remark:
>
          [js] Maybe move the rest of this explanation elsewhere?

itemizedlist.para:
If <literal>FILE_BLOCK_SIZE</literal> is equal the
          <literal role="sysvar">innodb_page_size</literal> value, the
          tablespace can contain only tables having an uncompressed row
          format (<literal>COMPACT</literal>,
          <literal>REDUNDANT</literal>, and <literal>DYNAMIC</literal>).
          Tables with a <literal>COMPRESSED</literal> row format have a
          different physical page size than uncompressed tables.
          Therefore, compressed tables cannot coexist in the same
          tablespace as uncompressed tables.

For a general tablespace to contain compressed tables,
          <literal>FILE_BLOCK_SIZE</literal> must be specified, and the
          <literal>FILE_BLOCK_SIZE</literal> value must be a valid
          compressed page size in relation to the
          <literal role="sysvar">innodb_page_size</literal> value. Also,
          the physical page size of the compressed table
          (<literal>KEY_BLOCK_SIZE</literal>) must be equal to
          <literal>FILE_BLOCK_SIZE/1024</literal>. For example, if
          <literal role="sysvar">innodb_page_size=16K</literal>, and
          <literal>FILE_BLOCK_SIZE=8K</literal>, the
          <literal>KEY_BLOCK_SIZE</literal> of the table must be 8. For
          more information, see <xref linkend="general-tablespaces" />.

<literal>USE LOGFILE GROUP</literal>: Required for
          <literal>NDB</literal>, this is the name of a log file group
          previously created using <literal role="stmt">CREATE LOGFILE
          GROUP</literal>. Not supported for <literal>InnoDB</literal>,
          where it fails with an error.

<literal>EXTENT_SIZE</literal>: This option is specific to
          NDB, and is not supported by InnoDB, where it fails with an
          error. <literal>EXTENT_SIZE</literal> sets the size, in bytes,
          of the extents used by any files belonging to the tablespace.
          The default value is 1M. The minimum size is 32K, and
          theoretical maximum is 2G, although the practical maximum size
          depends on a number of factors. In most cases, changing the
          extent size does not have any measurable effect on
          performance, and the default value is recommended for all but
          the most unusual situations.

An <emphasis role="firstterm">extent</emphasis> is a unit of
          disk space allocation. One extent is filled with as much data
          as that extent can contain before another extent is used. In
          theory, up to 65,535 (64K) extents may used per data file;
          however, the recommended maximum is 32,768 (32K). The
          recommended maximum size for a single data file is
          32Gmdashthat is, 32K extents times 1 MB per extent. In
          addition, once an extent is allocated to a given partition, it
          cannot be used to store data from a different partition; an
          extent cannot store data from more than one partition. This
          means, for example that a tablespace having a single datafile
          whose <literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> (described in the
          following item) is 256 MB and whose
          <literal>EXTENT_SIZE</literal> is 128M has just two extents,
          and so can be used to store data from at most two different
          disk data table partitions.

You can see how many extents remain free in a given data file
          by querying the
          <literal role="is">INFORMATION_SCHEMA.FILES</literal> table,
          and so derive an estimate for how much space remains free in
          the file. For further discussion and examples, see
          <xref linkend="files-table" />.

<literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal>: This option is specific to
          <literal>NDB</literal>, and is not supported by
          <literal>InnoDB</literal>, where it fails with an error.

The <literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> parameter sets the total
          size in bytes of the data file that was specific using
          <literal>ADD DATATFILE</literal>. Once this file has been
          created, its size cannot be changed; however, you can add more
          data files to the tablespace using
          <literal condition="alter-tablespace" role="stmt">ALTER
          TABLESPACE ... ADD DATAFILE</literal>.

<literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> is optional; its default value
          is 134217728 (128 MB).

On 32-bit systems, the maximum supported value for
          <literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> is 4294967296 (4 GB).

<literal>AUTOEXTEND_SIZE</literal>: Currently ignored by
          MySQL; reserved for possible future use. Has no effect in any
          release of MySQL 5.7 or MySQL NDB Cluster 7.5, regardless of
          the storage engine used.

<literal>MAX_SIZE</literal>: Currently ignored by MySQL;
          reserved for possible future use. Has no effect in any release
          of MySQL 5.7 or MySQL NDB Cluster 7.5, regardless of the
          storage engine used.

<literal>NODEGROUP</literal>: Currently ignored by MySQL;
          reserved for possible future use. Has no effect in any release
          of MySQL 5.7 or MySQL NDB Cluster 7.5, regardless of the
          storage engine used.

<literal>WAIT</literal>: Currently ignored by MySQL; reserved
          for possible future use. Has no effect in any release of MySQL
          5.7 or MySQL NDB Cluster 7.5, regardless of the storage engine
          used.

<literal>COMMENT</literal>: Currently ignored by MySQL;
          reserved for possible future use. Has no effect in any release
          of MySQL 5.7 or MySQL NDB Cluster 7.5, regardless of the
          storage engine used.

<literal>ENGINE</literal>: Defines the storage engine which
          uses the tablespace, where
          <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable> is the name of the
          storage engine. Currently, only the <literal>InnoDB</literal>
          storage engine is supported by standard MySQL current-series
          releases. MySQL NDB Cluster 7.5 supports both
          <literal>NDB</literal> and <literal>InnoDB</literal>
          tablespaces. The value of the
          <literal role="sysvar">default_storage_engine</literal> system
          variable is used for <literal>ENGINE</literal> if the option
          is not specified.

For the rules covering the naming of MySQL tablespaces, see
          <xref linkend="identifiers" />. In addition to these rules, the
          slash character (<quote>/</quote>) is not permitted, nor can
          you use names beginning with <literal>innodb_</literal>, as
          this prefix is reserved for system use.
Tablespaces do not support temporary tables.

<literal role="sysvar">innodb_file_per_table</literal>,
          <literal role="sysvar">innodb_file_format</literal>, and
          <literal role="sysvar">innodb_file_format_max</literal>
          settings have no influence on <literal>CREATE
          TABLESPACE</literal> operations.
          <literal role="sysvar">innodb_file_per_table</literal> does
          not need to be enabled. General tablespaces support all table
          row formats regardless of file format settings. Likewise,
          general tablespaces support the addition of tables of any row
          format using
          <literal condition="create-table" role="stmt">CREATE TABLE ...
          TABLESPACE</literal>, regardless of file format settings.

<literal role="sysvar">innodb_strict_mode</literal> is not
          applicable to general tablespaces. Tablespace management rules
          are strictly enforced independently of
          <literal role="sysvar">innodb_strict_mode</literal>. If
          <literal>CREATE TABLESPACE</literal> parameters are incorrect
          or incompatible, the operation fails regardless of the
          <literal role="sysvar">innodb_strict_mode</literal> setting.
          When a table is added to a general tablespace using
          <literal condition="create-table" role="stmt">CREATE TABLE ...
          TABLESPACE</literal> or
          <literal condition="alter-table" role="stmt">ALTER TABLE ...
          TABLESPACE</literal>,
          <literal role="sysvar">innodb_strict_mode</literal> is ignored
          but the statement is evaluated as if
          <literal role="sysvar">innodb_strict_mode</literal> is
          enabled.

Use <literal>DROP TABLESPACE</literal> to remove a tablespace.
          All tables must be dropped from a tablespace using
          <literal role="stmt">DROP TABLE</literal> prior to dropping
          the tablespace. Before dropping an NDB Cluster tablespace you
          must also remove all its data files using one or more
          <literal condition="alter-tablespace" role="stmt">ALTER
          TABLESPACE ... DROP DATATFILE</literal> statements. See
          <xref linkend="mysql-cluster-disk-data-objects" />.

All parts of an <literal>InnoDB</literal> table added to an
          <literal>InnoDB</literal> general tablespace reside in the
          general tablespace, including indexes and
          <literal role="type">BLOB</literal> pages.

For an <literal>NDB</literal> table assigned to a tablespace,
          only those columns which are not indexed are stored on disk,
          and actually use the tablespace data files. Indexes and
          indexed columns for all <literal>NDB</literal> tables are
          always kept in memory.

Similar to the system tablespace, truncating or dropping
          tables stored in a general tablespace creates free space
          internally in the general tablespace
          <link linkend="glos_ibd_file">.ibd data file</link> which can
          only be used for new <literal>InnoDB</literal> data. Space is
          not released back to the operating system as it is for
          file-per-table tablespaces.

A general tablespace is not associated with any database or
          schema.

<literal condition="alter-table" role="stmt">ALTER TABLE ...
          DISCARD TABLESPACE</literal> and
          <literal condition="alter-table" role="stmt">ALTER TABLE
          ...IMPORT TABLESPACE</literal> are not supported for tables
          that belong to a general tablespace.

The server uses tablespace-level metadata locking for DDL that
          references general tablespaces. By comparison, the server uses
          table-level metadata locking for DDL that references
          file-per-table tablespaces.

A generated or existing tablespace cannot be changed to a
          general tablespace.

Tables stored in a general tablespace can only be opened in
          MySQL 5.7.6 or later due to the addition of new table flags.

There is no conflict between general tablespace names and
          file-per-table tablespace names. The <quote>/</quote>
          character, which is present in file-per-table tablespace
          names, is not permitted in general tablespace names.

<command>mysqldump</command> and <command>mysqlpump</command>
          do not dump <literal>InnoDB</literal>
          <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLESPACE</literal> statements.

description.para:
This example demonstrates creating a general tablespace and adding
      three uncompressed tables of different row formats.

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>CREATE TABLESPACE `ts1` ADD DATAFILE 'ts1.ibd' ENGINE=INNODB;</userinput>

mysql> <userinput>CREATE TABLE t1 (c1 INT PRIMARY KEY) TABLESPACE ts1 ROW_FORMAT=REDUNDANT;</userinput>

mysql> <userinput>CREATE TABLE t2 (c1 INT PRIMARY KEY) TABLESPACE ts1 ROW_FORMAT=COMPACT;</userinput>

mysql> <userinput>CREATE TABLE t3 (c1 INT PRIMARY KEY) TABLESPACE ts1 ROW_FORMAT=DYNAMIC;</userinput>

description.para:
This example demonstrates creating a general tablespace and adding
      a compressed table. The example assumes a default
      <literal role="sysvar">innodb_page_size</literal> value of 16K.
      The <literal>FILE_BLOCK_SIZE</literal> of 8192 requires that the
      compressed table have a <literal>KEY_BLOCK_SIZE</literal> of 8.

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>CREATE TABLESPACE `ts2` ADD DATAFILE 'ts2.ibd' FILE_BLOCK_SIZE = 8192 Engine=InnoDB;</userinput>

mysql> <userinput>CREATE TABLE t4 (c1 INT PRIMARY KEY) TABLESPACE ts2 ROW_FORMAT=COMPRESSED KEY_BLOCK_SIZE=8;</userinput>

description.para:
Suppose that you wish to create an NDB Cluster Disk Data
      tablespace named <literal>myts</literal> using a datafile named
      <filename>mydata-1.dat</filename>. An <filename>NDB</filename>
      tablespace always requires the use of a log file group consisting
      of one or more undo log files. For this example, we first create a
      log file group named <literal>mylg</literal> that contains one
      undo long file named <filename>myundo-1.dat</filename>, using the
      <literal role="stmt">CREATE LOGFILE GROUP</literal> statement
      shown here:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>CREATE LOGFILE GROUP myg1</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>ADD UNDOFILE 'myundo-1.dat'</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>ENGINE=NDB;</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected (3.29 sec)

description.para:
Now you can create the tablespace previously described using the
      following statement:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>CREATE TABLESPACE myts</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>ADD DATAFILE 'mydata-1.dat'</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>USE LOGFILE GROUP mylg</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>ENGINE=NDB;</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected (2.98 sec)

description.para:
You can now create a Disk Data table using a
      <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal> statement with the
      <literal>TABLESPACE</literal> and <literal>STORAGE DISK</literal>
      options, similar to what is shown here:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>CREATE TABLE mytable (</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>id INT UNSIGNED NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>lname VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>fname VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>dob DATE NOT NULL,</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>joined DATE NOT NULL,</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>INDEX(last_name, first_name)</userinput>
    -> <userinput>)</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>TABLESPACE myts STORAGE DISK</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>ENGINE=NDB;</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected (1.41 sec)

description.para:
It is important to note that only the <literal>dob</literal> and
      <literal>joined</literal> columns from <literal>mytable</literal>
      are actually stored on disk, due to the fact that the
      <literal>id</literal>, <literal>lname</literal>, and
      <literal>fname</literal> columns are all indexed.

As mentioned previously, when <literal>CREATE TABLESPACE</literal>
      is used with <literal>ENGINE [=] NDB</literal>, a tablespace and
      associated data file are created on each NDB Cluster data node.
      You can verify that the data files were created and obtain
      information about them by querying the
      <literal role="is">INFORMATION_SCHEMA.FILES</literal> table, as
      shown here:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT FILE_NAME, FILE_TYPE, LOGFILE_GROUP_NAME, STATUS, EXTRA</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.FILES</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>WHERE TABLESPACE_NAME = 'myts';</userinput>

+--------------+------------+--------------------+--------+----------------+
| file_name    | file_type  | logfile_group_name | status | extra          |
+--------------+------------+--------------------+--------+----------------+
| mydata-1.dat | DATAFILE   | mylg               | NORMAL | CLUSTER_NODE=5 |
| mydata-1.dat | DATAFILE   | mylg               | NORMAL | CLUSTER_NODE=6 |
| NULL         | TABLESPACE | mylg               | NORMAL | NULL           |
+--------------+------------+--------------------+--------+----------------+
3 rows in set (0.01 sec)

description.para:
For additional information and examples, see
      <xref linkend="mysql-cluster-disk-data-objects" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
CREATE TABLESPACE <replaceable>tablespace_name</replaceable>

  <emphasis>InnoDB and NDB:</emphasis>
    ADD DATAFILE '<replaceable>file_name</replaceable>'

  <emphasis>InnoDB only:</emphasis>
    [FILE_BLOCK_SIZE = value]

  <emphasis>NDB only:</emphasis>
    USE LOGFILE GROUP <replaceable>logfile_group</replaceable>
    [EXTENT_SIZE [=] <replaceable>extent_size</replaceable>]
    [INITIAL_SIZE [=] <replaceable>initial_size</replaceable>]
    [AUTOEXTEND_SIZE [=] <replaceable>autoextend_size</replaceable>]
    [MAX_SIZE [=] <replaceable>max_size</replaceable>]
    [NODEGROUP [=] <replaceable>nodegroup_id</replaceable>]
    [WAIT]
    [COMMENT [=] '<replaceable>string</replaceable>']

  <emphasis>InnoDB and NDB:</emphasis>
    [ENGINE [=] <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable>]

description.para:
This statement creates a new trigger. A trigger is a named
      database object that is associated with a table, and that
      activates when a particular event occurs for the table. The
      trigger becomes associated with the table named
      <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>, which must refer to a
      permanent table. You cannot associate a trigger with a
      <literal>TEMPORARY</literal> table or a view.

Trigger names exist in the schema namespace, meaning that all
      triggers must have unique names within a schema. Triggers in
      different schemas can have the same name.

This section describes <literal role="stmt">CREATE
      TRIGGER</literal> syntax. For additional discussion, see
      <xref linkend="trigger-syntax" />.

<literal role="stmt">CREATE TRIGGER</literal> requires the
      <literal role="priv">TRIGGER</literal> privilege for the table
      associated with the trigger. If the <literal>DEFINER</literal>
      clause is present, the privileges required depend on the
      <replaceable>user</replaceable> value, as discussed in
      <xref linkend="stored-objects-security" />. If binary logging is
      enabled, <literal role="stmt">CREATE TRIGGER</literal> might
      require the <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege, as
      discussed in <xref linkend="stored-programs-logging" />.

The <literal>DEFINER</literal> clause determines the security
      context to be used when checking access privileges at trigger
      activation time, as described later in this section.

<replaceable>trigger_time</replaceable> is the trigger action
      time. It can be <literal>BEFORE</literal> or
      <literal>AFTER</literal> to indicate that the trigger activates
      before or after each row to be modified.

Basic column value checks occur prior to trigger activation, so
      you cannot use <literal>BEFORE</literal> triggers to convert
      values inappropriate for the column type to valid values.

<replaceable>trigger_event</replaceable> indicates the kind of
      operation that activates the trigger. These
      <replaceable>trigger_event</replaceable> values are permitted:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal>: The trigger activates
          whenever a new row is inserted into the table (for example,
          through <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal>,
          <literal role="stmt">LOAD DATA</literal>, and
          <literal role="stmt">REPLACE</literal> statements).

<literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal>: The trigger activates
          whenever a row is modified (for example, through
          <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> statements).

<literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal>: The trigger activates
          whenever a row is deleted from the table (for example, through
          <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> and
          <literal role="stmt">REPLACE</literal> statements).
          <literal role="stmt">DROP TABLE</literal> and
          <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> statements on
          the table do <emphasis>not</emphasis> activate this trigger,
          because they do not use <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal>.
          Dropping a partition does not activate
          <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> triggers, either.

syntax.programlisting:
>
CREATE
    [DEFINER = <replaceable>user</replaceable>]
    TRIGGER <replaceable>trigger_name</replaceable>
    <replaceable>trigger_time</replaceable> <replaceable>trigger_event</replaceable>
    ON <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> FOR EACH ROW
    [<replaceable>trigger_order</replaceable>]
    <replaceable>trigger_body</replaceable>

<replaceable>trigger_time</replaceable>: { BEFORE | AFTER }

<replaceable>trigger_event</replaceable>: { INSERT | UPDATE | DELETE }

<replaceable>trigger_order</replaceable>: { FOLLOWS | PRECEDES } <replaceable>other_trigger_name</replaceable>

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">CREATE VIEW</literal> statement creates a
      new view, or replaces an existing view if the <literal>OR
      REPLACE</literal> clause is given. If the view does not exist,
      <literal condition="create-view" role="stmt">CREATE OR REPLACE
      VIEW</literal> is the same as <literal role="stmt">CREATE
      VIEW</literal>. If the view does exist,
      <literal condition="create-view" role="stmt">CREATE OR REPLACE
      VIEW</literal> replaces it.

For information about restrictions on view use, see
      <xref linkend="view-restrictions" />.

The <replaceable>select_statement</replaceable> is a
      <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement that provides the
      definition of the view. (Selecting from the view selects, in
      effect, using the <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal>
      statement.) The <replaceable>select_statement</replaceable> can
      select from base tables or other views.

The view definition is <quote>frozen</quote> at creation time and
      is not affected by subsequent changes to the definitions of the
      underlying tables. For example, if a view is defined as
      <literal>SELECT *</literal> on a table, new columns added to the
      table later do not become part of the view, and columns dropped
      from the table will result in an error when selecting from the
      view.

The <literal>ALGORITHM</literal> clause affects how MySQL
      processes the view. The <literal>DEFINER</literal> and
      <literal>SQL SECURITY</literal> clauses specify the security
      context to be used when checking access privileges at view
      invocation time. The <literal>WITH CHECK OPTION</literal> clause
      can be given to constrain inserts or updates to rows in tables
      referenced by the view. These clauses are described later in this
      section.

The <literal role="stmt">CREATE VIEW</literal> statement requires
      the <literal role="priv">CREATE VIEW</literal> privilege for the
      view, and some privilege for each column selected by the
      <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement. For columns used
      elsewhere in the <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement,
      you must have the <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege.
      If the <literal>OR REPLACE</literal> clause is present, you must
      also have the <literal role="priv">DROP</literal> privilege for
      the view. If the <literal>DEFINER</literal> clause is present, the
      privileges required depend on the <replaceable>user</replaceable>
      value, as discussed in <xref linkend="stored-objects-security" />.

When a view is referenced, privilege checking occurs as described
      later in this section.

A view belongs to a database. By default, a new view is created in
      the default database. To create the view explicitly in a given
      database, use <replaceable>db_name.view_name</replaceable> syntax
      to qualify the view name with the database name:

description.programlisting:
>
CREATE VIEW test.v AS SELECT * FROM t;

description.para:
Unqualified table or view names in the
      <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement are also
      interpreted with respect to the default database. A view can refer
      to tables or views in other databases by qualifying the table or
      view name with the appropriate database name.

Within a database, base tables and views share the same namespace,
      so a base table and a view cannot have the same name.

Columns retrieved by the <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal>
      statement can be simple references to table columns, or
      expressions that use functions, constant values, operators, and so
      forth.

A view must have unique column names with no duplicates, just like
      a base table. By default, the names of the columns retrieved by
      the <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement are used for
      the view column names. To define explicit names for the view
      columns, specify the optional
      <replaceable>column_list</replaceable> clause as a list of
      comma-separated identifiers. The number of names in
      <replaceable>column_list</replaceable> must be the same as the
      number of columns retrieved by the
      <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement.

A view can be created from many kinds of
      <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statements. It can refer to
      base tables or other views. It can use joins,
      <literal role="stmt">UNION</literal>, and subqueries. The
      <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> need not even refer to any
      tables:

description.programlisting:
>
CREATE VIEW v_today (today) AS SELECT CURRENT_DATE;

description.para:
The following example defines a view that selects two columns from
      another table as well as an expression calculated from those
      columns:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>CREATE TABLE t (qty INT, price INT);</userinput>
mysql> <userinput>INSERT INTO t VALUES(3, 50);</userinput>
mysql> <userinput>CREATE VIEW v AS SELECT qty, price, qty*price AS value FROM t;</userinput>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT * FROM v;</userinput>
+------+-------+-------+
| qty  | price | value |
+------+-------+-------+
|    3 |    50 |   150 |
+------+-------+-------+

description.para: A view definition is subject to the following restrictions:

itemizedlist.para:
The <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement cannot
          refer to system variables or user-defined variables.

Within a stored program, the
          <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement cannot refer
          to program parameters or local variables.

The <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement cannot
          refer to prepared statement parameters.

Any table or view referred to in the definition must exist.
          If, after the view has been created, a table or view that the
          definition refers to is dropped, use of the view results in an
          error. To check a view definition for problems of this kind,
          use the <literal role="stmt">CHECK TABLE</literal> statement.

The definition cannot refer to a <literal>TEMPORARY</literal>
          table, and you cannot create a <literal>TEMPORARY</literal>
          view.
You cannot associate a trigger with a view.

Aliases for column names in the
          <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement are checked
          against the maximum column length of 64 characters (not the
          maximum alias length of 256 characters).

description.para:
<literal>ORDER BY</literal> is permitted in a view definition, but
      it is ignored if you select from a view using a statement that has
      its own <literal>ORDER BY</literal>.

For other options or clauses in the definition, they are added to
      the options or clauses of the statement that references the view,
      but the effect is undefined. For example, if a view definition
      includes a <literal>LIMIT</literal> clause, and you select from
      the view using a statement that has its own
      <literal>LIMIT</literal> clause, it is undefined which limit
      applies. This same principle applies to options such as
      <literal>ALL</literal>, <literal>DISTINCT</literal>, or
      <literal>SQL_SMALL_RESULT</literal> that follow the
      <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> keyword, and to clauses such
      as <literal>INTO</literal>, <literal>FOR UPDATE</literal>,
      <literal>LOCK IN SHARE MODE</literal>, and
      <literal>PROCEDURE</literal>.

The results obtained from a view may be affected if you change the
      query processing environment by changing system variables:

description.programlisting:
>

mysql> <userinput>CREATE VIEW v (mycol) AS SELECT 'abc';</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.01 sec)

mysql> <userinput>SET sql_mode = '';</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.00 sec)

mysql> <userinput>SELECT "mycol" FROM v;</userinput>
+-------+
| mycol |
+-------+
| mycol |
+-------+
1 row in set (0.01 sec)

mysql> <userinput>SET sql_mode = 'ANSI_QUOTES';</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.00 sec)

mysql> <userinput>SELECT "mycol" FROM v;</userinput>
+-------+
| mycol |
+-------+
| abc   |
+-------+
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

description.para:
The <literal>DEFINER</literal> and <literal>SQL SECURITY</literal>
      clauses determine which MySQL account to use when checking access
      privileges for the view when a statement is executed that
      references the view. The valid <literal>SQL SECURITY</literal>
      characteristic values are <literal>DEFINER</literal> (the default)
      and <literal>INVOKER</literal>. These indicate that the required
      privileges must be held by the user who defined or invoked the
      view, respectively.

If the <literal>DEFINER</literal> clause is present, the
      <replaceable>user</replaceable> value should be a MySQL account
      specified as
      <literal>'<replaceable>user_name</replaceable>'@'<replaceable>host_name</replaceable>'</literal>,
      <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER</literal>, or
      <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER()</literal>. The permitted
      <replaceable>user</replaceable> values depend on the privileges
      you hold, as discussed in
      <xref linkend="stored-objects-security" />. Also see that section
      for additional information about view security.

If the <literal>DEFINER</literal> clause is omitted, the default
      definer is the user who executes the <literal role="stmt">CREATE
      VIEW</literal> statement. This is the same as specifying
      <literal>DEFINER = CURRENT_USER</literal> explicitly.

Within a view definition, the
      <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER</literal> function returns the
      view's <literal>DEFINER</literal> value by default. For views
      defined with the <literal>SQL SECURITY INVOKER</literal>
      characteristic, <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER</literal>
      returns the account for the view's invoker. For information about
      user auditing within views, see
      <xref linkend="account-activity-auditing" />.

Within a stored routine that is defined with the <literal>SQL
      SECURITY DEFINER</literal> characteristic,
      <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER</literal> returns the routine's
      <literal>DEFINER</literal> value. This also affects a view defined
      within such a routine, if the view definition contains a
      <literal>DEFINER</literal> value of
      <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER</literal>.
MySQL checks view privileges like this:

itemizedlist.para:
At view definition time, the view creator must have the
          privileges needed to use the top-level objects accessed by the
          view. For example, if the view definition refers to table
          columns, the creator must have some privilege for each column
          in the select list of the definition, and the
          <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege for each
          column used elsewhere in the definition. If the definition
          refers to a stored function, only the privileges needed to
          invoke the function can be checked. The privileges required at
          function invocation time can be checked only as it executes:
          For different invocations, different execution paths within
          the function might be taken.

The user who references a view must have appropriate
          privileges to access it (<literal role="priv">SELECT</literal>
          to select from it, <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> to
          insert into it, and so forth.)

When a view has been referenced, privileges for objects
          accessed by the view are checked against the privileges held
          by the view <literal>DEFINER</literal> account or invoker,
          depending on whether the <literal>SQL SECURITY</literal>
          characteristic is <literal>DEFINER</literal> or
          <literal>INVOKER</literal>, respectively.

If reference to a view causes execution of a stored function,
          privilege checking for statements executed within the function
          depend on whether the function <literal>SQL SECURITY</literal>
          characteristic is <literal>DEFINER</literal> or
          <literal>INVOKER</literal>. If the security characteristic is
          <literal>DEFINER</literal>, the function runs with the
          privileges of the <literal>DEFINER</literal> account. If the
          characteristic is <literal>INVOKER</literal>, the function
          runs with the privileges determined by the view's <literal>SQL
          SECURITY</literal> characteristic.

description.para:
Example: A view might depend on a stored function, and that
      function might invoke other stored routines. For example, the
      following view invokes a stored function <literal>f()</literal>:

description.programlisting:
>
CREATE VIEW v AS SELECT * FROM t WHERE t.id = f(t.name);

description.para:
Suppose that <literal>f()</literal> contains a statement such as
      this:

The privileges required for executing statements within
      <literal>f()</literal> need to be checked when
      <literal>f()</literal> executes. This might mean that privileges
      are needed for <literal>p1()</literal> or <literal>p2()</literal>,
      depending on the execution path within <literal>f()</literal>.
      Those privileges must be checked at runtime, and the user who must
      possess the privileges is determined by the <literal>SQL
      SECURITY</literal> values of the view <literal>v</literal> and the
      function <literal>f()</literal>.

The <literal>DEFINER</literal> and <literal>SQL SECURITY</literal>
      clauses for views are extensions to standard SQL. In standard SQL,
      views are handled using the rules for <literal>SQL SECURITY
      DEFINER</literal>. The standard says that the definer of the view,
      which is the same as the owner of the view's schema, gets
      applicable privileges on the view (for example,
      <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal>) and may grant them. MySQL
      has no concept of a schema <quote>owner</quote>, so MySQL adds a
      clause to identify the definer. The <literal>DEFINER</literal>
      clause is an extension where the intent is to have what the
      standard has; that is, a permanent record of who defined the view.
      This is why the default <literal>DEFINER</literal> value is the
      account of the view creator.

The optional <literal>ALGORITHM</literal> clause is a MySQL
      extension to standard SQL. It affects how MySQL processes the
      view. <literal>ALGORITHM</literal> takes three values:
      <literal>MERGE</literal>, <literal>TEMPTABLE</literal>, or
      <literal>UNDEFINED</literal>. For more information, see
      <xref linkend="view-algorithms" />, as well as
      <xref linkend="derived-table-optimization" />.

Some views are updatable. That is, you can use them in statements
      such as <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal>,
      <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal>, or
      <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> to update the contents of
      the underlying table. For a view to be updatable, there must be a
      one-to-one relationship between the rows in the view and the rows
      in the underlying table. There are also certain other constructs
      that make a view nonupdatable.

A generated column in a view is considered updatable because it is
      possible to assign to it. However, if such a column is updated
      explicitly, the only permitted value is
      <literal>DEFAULT</literal>. For information about generated
      columns, see <xref linkend="create-table-generated-columns" />.

The <literal>WITH CHECK OPTION</literal> clause can be given for
      an updatable view to prevent inserts or updates to rows except
      those for which the <literal>WHERE</literal> clause in the
      <replaceable>select_statement</replaceable> is true.

In a <literal>WITH CHECK OPTION</literal> clause for an updatable
      view, the <literal>LOCAL</literal> and <literal>CASCADED</literal>
      keywords determine the scope of check testing when the view is
      defined in terms of another view. The <literal>LOCAL</literal>
      keyword restricts the <literal>CHECK OPTION</literal> only to the
      view being defined. <literal>CASCADED</literal> causes the checks
      for underlying views to be evaluated as well. When neither keyword
      is given, the default is <literal>CASCADED</literal>.

For more information about updatable views and the <literal>WITH
      CHECK OPTION</literal> clause, see
      <xref linkend="view-updatability" />, and
      <xref linkend="view-check-option" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
CREATE
    [OR REPLACE]
    [ALGORITHM = {UNDEFINED | MERGE | TEMPTABLE}]
    [DEFINER = <replaceable>user</replaceable>]
    [SQL SECURITY { DEFINER | INVOKER }]
    VIEW <replaceable>view_name</replaceable> [(<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>)]
    AS <replaceable>select_statement</replaceable>
    [WITH [CASCADED | LOCAL] CHECK OPTION]

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">DROP DATABASE</literal> drops all tables in
      the database and deletes the database. Be
      <emphasis>very</emphasis> careful with this statement! To use
      <literal role="stmt">DROP DATABASE</literal>, you need the
      <literal role="priv">DROP</literal> privilege on the database.
      <literal condition="drop-database" role="stmt">DROP
      SCHEMA</literal> is a synonym for <literal role="stmt">DROP
      DATABASE</literal>.

<literal>IF EXISTS</literal> is used to prevent an error from
      occurring if the database does not exist.

This statement drops the event named
      <replaceable>event_name</replaceable>. The event immediately
      ceases being active, and is deleted completely from the server.

If the event does not exist, the error <errortext>ERROR 1517
      (HY000): Unknown event
      '<replaceable>event_name</replaceable>'</errortext> results. You
      can override this and cause the statement to generate a warning
      for nonexistent events instead using <literal>IF EXISTS</literal>.

This statement requires the <literal role="priv">EVENT</literal>
      privilege for the schema to which the event to be dropped belongs.

<literal role="stmt">DROP INDEX</literal> drops the index named
      <replaceable>index_name</replaceable> from the table
      <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>. This statement is mapped to
      an <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal> statement to drop
      the index. See <xref linkend="alter-table" />.

To drop a primary key, the index name is always
      <literal>PRIMARY</literal>, which must be specified as a quoted
      identifier because <literal>PRIMARY</literal> is a reserved word:

description.programlisting:
>
DROP INDEX `PRIMARY` ON t;

description.para:
This statement is used to drop a stored procedure or function.
      That is, the specified routine is removed from the server. You
      must have the <literal role="priv">ALTER ROUTINE</literal>
      privilege for the routine. (If the
      <literal>automatic_sp_privileges</literal> system variable is
      enabled, that privilege and <literal role="priv">EXECUTE</literal>
      are granted automatically to the routine creator when the routine
      is created and dropped from the creator when the routine is
      dropped. See <xref linkend="stored-routines-privileges" />.)

The <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> clause is a MySQL extension. It
      prevents an error from occurring if the procedure or function does
      not exist. A warning is produced that can be viewed with
      <literal role="stmt">SHOW WARNINGS</literal>.

Drops the server definition for the server named
      <literal><replaceable>server_name</replaceable></literal>. The
      corresponding row in the <literal>mysql.servers</literal> table is
      deleted. This statement requires the
      <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

Dropping a server for a table does not affect any
      <literal>FEDERATED</literal> tables that used this connection
      information when they were created. See
      <xref linkend="create-server" />.

<literal role="stmt">DROP TABLE</literal> removes one or more
      tables. You must have the <literal role="priv">DROP</literal>
      privilege for each table.

<emphasis>Be careful</emphasis> with this statement! For each
      table, it removes the table definition and all table data. If the
      table is partitioned, the statement removes the table definition,
      all its partitions, all data stored in those partitions, and all
      partition definitions associated with the dropped table.
Dropping a table also drops any triggers for the table.

<literal role="stmt">DROP TABLE</literal> causes an implicit
      commit, except when used with the <literal>TEMPORARY</literal>
      keyword. See <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

If any tables named in the argument list do not exist,
      <literal role="stmt">DROP TABLE</literal> behavior depends on
      whether the <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> clause is given:

itemizedlist.para:
Without <literal>IF EXISTS</literal>, the statement drops all
          named tables that do exist, and returns an error indicating
          which nonexisting tables it was unable to drop.

With <literal>IF EXISTS</literal>, no error occurs for
          nonexisting tables. The statement drops all named tables that
          do exist, and generates a <literal>NOTE</literal> diagnostic
          for each nonexistent table. These notes can be displayed with
          <literal role="stmt">SHOW WARNINGS</literal>. See
          <xref linkend="show-warnings" />.

description.para:
<literal>IF EXISTS</literal> can also be useful for dropping
      tables in unusual circumstances under which there is an
      <filename>.frm</filename> file but no table managed by the storage
      engine. (For example, if an abnormal server exit occurs after
      removal of the table from the storage engine but before
      <filename>.frm</filename> file removal.)

The <literal>TEMPORARY</literal> keyword has the following
      effects:

itemizedlist.para: The statement drops only <literal>TEMPORARY</literal> tables.
The statement does not cause an implicit commit.

No access rights are checked. A <literal>TEMPORARY</literal>
          table is visible only with the session that created it, so no
          check is necessary.

description.para:
Including the <literal>TEMPORARY</literal> keyword is a good way
      to prevent accidentally dropping non-<literal>TEMPORARY</literal>
      tables.

The <literal>RESTRICT</literal> and <literal>CASCADE</literal>
      keywords do nothing. They are permitted to make porting easier
      from other database systems.

<literal role="stmt">DROP TABLE</literal> is not supported with
      all <literal role="sysvar">innodb_force_recovery</literal>
      settings. See <xref linkend="forcing-innodb-recovery" />.

This statement drops a tablespace that was previously created
      using <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLESPACE</literal>. It is
      supported with all MySQL NDB Cluster 7.5 releases, and with
      <literal>InnoDB</literal> in the standard MySQL Server as well.

<literal>ENGINE</literal> sets the storage engine that uses the
      tablespace, where <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable> is the
      name of the storage engine. Currently, the values
      <literal>InnoDB</literal> and <literal>NDB</literal> are
      supported. If not set, the value of
      <literal role="sysvar">default_storage_engine</literal> is used.
      If it is not the same as the storage engine used to create the
      tablespace, the <literal>DROP TABLESPACE</literal> statement
      fails.

For an <literal>InnoDB</literal> tablespace, all tables must be
      dropped from the tablespace prior to a <literal>DROP
      TABLESPACE</literal> operation. If the tablespace is not empty,
      <literal>DROP TABLESPACE</literal> returns an error.

As with the <literal>InnoDB</literal> system tablespace,
      truncating or dropping <literal>InnoDB</literal> tables stored in
      a general tablespace creates free space in the tablespace
      <link linkend="glos_ibd_file">.ibd data file</link>, which can
      only be used for new <literal>InnoDB</literal> data. Space is not
      released back to the operating system by such operations as it is
      for file-per-table tablespaces.

An <literal>NDB</literal> tablespace to be dropped must not
      contain any data files; in other words, before you can drop an
      <literal>NDB</literal> tablespace, you must first drop each of its
      data files using
      <literal condition="alter-tablespace" role="stmt">ALTER TABLESPACE
      ... DROP DATAFILE</literal>.

itemizedlist.para:
Tablespaces are not deleted automatically. A tablespace must
          be dropped explicitly using <literal>DROP
          TABLESPACE</literal>. <literal role="stmt">DROP
          DATABASE</literal> has no effect in this regard, even if the
          operation drops all tables belonging to the tablespace.

A <literal role="stmt">DROP DATABASE</literal> operation can
          drop tables that belong to a general tablespace but it cannot
          drop the tablespace, even if the operation drops all tables
          that belong to the tablespace. The tablespace must be dropped
          explicitly using <literal>DROP TABLESPACE
          <replaceable>tablespace_name</replaceable></literal>.

Similar to the system tablespace, truncating or dropping
          tables stored in a general tablespace creates free space
          internally in the general tablespace
          <link linkend="glos_ibd_file">.ibd data file</link> which can
          only be used for new <literal>InnoDB</literal> data. Space is
          not released back to the operating system as it is for
          file-per-table tablespaces.

description.para:
This example demonstrates how to drop an <literal>InnoDB</literal>
      general tablespace. The general tablespace <literal>ts1</literal>
      is created with a single table. Before dropping the tablespace,
      the table must be dropped.

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>CREATE TABLESPACE `ts1` ADD DATAFILE 'ts1.ibd' Engine=InnoDB;</userinput> 

mysql> <userinput>CREATE TABLE t1 (c1 INT PRIMARY KEY) TABLESPACE ts1 Engine=InnoDB;</userinput> 
      
mysql> <userinput>DROP TABLE t1;</userinput>

mysql> <userinput>DROP TABLESPACE ts1;</userinput>

description.para:
This example shows how to drop an <literal>NDB</literal>
      tablespace <literal>myts</literal> having a data file named
      <filename>mydata-1.dat</filename> after first creating the
      tablespace, and assumes the existence of a log file group named
      <literal>mylg</literal> (see
      <xref linkend="create-logfile-group" />).

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>CREATE TABLESPACE myts</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>ADD DATAFILE 'mydata-1.dat'</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>USE LOGFILE GROUP mylg</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>ENGINE=NDB;</userinput>

description.para:
You must remove all data files from the tablespace using
      <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLESPACE</literal>, as shown here,
      before it can be dropped:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>ALTER TABLESPACE myts</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>DROP DATAFILE 'mydata-1.dat'</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>ENGINE=NDB;</userinput>

mysql> <userinput>DROP TABLESPACE myts;</userinput>

description.para:
This statement drops a trigger. The schema (database) name is
      optional. If the schema is omitted, the trigger is dropped from
      the default schema. <literal role="stmt">DROP TRIGGER</literal>
      requires the <literal role="priv">TRIGGER</literal> privilege for
      the table associated with the trigger.

Use <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> to prevent an error from
      occurring for a trigger that does not exist. A
      <literal>NOTE</literal> is generated for a nonexistent trigger
      when using <literal>IF EXISTS</literal>. See
      <xref linkend="show-warnings" />.
Triggers for a table are also dropped if you drop the table.

<literal role="stmt">DROP VIEW</literal> removes one or more
      views. You must have the <literal role="priv">DROP</literal>
      privilege for each view.

If any views named in the argument list do not exist, the
      statement returns an error indicating by name which nonexisting
      views it was unable to drop, but also drops all views in the list
      that do exist.

The <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> clause prevents an error from
      occurring for views that don't exist. When this clause is given, a
      <literal>NOTE</literal> is generated for each nonexistent view.
      See <xref linkend="show-warnings" />.

<literal>RESTRICT</literal> and <literal>CASCADE</literal>, if
      given, are parsed and ignored.

<literal role="stmt">RENAME TABLE</literal> renames one or more
      tables. You must have <literal role="priv">ALTER</literal> and
      <literal role="priv">DROP</literal> privileges for the original
      table, and <literal role="priv">CREATE</literal> and
      <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privileges for the new
      table.

For example, to rename a table named <literal>old_table</literal>
      to <literal>new_table</literal>, use this statement:

description.programlisting:
>
RENAME TABLE old_table TO new_table;

description.para:
That statement is equivalent to the following
      <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal> statement:

description.programlisting:
>
ALTER TABLE old_table RENAME new_table;

description.para:
<literal>RENAME TABLE</literal>, unlike <literal role="stmt">ALTER
      TABLE</literal>, can rename multiple tables within a single
      statement:

description.programlisting:
>
RENAME TABLE old_table1 TO new_table1,
             old_table2 TO new_table2,
             old_table3 TO new_table3;

description.para:
Renaming operations are performed left to right. Thus, to swap two
      table names, do this (assuming that a table with the intermediary
      name <literal>tmp_table</literal> does not already exist):

description.programlisting:
>
RENAME TABLE old_table TO tmp_table,
             new_table TO old_table,
             tmp_table TO new_table;

description.para:
Metadata locks on tables are acquired in name order, which in some
      cases can make a difference in operation outcome when multiple
      transactions execute concurrently. See
      <xref linkend="metadata-locking" />.

To execute <literal>RENAME TABLE</literal>, there must be no
      active transactions or tables locked with <literal>LOCK
      TABLES</literal>. With the transaction table locking conditions
      satisfied, the rename operation is done atomically; no other
      session can access any of the tables while the rename is in
      progress.

If any errors occur during a <literal>RENAME TABLE</literal>, the
      statement fails and no changes are made.

You can use <literal>RENAME TABLE</literal> to move a table from
      one database to another:

description.programlisting:
>
RENAME TABLE <replaceable>current_db.tbl_name</replaceable> TO <replaceable>other_db.tbl_name;</replaceable>

description.para:
Using this method to move all tables from one database to a
      different one in effect renames the database (an operation for
      which MySQL has no single statement), except that the original
      database continues to exist, albeit with no tables.

Like <literal>RENAME TABLE</literal>, <literal>ALTER TABLE ...
      RENAME</literal> can also be used to move a table to a different
      database. Regardless of the statement used, if the rename
      operation would move the table to a database located on a
      different file system, the success of the outcome is platform
      specific and depends on the underlying operating system calls used
      to move table files.

If a table has triggers, attempts to rename the table into a
      different database fail with a <errortext>Trigger in wrong
      schema</errortext>
      (<literal role="error">ER_TRG_IN_WRONG_SCHEMA</literal>) error.

To rename <literal>TEMPORARY</literal> tables, <literal>RENAME
      TABLE</literal> does not work. Use <literal role="stmt">ALTER
      TABLE</literal> instead.

<literal>RENAME TABLE</literal> works for views, except that views
      cannot be renamed into a different database.

Any privileges granted specifically for a renamed table or view
      are not migrated to the new name. They must be changed manually.

<literal>RENAME TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> TO
      <replaceable>new_tbl_name</replaceable></literal> changes
      internally generated foreign key constraint names and user-defined
      foreign key constraint names that begin with the string
      <quote><replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>_ibfk_</quote> to
      reflect the new table name. <literal>InnoDB</literal> interprets
      foreign key constraint names that begin with the string
      <quote><replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>_ibfk_</quote> as
      internally generated names.

Foreign key constraint names that point to the renamed table are
      automatically updated unless there is a conflict, in which case
      the statement fails with an error. A conflict occurs if the
      renamed constraint name already exists. In such cases, you must
      drop and re-create the foreign keys for them to function properly.

<literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> empties a table
      completely. It requires the <literal role="priv">DROP</literal>
      privilege.

Logically, <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> is
      similar to a <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> statement that
      deletes all rows, or a sequence of <literal role="stmt">DROP
      TABLE</literal> and <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal>
      statements. To achieve high performance, it bypasses the DML
      method of deleting data. Thus, it cannot be rolled back, it does
      not cause <literal>ON DELETE</literal> triggers to fire, and it
      cannot be performed for <literal>InnoDB</literal> tables with
      parent-child foreign key relationships.

Although <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> is similar
      to <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal>, it is classified as a
      DDL statement rather than a DML statement. It differs from
      <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> in the following ways:

itemizedlist.para:
Truncate operations drop and re-create the table, which is
          much faster than deleting rows one by one, particularly for
          large tables.

Truncate operations cause an implicit commit, and so cannot be
          rolled back. See <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

Truncation operations cannot be performed if the session holds
          an active table lock.

<literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> fails for an
          <literal>InnoDB</literal> table or
          <literal role="se">NDB</literal> table if there are any
          <literal>FOREIGN KEY</literal> constraints from other tables
          that reference the table. Foreign key constraints between
          columns of the same table are permitted.

Truncation operations do not return a meaningful value for the
          number of deleted rows. The usual result is <quote>0 rows
          affected,</quote> which should be interpreted as <quote>no
          information.</quote>

As long as the table format file
          <filename><replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>.frm</filename>
          is valid, the table can be re-created as an empty table with
          <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal>, even if the
          data or index files have become corrupted.

Any <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> value is reset to its
          start value. This is true even for <literal>MyISAM</literal>
          and <literal>InnoDB</literal>, which normally do not reuse
          sequence values.

When used with partitioned tables,
          <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> preserves the
          partitioning; that is, the data and index files are dropped
          and re-created, while the partition definitions
          (<filename>.par</filename>) file is unaffected.

The <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> statement
          does not invoke <literal>ON DELETE</literal> triggers.

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">CALL</literal> statement invokes a stored
      procedure that was defined previously with
      <literal role="stmt">CREATE PROCEDURE</literal>.

Stored procedures that take no arguments can be invoked without
      parentheses. That is, <literal>CALL p()</literal> and
      <literal>CALL p</literal> are equivalent.

<literal role="stmt">CALL</literal> can pass back values to its
      caller using parameters that are declared as
      <literal>OUT</literal> or <literal>INOUT</literal> parameters.
      When the procedure returns, a client program can also obtain the
      number of rows affected for the final statement executed within
      the routine: At the SQL level, call the
      <literal role="func">ROW_COUNT()</literal> function; from the C
      API, call the
      <literal role="cfunc">mysql_affected_rows()</literal> function.

For information about the effect of unhandled conditions on
      procedure parameters, see
      <xref linkend="conditions-and-parameters" />.

You need the <literal role="priv">DELETE</literal> privilege on a
      table to delete rows from it. You need only the
      <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege for any columns
      that are only read, such as those named in the
      <literal>WHERE</literal> clause.

When you do not need to know the number of deleted rows, the
      <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> statement is a
      faster way to empty a table than a
      <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> statement with no
      <literal>WHERE</literal> clause. Unlike
      <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal>,
      <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> cannot be used
      within a transaction or if you have a lock on the table. See
      <xref linkend="truncate-table" /> and
      <xref linkend="lock-tables" />.

The speed of delete operations may also be affected by factors
      discussed in <xref linkend="delete-optimization" />.

To ensure that a given <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal>
      statement does not take too much time, the MySQL-specific
      <literal>LIMIT <replaceable>row_count</replaceable></literal>
      clause for <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> specifies the
      maximum number of rows to be deleted. If the number of rows to
      delete is larger than the limit, repeat the
      <literal>DELETE</literal> statement until the number of affected
      rows is less than the <literal>LIMIT</literal> value.

You cannot delete from a table and select from the same table in a
      subquery.

<literal>DELETE</literal> supports explicit partition selection
      using the <literal>PARTITION</literal> option, which takes a list
      of the comma-separated names of one or more partitions or
      subpartitions (or both) from which to select rows to be dropped.
      Partitions not included in the list are ignored. Given a
      partitioned table <literal>t</literal> with a partition named
      <literal>p0</literal>, executing the statement <literal>DELETE
      FROM t PARTITION (p0)</literal> has the same effect on the table
      as executing <literal condition="alter-table" role="stmt">ALTER
      TABLE t TRUNCATE PARTITION (p0)</literal>; in both cases, all rows
      in partition <literal>p0</literal> are dropped.

<literal>PARTITION</literal> can be used along with a
      <literal>WHERE</literal> condition, in which case the condition is
      tested only on rows in the listed partitions. For example,
      <literal>DELETE FROM t PARTITION (p0) WHERE c < 5</literal>
      deletes rows only from partition <literal>p0</literal> for which
      the condition <literal>c < 5</literal> is true; rows in any
      other partitions are not checked and thus not affected by the
      <literal>DELETE</literal>.

The <literal>PARTITION</literal> option can also be used in
      multiple-table <literal>DELETE</literal> statements. You can use
      up to one such option per table named in the
      <literal>FROM</literal> option.

For more information and examples, see
      <xref linkend="partitioning-selection" />.

syntax.para:
<literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> is a DML statement that
      removes rows from a table.

The <literal>DELETE</literal> statement deletes rows from
      <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> and returns the number of
      deleted rows. To check the number of deleted rows, call the
      <literal role="func">ROW_COUNT()</literal> function described in
      <xref linkend="information-functions" />.

The conditions in the optional <literal>WHERE</literal> clause
      identify which rows to delete. With no <literal>WHERE</literal>
      clause, all rows are deleted.

<replaceable>where_condition</replaceable> is an expression that
      evaluates to true for each row to be deleted. It is specified as
      described in <xref linkend="select" />.

If the <literal>ORDER BY</literal> clause is specified, the rows
      are deleted in the order that is specified. The
      <literal>LIMIT</literal> clause places a limit on the number of
      rows that can be deleted. These clauses apply to single-table
      deletes, but not multi-table deletes.

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">DO</literal> executes the expressions but
      does not return any results. In most respects,
      <literal role="stmt">DO</literal> is shorthand for <literal>SELECT
      <replaceable>expr</replaceable>, ...</literal>, but has the
      advantage that it is slightly faster when you do not care about
      the result.

<literal role="stmt">DO</literal> is useful primarily with
      functions that have side effects, such as
      <literal role="func">RELEASE_LOCK()</literal>.

Example: This <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement
      pauses, but also produces a result set:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT SLEEP(5);</userinput>
+----------+
| SLEEP(5) |
+----------+
|        0 |
+----------+
1 row in set (5.02 sec)

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">DO</literal>, on the other hand, pauses
      without producing a result set.:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>DO SLEEP(5);</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected (4.99 sec)

description.para:
This could be useful, for example in a stored function or trigger,
      which prohibit statements that produce result sets.

<literal role="stmt">DO</literal> only executes expressions. It
      cannot be used in all cases where <literal>SELECT</literal> can be
      used. For example, <literal>DO id FROM t1</literal> is invalid
