  | REPLICATE_REWRITE_DB = (<replaceable>db_pair_list</replaceable>)

<replaceable>db_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>[, <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>][, ...]

<replaceable>tbl_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>db_name.table_name</replaceable>[, <replaceable>db_table_name</replaceable>][, ...]
<replaceable>wild_tbl_list</replaceable>:
    '<replaceable>db_pattern.table_pattern</replaceable>'[, '<replaceable>db_pattern.table_pattern</replaceable>'][, ...]

<replaceable>db_pair_list</replaceable>:
    (<replaceable>db_pair</replaceable>)[, (<replaceable>db_pair</replaceable>)][, ...]

<replaceable>db_pair</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>from_db</replaceable>, <replaceable>to_db</replaceable>

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> makes the slave
        forget its replication position in the master's binary log. This
        statement is meant to be used for a clean start: It clears the
        master info and relay log info repositories, deletes all the
        relay log files, and starts a new relay log file. It also resets
        to 0 the replication delay specified with the
        <literal>MASTER_DELAY</literal> option to <literal>CHANGE MASTER
        TO</literal>.

For a server where GTIDs are in use
        (<literal role="sysvar">gtid_mode</literal> is
        <literal>ON</literal>), issuing <literal role="stmt">RESET
        SLAVE</literal> has no effect on the GTID execution history. The
        statement does not change the values of
        <literal>gtid_executed</literal> or
        <literal>gtid_purged</literal>, or the
        <literal>mysql.gtid_executed</literal> table. If you need to
        reset the GTID execution history, use <literal role="stmt">RESET
        MASTER</literal>, even if the GTID-enabled server is a
        replication slave where binary logging is disabled.

<literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">RELOAD</literal> privilege.

To use <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal>, the slave
        replication threads must be stopped, so on a running slave use
        <literal role="stmt">STOP SLAVE</literal> before issuing
        <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal>. To use
        <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> on a Group
        Replication group member, the member status must be
        <literal>OFFLINE</literal>, meaning that the plugin is loaded
        but the member does not currently belong to any group. A group
        member can be taken offline by using a <literal role="stmt">STOP
        GROUP REPLICATION</literal> statement.

The optional <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause enables you
        to name which replication channel the statement applies to.
        Providing a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause applies the
        <literal>RESET SLAVE</literal> statement to a specific
        replication channel. Combining a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause with the
        <literal>ALL</literal> option deletes the specified channel. If
        no channel is named and no extra channels exist, the statement
        applies to the default channel. Issuing a
        <literal condition="reset-slave" role="stmt">RESET SLAVE
        ALL</literal> statement without a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause when
        multiple replication channels exist deletes
        <emphasis>all</emphasis> replication channels and recreates only
        the default channel. See <xref linkend="replication-channels" />
        for more information.

<literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> does not change any
        replication connection parameters such as master host, master
        port, master user, or master password.

itemizedlist.para:
From MySQL 5.7.24, when
            <literal role="sysvar">master_info_repository=TABLE</literal>
            is set on the server, replication connection parameters are
            preserved in the crash-safe <literal>InnoDB</literal> table
            <literal>mysql.slave_master_info</literal> as part of the
            <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> operation. They
            are also retained in memory. In the event of a server crash
            or deliberate restart after issuing
            <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> but before
            issuing <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal>, the
            replication connection parameters are retrieved from the
            table and reused for the new connection.

When
            <literal role="sysvar">master_info_repository=FILE</literal>
            is set on the server (which is the default in MySQL 5.7),
            replication connection parameters are only retained in
            memory. If the slave <command>mysqld</command> is restarted
            immediately after issuing <literal role="stmt">RESET
            SLAVE</literal> due to a server crash or deliberate restart,
            the connection parameters are lost. In that case, you must
            issue a <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>
            statement after the server start to respecify the connection
            parameters before issuing <literal role="stmt">START
            SLAVE</literal>.

description.para:
If you want to reset the connection parameters intentionally,
        you need to use
        <literal condition="reset-slave" role="stmt">RESET SLAVE
        ALL</literal>, which clears the connection parameters. In that
        case, you must issue a <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER
        TO</literal> statement after the server start to specify the new
        connection parameters.

<literal>RESET SLAVE</literal> causes an implicit commit of an
        ongoing transaction. See <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

If the slave SQL thread was in the middle of replicating
        temporary tables when it was stopped, and
        <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> is issued, these
        replicated temporary tables are deleted on the slave.

Prior to MySQL 5.7.5, <literal>RESET SLAVE</literal> also had
        the effect of resetting both the heartbeat period
        (<literal role="statvar">Slave_heartbeat_period</literal>) and
        <literal>SSL_VERIFY_SERVER_CERT</literal>. This issue is fixed
        in MySQL 5.7.5 and later. (Bug #18777899, Bug #18778485)

Prior to MySQL 5.7.5, <literal>RESET SLAVE ALL</literal> did not
        clear the <literal>IGNORE_SERVER_IDS</literal> list set by
        <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>. In MySQL 5.7.5
        and later, the statement clears the list. (Bug #18816897)

This statement skips the next <replaceable>N</replaceable>
        events from the master. This is useful for recovering from
        replication stops caused by a statement.

This statement is valid only when the slave threads are not
        running. Otherwise, it produces an error.

<literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> with no
        <replaceable>thread_type</replaceable> options starts both of
        the slave threads. The I/O thread reads events from the master
        server and stores them in the relay log. The SQL thread reads
        events from the relay log and executes them.
        <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">REPLICATION_SLAVE_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

If <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> succeeds in
        starting the slave threads, it returns without any error.
        However, even in that case, it might be that the slave threads
        start and then later stop (for example, because they do not
        manage to connect to the master or read its binary log, or some
        other problem). <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> does
        not warn you about this. You must check the slave's error log
        for error messages generated by the slave threads, or check that
        they are running satisfactorily with <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        SLAVE STATUS</literal>.

In MySQL current-series, <literal>START SLAVE</literal> causes
        an implicit commit of an ongoing transaction. See
        <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

<literal role="sysvar">gtid_next</literal> must be set to
        <literal>AUTOMATIC</literal> before issuing this statement.

The optional <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause enables you
        to name which replication channel the statement applies to.
        Providing a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause applies the
        <literal>START SLAVE</literal> statement to a specific
        replication channel. If no clause is named and no extra channels
        exist, the statement applies to the default channel. If a
        <literal>START SLAVE</literal> statement does not have a channel
        defined when using multiple channels, this statement starts the
        specified threads for all channels. This statement is disallowed
        for the <literal>group_replication_recovery</literal> channel.
        See <xref linkend="replication-channels" /> for more information.

You can add <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> and
        <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> options to the statement to name
        which of the threads to start. Note that the Group Replication
        applier channel (<literal>group_replication_applier</literal>)
        has no I/O thread, only a SQL thread. Specifying the
        <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> or <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal>
        options when you start this channel has no benefit.

MySQL supports pluggable user-password authentication with
        <literal>START SLAVE</literal> with the <literal>USER</literal>,
        <literal>PASSWORD</literal>, <literal>DEFAULT_AUTH</literal> and
        <literal>PLUGIN_DIR</literal> options, as described in the
        following list:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>USER</literal>: User name. Cannot be set to an
            empty or null string, or left unset if
            <literal>PASSWORD</literal> is used.
<literal>PASSWORD</literal>: Password.

<literal>DEFAULT_AUTH</literal>: Name of plugin; default is
            MySQL native authentication.
<literal>PLUGIN_DIR</literal>: Location of plugin.

description.para:
You cannot use the <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> option when
        specifying any of <literal>USER</literal>,
        <literal>PASSWORD</literal>, <literal>DEFAULT_AUTH</literal>, or
        <literal>PLUGIN_DIR</literal>, unless the
        <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> option is also provided.

See <xref linkend="pluggable-authentication" />, for more
        information.

If an insecure connection is used with any these options, the
        server issues the warning <errortext>Sending passwords in plain
        text without SSL/TLS is extremely insecure</errortext>.

<literal>START SLAVE ... UNTIL</literal> supports two additional
        options for use with global transaction identifiers (GTIDs) (see
        <xref linkend="replication-gtids" />). Each of these takes a set
        of one or more global transaction identifiers
        <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable> as an argument (see
        <xref linkend="replication-gtids-concepts-gtid-sets" />, for more
        information).

When no <replaceable>thread_type</replaceable> is specified,
        <literal>START SLAVE UNTIL SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS</literal> causes the
        slave SQL thread to process transactions until it has reached
        the <emphasis>first</emphasis> transaction whose GTID is listed
        in the <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>. <literal>START SLAVE
        UNTIL SQL_AFTER_GTIDS</literal> causes the slave threads to
        process all transactions until the
        <replaceable>last</replaceable> transaction in the
        <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable> has been processed by both
        threads. In other words, <literal>START SLAVE UNTIL
        SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS</literal> causes the slave SQL thread to
        process all transactions occurring before the first GTID in the
        <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable> is reached, and
        <literal>START SLAVE UNTIL SQL_AFTER_GTIDS</literal> causes the
        slave threads to handle all transactions, including those whose
        GTIDs are found in <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>, until
        each has encountered a transaction whose GTID is not part of the
        set. <literal>SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS</literal> and
        <literal>SQL_AFTER_GTIDS</literal> each support the
        <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> and <literal>IO_THREAD</literal>
        options, although using <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> with them
        currently has no effect.

For example, <literal>START SLAVE SQL_THREAD UNTIL
        SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS =
        3E11FA47-71CA-11E1-9E33-C80AA9429562:11-56</literal> causes the
        slave SQL thread to process all transactions originating from
        the master whose <literal role="sysvar">server_uuid</literal> is
        <literal>3E11FA47-71CA-11E1-9E33-C80AA9429562</literal> until it
        encounters the transaction having sequence number 11; it then
        stops without processing this transaction. In other words, all
        transactions up to and including the transaction with sequence
        number 10 are processed. Executing <literal>START SLAVE
        SQL_THREAD UNTIL SQL_AFTER_GTIDS =
        3E11FA47-71CA-11E1-9E33-C80AA9429562:11-56</literal>, on the
        other hand, would cause the slave SQL thread to obtain all
        transactions just mentioned from the master, including all of
        the transactions having the sequence numbers 11 through 56, and
        then to stop without processing any additional transactions;
        that is, the transaction having sequence number 56 would be the
        last transaction fetched by the slave SQL thread.

Prior to MySQL 5.7.3, <literal>SQL_AFTER_GTIDS</literal> did not
        stop the slave once the indicated transaction was completed, but
        waited until another GTID event was received (Bug #14767986).

When using a multithreaded slave, there is a chance of gaps in
        the sequence of transactions that have been executed from the
        relay log in the following cases:

itemizedlist.para: killing the coordinator thread
after an error occurs in the worker threads
<command>mysqld</command> shuts down unexpectedly

description.para:
Use the <literal condition="start-slave" role="stmt">START SLAVE
        UNTIL SQL_AFTER_MTS_GAPS</literal> statement to cause a
        multithreaded slave's worker threads to only run until no
        more gaps are found in the relay log, and then to stop. This
        statement can take an <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> option, but
        the effects of the statement remain unchanged. It has no effect
        on the slave I/O thread (and cannot be used with the
        <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> option).

Issuing <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> on a
        multithreaded slave with gaps in the sequence of transactions
        executed from the relay log generates a warning. In such a
        situation, the solution is to use
        <literal condition="start-slave" role="stmt">START SLAVE UNTIL
        SQL_AFTER_MTS_GAPS</literal>, then issue
        <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> to remove any
        remaining relay logs. See
        <xref linkend="replication-features-transaction-inconsistencies" />
        for more information.

To change a failed multithreaded slave to single-threaded mode,
        you can issue the following series of statements, in the order
        shown:

syntax.programlisting:
>
START SLAVE [<replaceable>thread_types</replaceable>] [<replaceable>until_option</replaceable>] [<replaceable>connection_options</replaceable>] [<replaceable>channel_option</replaceable>]

<replaceable>thread_types</replaceable>:
    [<replaceable>thread_type</replaceable> [, <replaceable>thread_type</replaceable>] ... ]

<replaceable>thread_type</replaceable>:
    IO_THREAD | SQL_THREAD

<replaceable>until_option</replaceable>:
    UNTIL {   {SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS | SQL_AFTER_GTIDS} = <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>
          |   MASTER_LOG_FILE = '<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>', MASTER_LOG_POS = <replaceable>log_pos</replaceable>
          |   RELAY_LOG_FILE = '<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>', RELAY_LOG_POS = <replaceable>log_pos</replaceable>
          |   SQL_AFTER_MTS_GAPS  }

<replaceable>connection_options</replaceable>:
    [USER='<replaceable>user_name</replaceable>'] [PASSWORD='<replaceable>user_pass</replaceable>'] [DEFAULT_AUTH='<replaceable>plugin_name</replaceable>'] [PLUGIN_DIR='<replaceable>plugin_dir</replaceable>']


<replaceable>channel_option</replaceable>:
    FOR CHANNEL <replaceable>channel</replaceable>

<replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>uuid_set</replaceable> [, <replaceable>uuid_set</replaceable>] ...
    | ''

<replaceable>uuid_set</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>uuid</replaceable>:<replaceable>interval</replaceable>[:<replaceable>interval</replaceable>]...

<replaceable>uuid</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>hhhhhhhh</replaceable>-<replaceable>hhhh</replaceable>-<replaceable>hhhh</replaceable>-<replaceable>hhhh</replaceable>-<replaceable>hhhhhhhhhhhh</replaceable>

<replaceable>h</replaceable>:
    [0-9,A-F]

<replaceable>interval</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>n</replaceable>[-<replaceable>n</replaceable>]

    (<replaceable>n</replaceable> >= 1)

description.para:
Stops the slave threads. <literal role="stmt">STOP
        SLAVE</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">REPLICATION_SLAVE_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege. Recommended best
        practice is to execute <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> on the
        slave before stopping the slave server (see
        <xref linkend="server-shutdown" />, for more information).

<emphasis>When using the row-based logging format</emphasis>:
        You should execute <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> or
        <literal>STOP SLAVE SQL_THREAD</literal> on the slave prior to
        shutting down the slave server if you are replicating any tables
        that use a nontransactional storage engine (see the
        <citetitle>Note</citetitle> later in this section).

Like <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal>, this statement
        may be used with the <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> and
        <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> options to name the thread or
        threads to be stopped. Note that the Group Replication applier
        channel (<literal>group_replication_applier</literal>) has no
        I/O thread, only a SQL thread. Using the
        <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> option therefore stops this
        channel completely.

<literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> causes an implicit commit of an
        ongoing transaction. See <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

From MySQL 5.7, <literal role="sysvar">gtid_next</literal> must
        be set to <literal>AUTOMATIC</literal> before issuing this
        statement (Bug #16062608).

From MySQL 5.7, you can control how long <literal>STOP
        SLAVE</literal> waits before timing out by setting the
        <literal role="sysvar">rpl_stop_slave_timeout</literal> system
        variable. This can be used to avoid deadlocks between
        <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> and other slave SQL statements
        using different client connections to the slave. When the
        timeout value is reached, the issuing client returns an error
        message and stops waiting, but the <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal>
        instruction remains in effect. Once the slave threads are no
        longer busy, the <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> statement is
        executed and the slave stops. (Bug #16856735)

Some <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statements are allowed
        while the slave is running, depending on the states of the slave
        SQL and I/O threads. However, using <literal>STOP
        SLAVE</literal> prior to executing <literal>CHANGE MASTER
        TO</literal> in such cases is still supported. See
        <xref linkend="change-master-to" />, and
        <xref linkend="replication-solutions-switch" />, for more
        information.

The optional <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause enables you
        to name which replication channel the statement applies to.
        Providing a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause applies the
        <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> statement to a specific
        replication channel. If no channel is named and no extra
        channels exist, the statement applies to the default channel. If
        a <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> statement does not name a
        channel when using multiple channels, this statement stops the
        specified threads for all channels. This statement cannot be
        used with the <literal>group_replication_recovery</literal>
        channel. See <xref linkend="replication-channels" /> for more
        information.

<emphasis>When using statement-based replication</emphasis>:
        changing the master while it has open temporary tables is
        potentially unsafe. This is one of the reasons why
        statement-based replication of temporary tables is not
        recommended. You can find out whether there are any temporary
        tables on the slave by checking the value of
        <literal role="statvar">Slave_open_temp_tables</literal>; when
        using statement-based replication, this value should be 0 before
        executing <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>. If there are any
        temporary tables open on the slave, issuing a <literal>CHANGE
        MASTER TO</literal> statement after issuing a <literal>STOP
        SLAVE</literal> causes an
        <literal role="error">ER_WARN_OPEN_TEMP_TABLES_MUST_BE_ZERO</literal>
        warning.

When using a multithreaded slave
        (<literal role="sysvar">slave_parallel_workers</literal> is a
        nonzero value), any gaps in the sequence of transactions
        executed from the relay log are closed as part of stopping the
        worker threads. If the slave is stopped unexpectedly (for
        example due to an error in a worker thread, or another thread
        issuing <literal role="stmt">KILL</literal>) while a
        <literal role="stmt">STOP SLAVE</literal> statement is
        executing, the sequence of executed transactions from the relay
        log may become inconsistent. See
        <xref linkend="replication-features-transaction-inconsistencies" />,
        for more information.

If the current replication event group has modified one or more
        nontransactional tables, STOP SLAVE waits for up to 60 seconds
        for the event group to complete, unless you issue a
        <literal condition="kill" role="stmt">KILL QUERY</literal> or
        <literal condition="kill" role="stmt">KILL CONNECTION</literal>
        statement for the slave SQL thread. If the event group remains
        incomplete after the timeout, an error message is logged.

syntax.programlisting:
>
STOP SLAVE [<replaceable>thread_types</replaceable>] [<replaceable>channel_option</replaceable>]

<replaceable>thread_types</replaceable>:
    [<replaceable>thread_type</replaceable> [, <replaceable>thread_type</replaceable>] ... ]

<replaceable>thread_type</replaceable>: IO_THREAD | SQL_THREAD

<replaceable>channel_option</replaceable>:
    FOR CHANNEL <replaceable>channel</replaceable>

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">ALTER USER</literal> statement modifies
        MySQL accounts. It enables authentication, SSL/TLS,
        resource-limit, and password-management properties to be
        modified for existing accounts. It can also be used to lock and
        unlock accounts.

To use <literal role="stmt">ALTER USER</literal>, you must have
        the global <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal> privilege
        or the <literal role="priv">UPDATE</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system database. When the
        <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system variable is
        enabled, <literal role="stmt">ALTER USER</literal> additionally
        requires the <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

By default, an error occurs if you try to modify a user that
        does not exist. If the <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> clause is
        given, the statement produces a warning for each named user that
        does not exist, rather than an error.

syntax.programlisting:
>
ALTER USER [IF EXISTS]
    <replaceable>user</replaceable> [<replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>] [, <replaceable>user</replaceable> [<replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>]] ...
    [REQUIRE {NONE | <replaceable>tls_option</replaceable> [[AND] <replaceable>tls_option</replaceable>] ...}]
    [WITH <replaceable>resource_option</replaceable> [<replaceable>resource_option</replaceable>] ...]
    [<replaceable>password_option</replaceable> | <replaceable>lock_option</replaceable>] ...

ALTER USER [IF EXISTS]
    USER() IDENTIFIED BY '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'

<replaceable>user</replaceable>:
    (see <xref linkend="account-names" />)

<replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>: {
    IDENTIFIED BY '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
  | IDENTIFIED WITH <replaceable>auth_plugin</replaceable>
  | IDENTIFIED WITH <replaceable>auth_plugin</replaceable> BY '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
  | IDENTIFIED WITH <replaceable>auth_plugin</replaceable> AS '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
}

<replaceable>tls_option</replaceable>: {
   SSL
 | X509
 | CIPHER '<replaceable>cipher</replaceable>'
 | ISSUER '<replaceable>issuer</replaceable>'
 | SUBJECT '<replaceable>subject</replaceable>'
}

<replaceable>resource_option</replaceable>: {
    MAX_QUERIES_PER_HOUR <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MAX_UPDATES_PER_HOUR <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MAX_CONNECTIONS_PER_HOUR <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MAX_USER_CONNECTIONS <replaceable>count</replaceable>
}

<replaceable>password_option</replaceable>: {
    PASSWORD EXPIRE
  | PASSWORD EXPIRE DEFAULT
  | PASSWORD EXPIRE NEVER
  | PASSWORD EXPIRE INTERVAL <replaceable>N</replaceable> DAY
}

<replaceable>lock_option</replaceable>: {
    ACCOUNT LOCK
  | ACCOUNT UNLOCK
}

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">CREATE USER</literal> statement creates
        new MySQL accounts. It enables authentication, SSL/TLS,
        resource-limit, and password-management properties to be
        established for new accounts, and controls whether accounts are
        initially locked or unlocked.

To use <literal role="stmt">CREATE USER</literal>, you must have
        the global <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal> privilege,
        or the <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system database. When the
        <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system variable is
        enabled, <literal role="stmt">CREATE USER</literal> additionally
        requires the <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

An error occurs if you try to create an account that already
        exists. If the <literal>IF NOT EXISTS</literal> clause is given,
        the statement produces a warning for each named account that
        already exists, rather than an error.

syntax.programlisting:
>
CREATE USER [IF NOT EXISTS]
    <replaceable>user</replaceable> [<replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>] [, <replaceable>user</replaceable> [<replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>]] ...
    [REQUIRE {NONE | <replaceable>tls_option</replaceable> [[AND] <replaceable>tls_option</replaceable>] ...}]
    [WITH <replaceable>resource_option</replaceable> [<replaceable>resource_option</replaceable>] ...]
    [<replaceable>password_option</replaceable> | <replaceable>lock_option</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>user</replaceable>:
    (see <xref linkend="account-names" />)

<replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>: {
    IDENTIFIED BY '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
  | IDENTIFIED WITH <replaceable>auth_plugin</replaceable>
  | IDENTIFIED WITH <replaceable>auth_plugin</replaceable> BY '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
  | IDENTIFIED WITH <replaceable>auth_plugin</replaceable> AS '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
  | IDENTIFIED BY PASSWORD '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
}

<replaceable>tls_option</replaceable>: {
   SSL
 | X509
 | CIPHER '<replaceable>cipher</replaceable>'
 | ISSUER '<replaceable>issuer</replaceable>'
 | SUBJECT '<replaceable>subject</replaceable>'
}

<replaceable>resource_option</replaceable>: {
    MAX_QUERIES_PER_HOUR <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MAX_UPDATES_PER_HOUR <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MAX_CONNECTIONS_PER_HOUR <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MAX_USER_CONNECTIONS <replaceable>count</replaceable>
}

<replaceable>password_option</replaceable>: {
    PASSWORD EXPIRE
  | PASSWORD EXPIRE DEFAULT
  | PASSWORD EXPIRE NEVER
  | PASSWORD EXPIRE INTERVAL <replaceable>N</replaceable> DAY
}

<replaceable>lock_option</replaceable>: {
    ACCOUNT LOCK
  | ACCOUNT UNLOCK
}

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">DROP USER</literal> statement removes
        one or more MySQL accounts and their privileges. It removes
        privilege rows for the account from all grant tables.

To use <literal role="stmt">DROP USER</literal>, you must have
        the global <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal> privilege,
        or the <literal role="priv">DELETE</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system database. When the
        <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system variable is
        enabled, <literal role="stmt">DROP USER</literal> additionally
        requires the <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

An error occurs if you try to drop an account that does not
        exist. If the <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> clause is given, the
        statement produces a warning for each named user that does not
        exist, rather than an error.

Each account name uses the format described in
        <xref linkend="account-names" />. For example:

description.programlisting:
>
DROP USER 'jeffrey'@'localhost';

description.para:
The host name part of the account name, if omitted, defaults to
        <literal>'%'</literal>.

syntax.programlisting:
>
GRANT
    <replaceable>priv_type</replaceable> [(<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>)]
      [, <replaceable>priv_type</replaceable> [(<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>)]] ...
    ON [<replaceable>object_type</replaceable>] <replaceable>priv_level</replaceable>
    TO <replaceable>user</replaceable> [<replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>] [, <replaceable>user</replaceable> [<replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>]] ...
    [REQUIRE {NONE | <replaceable>tls_option</replaceable> [[AND] <replaceable>tls_option</replaceable>] ...}]
    [WITH {GRANT OPTION | <replaceable>resource_option</replaceable>} ...]

GRANT PROXY ON <replaceable>user</replaceable>
    TO <replaceable>user</replaceable> [, <replaceable>user</replaceable>] ...
    [WITH GRANT OPTION]

<replaceable>object_type</replaceable>: {
    TABLE
  | FUNCTION
  | PROCEDURE
}

<replaceable>priv_level</replaceable>: {
    *
  | *.*
  | <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>.*
  | <replaceable>db_name.tbl_name</replaceable>
  | <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
  | <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>.<replaceable>routine_name</replaceable>
}

<replaceable>user</replaceable>:
    (see <xref linkend="account-names" />)

<replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>: {
    IDENTIFIED BY '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
  | IDENTIFIED WITH <replaceable>auth_plugin</replaceable>
  | IDENTIFIED WITH <replaceable>auth_plugin</replaceable> BY '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
  | IDENTIFIED WITH <replaceable>auth_plugin</replaceable> AS '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
  | IDENTIFIED BY PASSWORD '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
}

<replaceable>tls_option</replaceable>: {
    SSL
  | X509
  | CIPHER '<replaceable>cipher</replaceable>'
  | ISSUER '<replaceable>issuer</replaceable>'
  | SUBJECT '<replaceable>subject</replaceable>'
}

<replaceable>resource_option</replaceable>: {
  | MAX_QUERIES_PER_HOUR <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MAX_UPDATES_PER_HOUR <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MAX_CONNECTIONS_PER_HOUR <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MAX_USER_CONNECTIONS <replaceable>count</replaceable>
}

syntax.para:
The <literal role="stmt">GRANT</literal> statement grants
        privileges to MySQL user accounts. There are several aspects to
        the <literal role="stmt">GRANT</literal> statement, described
        under the following topics:

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">RENAME USER</literal> statement renames
        existing MySQL accounts. An error occurs for old accounts that
        do not exist or new accounts that already exist.

To use <literal role="stmt">RENAME USER</literal>, you must have
        the global <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal> privilege,
        or the <literal role="priv">UPDATE</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system database. When the
        <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system variable is
        enabled, <literal role="stmt">RENAME USER</literal> additionally
        requires the <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

Each account name uses the format described in
        <xref linkend="account-names" />. For example:

description.programlisting:
>
RENAME USER 'jeffrey'@'localhost' TO 'jeff'@'127.0.0.1';

description.para:
The host name part of the account name, if omitted, defaults to
        <literal>'%'</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">RENAME USER</literal> causes the privileges
        held by the old user to be those held by the new user. However,
        <literal role="stmt">RENAME USER</literal> does not
        automatically drop or invalidate databases or objects within
        them that the old user created. This includes stored programs or
        views for which the <literal>DEFINER</literal> attribute names
        the old user. Attempts to access such objects may produce an
        error if they execute in definer security context. (For
        information about security context, see
        <xref linkend="stored-objects-security" />.)

The privilege changes take effect as indicated in
        <xref linkend="privilege-changes" />.

The <literal role="stmt">REVOKE</literal> statement enables
        system administrators to revoke privileges from MySQL accounts.

For details on the levels at which privileges exist, the
        permissible <replaceable>priv_type</replaceable>,
        <replaceable>priv_level</replaceable>, and
        <replaceable>object_type</replaceable> values, and the syntax
        for specifying users and passwords, see <xref linkend="grant" />.

When the <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system
        variable is enabled, <literal role="stmt">REVOKE</literal>
        requires the <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege in
        addition to any other required privileges described in the
        following discussion.

Each account name uses the format described in
        <xref linkend="account-names" />. For example:

description.programlisting:
>
REVOKE INSERT ON *.* FROM 'jeffrey'@'localhost';

description.para:
The host name part of the account name, if omitted, defaults to
        <literal>'%'</literal>.

To use the first <literal role="stmt">REVOKE</literal> syntax,
        you must have the <literal role="priv">GRANT OPTION</literal>
        privilege, and you must have the privileges that you are
        revoking.

To revoke all privileges, use the second syntax, which drops all
        global, database, table, column, and routine privileges for the
        named user or users:

description.programlisting:
>
REVOKE ALL PRIVILEGES, GRANT OPTION FROM <replaceable>user</replaceable> [, <replaceable>user</replaceable>] ...

description.para:
To use this <literal role="stmt">REVOKE</literal> syntax, you
        must have the global <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal>
        privilege, or the <literal role="priv">UPDATE</literal>
        privilege for the <literal>mysql</literal> system database.

User accounts from which privileges are to be revoked must
        exist, but the privileges to be revoked need not be currently
        granted to them.

syntax.programlisting:
>
REVOKE
    <replaceable>priv_type</replaceable> [(<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>)]
      [, <replaceable>priv_type</replaceable> [(<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>)]] ...
    ON [<replaceable>object_type</replaceable>] <replaceable>priv_level</replaceable>
    FROM <replaceable>user</replaceable> [, <replaceable>user</replaceable>] ...

REVOKE ALL [PRIVILEGES], GRANT OPTION
    FROM <replaceable>user</replaceable> [, <replaceable>user</replaceable>] ...

REVOKE PROXY ON <replaceable>user</replaceable>
    FROM <replaceable>user</replaceable> [, <replaceable>user</replaceable>] ...

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">SET PASSWORD</literal> statement
        assigns a password to a MySQL user account.
        <literal>'<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'</literal>
        represents a cleartext (unencrypted) password.

<literal role="stmt">SET PASSWORD</literal> can be used with or
        without a <literal>FOR</literal> clause that explicitly names a
        user account:

itemizedlist.para:
With a <literal>FOR
            <replaceable>user</replaceable></literal> clause, the
            statement sets the password for the named account, which
            must exist:

With no <literal>FOR
            <replaceable>user</replaceable></literal> clause, the
            statement sets the password for the current user:

Any client who connects to the server using a nonanonymous
            account can change the password for that account. (In
            particular, you can change your own password.) To see which
            account the server authenticated you as, invoke the
            <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER()</literal> function:

description.para:
If a <literal>FOR <replaceable>user</replaceable></literal>
        clause is given, the account name uses the format described in
        <xref linkend="account-names" />. For example:

description.programlisting:
>
SET PASSWORD FOR 'bob'@'%.example.org' = '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>';

description.para:
The host name part of the account name, if omitted, defaults to
        <literal>'%'</literal>.

Setting the password for a named account (with a
        <literal>FOR</literal> clause) requires the
        <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system database. Setting the password
        for yourself (for a nonanonymous account with no
        <literal>FOR</literal> clause) requires no special privileges.
        When the <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system
        variable is enabled, <literal role="stmt">SET PASSWORD</literal>
        requires the <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege in
        addition to any other required privileges.
The password can be specified in these ways:

itemizedlist.para:
Use a string without
            <literal role="func">PASSWORD()</literal>

<literal role="stmt">SET PASSWORD</literal> interprets the
            string as a cleartext string, passes it to the
            authentication plugin associated with the account, and
            stores the result returned by the plugin in the account row
            in the <literal>mysql.user</literal> system table. (The
            plugin is given the opportunity to hash the value into the
            encryption format it expects. The plugin may use the value
            as specified, in which case no hashing occurs.)

Use the <literal role="func">PASSWORD()</literal> function
            (deprecated as of MySQL 5.7.6)

The <literal role="func">PASSWORD()</literal> argument is
            the cleartext (unencrypted) password.
            <literal role="func">PASSWORD()</literal> hashes the
            password and returns the encrypted password string for
            storage in the account row in the
            <literal>mysql.user</literal> system table.

The <literal role="func">PASSWORD()</literal> function
            hashes the password using the hashing method determined by
            the value of the
            <literal role="sysvar">old_passwords</literal> system
            variable value. Be sure that
            <literal role="sysvar">old_passwords</literal> has the value
            corresponding to the hashing method expected by the
            authentication plugin associated with the account. For
            example, if the account uses the
            <literal>mysql_native_password</literal> plugin, the
            <literal role="sysvar">old_passwords</literal> value must be
            0:

If the <literal role="sysvar">old_passwords</literal> value
            differs from that required by the authentication plugin, the
            hashed password value returned by
            <literal role="func">PASSWORD()</literal> will not by usable
            by the plugin and correct authentication of client
            connections will not occur.

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> performs a key
        distribution analysis and stores the distribution for the named
        table or tables. For <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables, this
        statement is equivalent to using <command>myisamchk
        --analyze</command>.

This statement requires <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal>
        and <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privileges for the
        table.

<literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> works with
        <literal>InnoDB</literal>, <literal>NDB</literal>, and
        <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables. It does not work with views.

<literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> is supported for
        partitioned tables, and you can use <literal>ALTER TABLE ...
        ANALYZE PARTITION</literal> to analyze one or more partitions;
        for more information, see <xref linkend="alter-table" />, and
        <xref linkend="partitioning-maintenance" />.

During the analysis, the table is locked with a read lock for
        <literal>InnoDB</literal> and <literal>MyISAM</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> removes the table
        from the table definition cache, which requires a flush lock. If
        there are long running statements or transactions still using
        the table, subsequent statements and transactions must wait for
        those operations to finish before the flush lock is released.
        Because <literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> itself
        typically finishes quickly, it may not be apparent that delayed
        transactions or statements involving the same table are due to
        the remaining flush lock.

By default, the server writes <literal role="stmt">ANALYZE
        TABLE</literal> statements to the binary log so that they
        replicate to replication slaves. To suppress logging, specify
        the optional <literal>NO_WRITE_TO_BINLOG</literal> keyword or
        its alias <literal>LOCAL</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">CHECK TABLE</literal> checks a table or
        tables for errors. For <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables, the key
        statistics are updated as well. <literal role="stmt">CHECK
        TABLE</literal> can also check views for problems, such as
        tables that are referenced in the view definition that no longer
        exist.
To check a table, you must have some privilege for it.

<literal role="stmt">CHECK TABLE</literal> works for
        <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal>,
        <literal role="se">MyISAM</literal>,
        <literal role="se">ARCHIVE</literal>, and
        <literal role="se">CSV</literal> tables.

Before running <literal role="stmt">CHECK TABLE</literal> on
        <literal>InnoDB</literal> tables, see
        <xref linkend="check-table-innodb" />.

<literal role="stmt">CHECK TABLE</literal> is supported for
        partitioned tables, and you can use <literal>ALTER TABLE ...
        CHECK PARTITION</literal> to check one or more partitions; for
        more information, see <xref linkend="alter-table" />, and
        <xref linkend="partitioning-maintenance" />.

<literal role="stmt">CHECK TABLE</literal> ignores virtual
        generated columns that are not indexed.

syntax.programlisting:
>
CHECK TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>] ... [<replaceable>option</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>option</replaceable>: {
    FOR UPGRADE
  | QUICK
  | FAST
  | MEDIUM
  | EXTENDED
  | CHANGED
}

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">CHECKSUM TABLE</literal> reports a
        <link linkend="glos_checksum">checksum</link> for the contents
        of a table. You can use this statement to verify that the
        contents are the same before and after a backup, rollback, or
        other operation that is intended to put the data back to a known
        state.

This statement requires the
        <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege for the table.

This statement is not supported for views. If you run
        <literal role="stmt">CHECKSUM TABLE</literal> against a view,
        the <literal>Checksum</literal> value is always
        <literal>NULL</literal>, and a warning is returned.

For a nonexistent table, <literal role="stmt">CHECKSUM
        TABLE</literal> returns <literal>NULL</literal> and generates a
        warning.

During the checksum operation, the table is locked with a read
        lock for <literal>InnoDB</literal> and
        <literal>MyISAM</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> reorganizes the
        physical storage of table data and associated index data, to
        reduce storage space and improve I/O efficiency when accessing
        the table. The exact changes made to each table depend on the
        <link linkend="glos_storage_engine">storage engine</link> used
        by that table.

Use <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> in these
        cases, depending on the type of table:

itemizedlist.para:
After doing substantial insert, update, or delete operations
            on an <literal>InnoDB</literal> table that has its own
            <link linkend="glos_ibd_file">.ibd file</link> because it
            was created with the
            <literal role="sysvar">innodb_file_per_table</literal>
            option enabled. The table and indexes are reorganized, and
            disk space can be reclaimed for use by the operating system.

After doing substantial insert, update, or delete operations
            on columns that are part of a <literal>FULLTEXT</literal>
            index in an <literal>InnoDB</literal> table. Set the
            configuration option
            <literal role="sysvar">innodb_optimize_fulltext_only=1</literal>
            first. To keep the index maintenance period to a reasonable
            time, set the
            <literal role="sysvar">innodb_ft_num_word_optimize</literal>
            option to specify how many words to update in the search
            index, and run a sequence of <literal>OPTIMIZE
            TABLE</literal> statements until the search index is fully
            updated.

After deleting a large part of a <literal>MyISAM</literal>
            or <literal>ARCHIVE</literal> table, or making many changes
            to a <literal>MyISAM</literal> or <literal>ARCHIVE
            </literal>table with variable-length rows (tables that have
            <literal role="type">VARCHAR</literal>,
            <literal role="type">VARBINARY</literal>,
            <literal role="type">BLOB</literal>, or
            <literal role="type">TEXT</literal> columns). Deleted rows
            are maintained in a linked list and subsequent
            <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> operations reuse old
            row positions. You can use <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE
            TABLE</literal> to reclaim the unused space and to
            defragment the data file. After extensive changes to a
            table, this statement may also improve performance of
            statements that use the table, sometimes significantly.

description.para:
This statement requires <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal>
        and <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privileges for the
        table.

<literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> works for
        <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal>,
        <literal role="se">MyISAM</literal>, and
        <literal role="se">ARCHIVE</literal> tables.
        <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> is also supported
        for dynamic columns of in-memory
        <literal role="se">NDB</literal> tables. It does not work for
        fixed-width columns of in-memory tables, nor does it work for
        Disk Data tables. The performance of <literal>OPTIMIZE</literal>
        on NDB Cluster tables can be tuned using
        <option role="mysqld">--ndb-optimization-delay</option>, which
        controls the length of time to wait between processing batches
        of rows by <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal>. For
        more information, see
        <xref linkend="mysql-cluster-limitations-resolved" />.

For NDB Cluster tables, <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE
        TABLE</literal> can be interrupted by (for example) killing the
        SQL thread performing the <literal>OPTIMIZE</literal> operation.

By default, <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> does
        <emphasis>not</emphasis> work for tables created using any other
        storage engine and returns a result indicating this lack of
        support. You can make <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE
        TABLE</literal> work for other storage engines by starting
        <command>mysqld</command> with the
        <option role="mysqld">--skip-new</option> option. In this case,
        <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> is just mapped to
        <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal>.
This statement does not work with views.

<literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> is supported for
        partitioned tables. For information about using this statement
        with partitioned tables and table partitions, see
        <xref linkend="partitioning-maintenance" />.

By default, the server writes <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE
        TABLE</literal> statements to the binary log so that they
        replicate to replication slaves. To suppress logging, specify
        the optional <literal>NO_WRITE_TO_BINLOG</literal> keyword or
        its alias <literal>LOCAL</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">REPAIR TABLE</literal> repairs a possibly
        corrupted table, for certain storage engines only.

This statement requires <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal>
        and <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privileges for the
        table.

Although normally you should never have to run
        <literal role="stmt">REPAIR TABLE</literal>, if disaster
        strikes, this statement is very likely to get back all your data
        from a <literal>MyISAM</literal> table. If your tables become
        corrupted often, try to find the reason for it, to eliminate the
        need to use <literal role="stmt">REPAIR TABLE</literal>. See
        <xref linkend="crashing" />, and
        <xref linkend="myisam-table-problems" />.

<literal role="stmt">REPAIR TABLE</literal> checks the table to
        see whether an upgrade is required. If so, it performs the
        upgrade, following the same rules as
        <literal condition="check-table" role="stmt">CHECK TABLE ... FOR
        UPGRADE</literal>. See <xref linkend="check-table" />, for more
        information.

A user-defined function (UDF) is a way to extend MySQL with a
        new function that works like a native (built-in) MySQL function
        such as <literal role="func">ABS()</literal> or
        <literal role="func">CONCAT()</literal>.

<replaceable>function_name</replaceable> is the name that should
        be used in SQL statements to invoke the function. The
        <literal>RETURNS</literal> clause indicates the type of the
        function's return value. <literal role="type">DECIMAL</literal>
        is a legal value after <literal>RETURNS</literal>, but currently
        <literal role="type">DECIMAL</literal> functions return string
        values and should be written like <literal>STRING</literal>
        functions.

<replaceable>shared_library_name</replaceable> is the base name
        of the shared library file that contains the code that
        implements the function. The file must be located in the plugin
        directory. This directory is given by the value of the
        <literal role="sysvar">plugin_dir</literal> system variable. For
        more information, see <xref linkend="udf-loading" />.

To create a function, you must have the
        <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system database. This is necessary
        because <literal role="stmt">CREATE FUNCTION</literal> adds a
        row to the <literal>mysql.func</literal> system table that
        records the function's name, type, and shared library name.

This statement drops the user-defined function (UDF) named
        <replaceable>function_name</replaceable>.

To drop a function, you must have the
        <literal role="priv">DELETE</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system database. This is because
        <literal role="stmt">DROP FUNCTION</literal> removes a row from
        the <literal>mysql.func</literal> system table that records the
        function's name, type, and shared library name.

This statement installs a server plugin. It requires the
        <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql.plugin</literal> system table.

<replaceable>plugin_name</replaceable> is the name of the plugin
        as defined in the plugin descriptor structure contained in the
        library file (see <xref linkend="plugin-data-structures" />).
        Plugin names are not case-sensitive. For maximal compatibility,
        plugin names should be limited to ASCII letters, digits, and
        underscore because they are used in C source files, shell
        command lines, M4 and Bourne shell scripts, and SQL
        environments.

<replaceable>shared_library_name</replaceable> is the name of
        the shared library that contains the plugin code. The name
        includes the file name extension (for example,
        <filename>libmyplugin.so</filename>,
        <filename>libmyplugin.dll</filename>, or
        <filename>libmyplugin.dylib</filename>).

The shared library must be located in the plugin directory (the
        directory named by the
        <literal role="sysvar">plugin_dir</literal> system variable).
        The library must be in the plugin directory itself, not in a
        subdirectory. By default,
        <literal role="sysvar">plugin_dir</literal> is the
        <filename>plugin</filename> directory under the directory named
        by the <literal>pkglibdir</literal> configuration variable, but
        it can be changed by setting the value of
        <literal role="sysvar">plugin_dir</literal> at server startup.
        For example, set its value in a <filename>my.cnf</filename>
        file:

description.programlisting:
>
[mysqld]
plugin_dir=<replaceable>/path/to/plugin/directory</replaceable>

description.para:
If the value of <literal role="sysvar">plugin_dir</literal> is a
        relative path name, it is taken to be relative to the MySQL base
        directory (the value of the
        <literal role="sysvar">basedir</literal> system variable).

<literal role="stmt">INSTALL PLUGIN</literal> loads and
        initializes the plugin code to make the plugin available for
        use. A plugin is initialized by executing its initialization
        function, which handles any setup that the plugin must perform
        before it can be used. When the server shuts down, it executes
        the deinitialization function for each plugin that is loaded so
        that the plugin has a chance to perform any final cleanup.

<literal role="stmt">INSTALL PLUGIN</literal> also registers the
        plugin by adding a line that indicates the plugin name and
        library file name to the <literal>mysql.plugin</literal> system
        table. At server startup, the server loads and initializes any
        plugin that is listed in <literal>mysql.plugin</literal>. This
        means that a plugin is installed with
        <literal role="stmt">INSTALL PLUGIN</literal> only once, not
        every time the server starts. Plugin loading at startup does not
        occur if the server is started with the
        <option role="mysqld">--skip-grant-tables</option> option.

A plugin library can contain multiple plugins. For each of them
        to be installed, use a separate <literal role="stmt">INSTALL
        PLUGIN</literal> statement. Each statement names a different
        plugin, but all of them specify the same library name.

This statement removes an installed server plugin. It requires
        the <literal role="priv">DELETE</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql.plugin</literal> system table.
        <literal role="stmt">UNINSTALL PLUGIN</literal> is the
        complement of <literal role="stmt">INSTALL PLUGIN</literal>.

<replaceable>plugin_name</replaceable> must be the name of some
        plugin that is listed in the <literal>mysql.plugin</literal>
        table. The server executes the plugin's deinitialization
        function and removes the row for the plugin from the
        <literal>mysql.plugin</literal> system table, so that subsequent
        server restarts will not load and initialize the plugin.
        <literal role="stmt">UNINSTALL PLUGIN</literal> does not remove
        the plugin's shared library file.

<literal condition="set-variable" role="stmt">SET</literal>
        syntax for variable assignment enables you to assign values to
        different types of variables that affect the operation of the
        server or clients:

itemizedlist.para:
User-defined variables. See
            <xref linkend="user-variables" />.

Stored procedure and function parameters, and stored program
            local variables. See
            <xref linkend="stored-program-variables" />.

System variables. See
            <xref linkend="server-system-variables" />. System variables
            also can be set at server startup, as described in
            <xref linkend="using-system-variables" />.

description.para:
This statement maps all strings sent between the server and the
        current client with the given mapping. <literal>SET CHARACTER
        SET</literal> sets three session system variables:
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_client</literal> and
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_results</literal> are set
        to the given character set, and
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_connection</literal> to the
        value of
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_database</literal>. See
        <xref linkend="charset-connection" />.

<replaceable>charset_name</replaceable> may be quoted or
        unquoted.

The default character set mapping can be restored by using the
        value <literal>DEFAULT</literal>. The default depends on the
        server configuration.

Some character sets cannot be used as the client character set.
        Attempting to use them with <literal role="stmt">SET CHARACTER
        SET</literal> produces an error. See
        <xref linkend="charset-connection-impermissible-client-charset" />.

This statement sets the three session system variables
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_client</literal>,
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_connection</literal>, and
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_results</literal> to the
        given character set. Setting
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_connection</literal> to
        <literal>charset_name</literal> also sets
        <literal role="sysvar">collation_connection</literal> to the
        default collation for <literal>charset_name</literal>. See
        <xref linkend="charset-connection" />.

The optional <literal>COLLATE</literal> clause may be used to
        specify a collation explicitly. If given, the collation must one
        of the permitted collations for
        <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>.

<replaceable>charset_name</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable> may be quoted or
        unquoted.

The default mapping can be restored by using a value of
        <literal>DEFAULT</literal>. The default depends on the server
        configuration.

Some character sets cannot be used as the client character set.
        Attempting to use them with <literal role="stmt">SET
        NAMES</literal> produces an error. See
        <xref linkend="charset-connection-impermissible-client-charset" />.

Lists the binary log files on the server. This statement is used
        as part of the procedure described in
        <xref linkend="purge-binary-logs" />, that shows how to determine
        which logs can be purged. A user with the
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">REPLICATION CLIENT</literal> privilege may
        execute this statement.

syntax.programlisting:
>
SHOW BINARY LOGS
SHOW MASTER LOGS

description.para:
Shows the events in the binary log. If you do not specify
        <literal>'<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>'</literal>, the
        first binary log is displayed. <literal role="stmt">SHOW BINLOG
        EVENTS</literal> requires the <literal role="priv">REPLICATION
        SLAVE</literal> privilege.

The <literal role="stmt">SHOW CHARACTER SET</literal> statement
        shows all available character sets. The
        <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if present, indicates
        which character set names to match. The <literal>WHERE</literal>
        clause can be given to select rows using more general
        conditions, as discussed in <xref linkend="extended-show" />. For
        example:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW CHARACTER SET LIKE 'latin%';</userinput>
+---------+-----------------------------+-------------------+--------+
| Charset | Description                 | Default collation | Maxlen |
+---------+-----------------------------+-------------------+--------+
| latin1  | cp1252 West European        | latin1_swedish_ci |      1 |
| latin2  | ISO 8859-2 Central European | latin2_general_ci |      1 |
| latin5  | ISO 8859-9 Turkish          | latin5_turkish_ci |      1 |
| latin7  | ISO 8859-13 Baltic          | latin7_general_ci |      1 |
+---------+-----------------------------+-------------------+--------+

description.para:
This statement lists collations supported by the server. By
        default, the output from <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        COLLATION</literal> includes all available collations. The
        <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if present, indicates
        which collation names to match. The <literal>WHERE</literal>
        clause can be given to select rows using more general
        conditions, as discussed in <xref linkend="extended-show" />. For
        example:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW COLLATION WHERE Charset = 'latin1';</userinput>
+-------------------+---------+----+---------+----------+---------+
| Collation         | Charset | Id | Default | Compiled | Sortlen |
+-------------------+---------+----+---------+----------+---------+
| latin1_german1_ci | latin1  |  5 |         | Yes      |       1 |
| latin1_swedish_ci | latin1  |  8 | Yes     | Yes      |       1 |
| latin1_danish_ci  | latin1  | 15 |         | Yes      |       1 |
| latin1_german2_ci | latin1  | 31 |         | Yes      |       2 |
| latin1_bin        | latin1  | 47 |         | Yes      |       1 |
| latin1_general_ci | latin1  | 48 |         | Yes      |       1 |
| latin1_general_cs | latin1  | 49 |         | Yes      |       1 |
| latin1_spanish_ci | latin1  | 94 |         | Yes      |       1 |
+-------------------+---------+----+---------+----------+---------+

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">SHOW COLUMNS</literal> displays information
        about the columns in a given table. It also works for views.
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW COLUMNS</literal> displays information
        only for those columns for which you have some privilege.

An alternative to <literal><replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
        FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable></literal> syntax is
        <replaceable>db_name.tbl_name</replaceable>. These two
        statements are equivalent:

The optional <literal>FULL</literal> keyword causes the output
        to include the column collation and comments, as well as the
        privileges you have for each column.

The <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if present,
        indicates which column names to match. The
        <literal>WHERE</literal> clause can be given to select rows
        using more general conditions, as discussed in
        <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

The data types may differ from what you expect them to be based
        on a <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal> statement
        because MySQL sometimes changes data types when you create or
        alter a table. The conditions under which this occurs are
        described in <xref linkend="silent-column-changes" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW COLUMNS</literal> displays the
        following values for each table column:

itemizedlist.para: <literal>Field</literal>
The column name.
<literal>Type</literal>
The column data type.
<literal>Collation</literal>

The collation for nonbinary string columns, or
            <literal>NULL</literal> for other columns. This value is
            displayed only if you use the <literal>FULL</literal>
            keyword.
<literal>Null</literal>

The column nullability. The value is <literal>YES</literal>
            if <literal>NULL</literal> values can be stored in the
            column, <literal>NO</literal> if not.
<literal>Key</literal>
Whether the column is indexed:

If <literal>Key</literal> is empty, the column either is
                not indexed or is indexed only as a secondary column in
                a multiple-column, nonunique index.

If <literal>Key</literal> is <literal>PRI</literal>, the
                column is a <literal>PRIMARY KEY</literal> or is one of
                the columns in a multiple-column <literal>PRIMARY
                KEY</literal>.

If <literal>Key</literal> is <literal>UNI</literal>, the
                column is the first column of a
                <literal>UNIQUE</literal> index. (A
                <literal>UNIQUE</literal> index permits multiple
                <literal>NULL</literal> values, but you can tell whether
                the column permits <literal>NULL</literal> by checking
                the <literal>Null</literal> field.)

If <literal>Key</literal> is <literal>MUL</literal>, the
                column is the first column of a nonunique index in which
                multiple occurrences of a given value are permitted
                within the column.

If more than one of the <literal>Key</literal> values
            applies to a given column of a table, <literal>Key</literal>
            displays the one with the highest priority, in the order
            <literal>PRI</literal>, <literal>UNI</literal>,
            <literal>MUL</literal>.

A <literal>UNIQUE</literal> index may be displayed as
            <literal>PRI</literal> if it cannot contain
            <literal>NULL</literal> values and there is no
            <literal>PRIMARY KEY</literal> in the table. A
            <literal>UNIQUE</literal> index may display as
            <literal>MUL</literal> if several columns form a composite
            <literal>UNIQUE</literal> index; although the combination of
            the columns is unique, each column can still hold multiple
            occurrences of a given value.
<literal>Default</literal>

The default value for the column. This is
            <literal>NULL</literal> if the column has an explicit
            default of <literal>NULL</literal>, or if the column
            definition includes no <literal>DEFAULT</literal> clause.
<literal>Extra</literal>

Any additional information that is available about a given
            column. The value is nonempty in these cases:

<literal>auto_increment</literal> for columns that have
                the <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> attribute.

<literal>on update CURRENT_TIMESTAMP</literal> for
                <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> or
                <literal role="type">DATETIME</literal> columns that
                have the <literal>ON UPDATE CURRENT_TIMESTAMP</literal>
                attribute.

<literal>VIRTUAL GENERATED</literal> or <literal>VIRTUAL
                STORED</literal> for generated columns.
<literal>Privileges</literal>

The privileges you have for the column. This value is
            displayed only if you use the <literal>FULL</literal>
            keyword.
<literal>Comment</literal>

Any comment included in the column definition. This value is
            displayed only if you use the <literal>FULL</literal>
            keyword.

description.para:
Table column information is also available from the
        <literal>INFORMATION_SCHEMA</literal>
        <literal role="is">COLUMNS</literal> table. See
        <xref linkend="columns-table" />.

You can list a table's columns with the <command>mysqlshow
        <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>
        <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable></command> command.

The <literal role="stmt">DESCRIBE</literal> statement provides
        information similar to <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        COLUMNS</literal>. See <xref linkend="describe" />.

The <literal role="stmt">SHOW CREATE TABLE</literal>,
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW TABLE STATUS</literal>, and
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW INDEX</literal> statements also
        provide information about tables. See <xref linkend="show" />.

Shows the <literal role="stmt">CREATE DATABASE</literal>
        statement that creates the named database. If the
        <literal>SHOW</literal> statement includes an <literal>IF NOT
        EXISTS</literal> clause, the output too includes such a clause.
        <literal condition="show-create-database" role="stmt">SHOW
        CREATE SCHEMA</literal> is a synonym for
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW CREATE DATABASE</literal>.

This statement displays the <literal role="stmt">CREATE
        EVENT</literal> statement needed to re-create a given event. It
        requires the <literal role="priv">EVENT</literal> privilege for
        the database from which the event is to be shown. For example
        (using the same event <literal>e_daily</literal> defined and
        then altered in <xref linkend="show-events" />):

This statement is similar to <literal role="stmt">SHOW CREATE
        PROCEDURE</literal> but for stored functions. See
        <xref linkend="show-create-procedure" />.

This statement is a MySQL extension. It returns the exact string
        that can be used to re-create the named stored procedure. A
        similar statement, <literal role="stmt">SHOW CREATE
        FUNCTION</literal>, displays information about stored functions
        (see <xref linkend="show-create-function" />).

To use either statement, you must be the user named in the
        routine <literal>DEFINER</literal> clause or have
        <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> access to the
        <literal>mysql.proc</literal> table. If you do not have
        privileges for the routine itself, the value displayed for the
        <literal>Create Procedure</literal> or <literal>Create
        Function</literal> field will be <literal>NULL</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW CREATE TABLE</literal> quotes table
        and column names according to the value of the
        <literal role="sysvar">sql_quote_show_create</literal> option.
        See <xref linkend="server-system-variables" />.

For information about how <literal role="stmt">CREATE
        TABLE</literal> statements are stored by MySQL, see
        <xref linkend="create-table-statement-retention" />.

This statement shows the <literal role="stmt">CREATE
        TRIGGER</literal> statement that creates the named trigger. This
        statement requires the <literal role="priv">TRIGGER</literal>
        privilege for the table associated with the trigger.

This statement shows the <literal role="stmt">CREATE
        USER</literal> statement that creates the named user. An error
        occurs if the user does not exist. The statement requires the
        <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system database, except to display
        information for the current user.

To name the account, use the format described in
        <xref linkend="account-names" />. The host name part of the
        account name, if omitted, defaults to <literal>'%'</literal>. It
        is also possible to specify
        <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER</literal> or
        <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER()</literal> to refer to the
        account associated with the current session.

This statement shows the <literal role="stmt">CREATE
        VIEW</literal> statement that creates the named view.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW DATABASES</literal> lists the
        databases on the MySQL server host.
        <literal condition="show-databases" role="stmt">SHOW
        SCHEMAS</literal> is a synonym for <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        DATABASES</literal>. The <literal role="op">LIKE</literal>
        clause, if present, indicates which database names to match. The
        <literal>WHERE</literal> clause can be given to select rows
        using more general conditions, as discussed in
        <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

You see only those databases for which you have some kind of
        privilege, unless you have the global <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        DATABASES</literal> privilege. You can also get this list using
        the <command>mysqlshow</command> command.

If the server was started with the
        <option role="mysqld">--skip-show-database</option> option, you
        cannot use this statement at all unless you have the
        <literal role="priv">SHOW DATABASES</literal> privilege.

MySQL implements databases as directories in the data directory,
        so this statement simply lists directories in that location.
        However, the output may include names of directories that do not
        correspond to actual databases.

Database information is also available from the
        <literal>INFORMATION_SCHEMA</literal>
        <literal role="is">SCHEMATA</literal> table. See
        <xref linkend="schemata-table" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW ENGINE</literal> displays operational
        information about a storage engine. It requires the
        <literal role="priv">PROCESS</literal> privilege. The statement
        has these variants:

description.programlisting:
>
SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS
SHOW ENGINE INNODB MUTEX
SHOW ENGINE PERFORMANCE_SCHEMA STATUS

description.para:
<literal condition="show-engine" role="stmt">SHOW ENGINE INNODB
        STATUS</literal> displays extensive information from the
        standard <literal>InnoDB</literal> Monitor about the state of
        the <literal>InnoDB</literal> storage engine. For information
        about the standard monitor and other <literal>InnoDB</literal>
        Monitors that provide information about
        <literal>InnoDB</literal> processing, see
        <xref linkend="innodb-monitors" />.

<literal condition="show-engine" role="stmt">SHOW ENGINE INNODB
        MUTEX</literal> displays <literal>InnoDB</literal>
        <link linkend="glos_mutex">mutex</link> and
        <link linkend="glos_rw_lock">rw-lock</link> statistics.

<literal condition="show-engine" role="stmt">SHOW ENGINE INNODB
        MUTEX</literal> output was removed in MySQL 5.7.2. It was
        revised and reintroduced in MySQL 5.7.8.

In MySQL 5.7.8, mutex statistics collection is configured
        dynamically using the following options:

itemizedlist.para: To enable the collection of mutex statistics, run:
To reset mutex statistics, run:
To disable the collection of mutex statistics, run:

description.para:
Collection of mutex statistics for
        <literal condition="show-engine" role="stmt">SHOW ENGINE INNODB
        MUTEX</literal> can also be enabled by setting
        <literal role="sysvar">innodb_monitor_enable='all'</literal>, or
        disabled by setting
        <literal role="sysvar">innodb_monitor_disable='all'</literal>.

<literal condition="show-engine" role="stmt">SHOW ENGINE INNODB
        MUTEX</literal> output has these columns:

itemizedlist.para: <literal>Type</literal>
Always <literal>InnoDB</literal>.
<literal>Name</literal>

Prior to MySQL 5.7.8, the <literal>Name</literal> field
            reports the source file where the mutex is implemented, and
            the line number in the file where the mutex is created. The
            line number is specific to your version of MySQL. As of
            MySQL 5.7.8, only the mutex name is reported. File name and
            line number are still reported for rwlocks.
<literal>Status</literal>
The mutex status.

Prior to MySQL 5.7.8, the <literal>Status</literal> field
            displays several values if
            <option role="cmake">WITH_DEBUG</option> was defined at
            MySQL compilation time. If
            <option role="cmake">WITH_DEBUG</option> was not defined,
            the statement displays only the <literal>os_waits</literal>
            value. In the latter case (without
            <option role="cmake">WITH_DEBUG</option>), the information
            on which the output is based is insufficient to distinguish
            regular mutexes and mutexes that protect rwlocks (which
            permit multiple readers or a single writer). Consequently,
            the output may appear to contain multiple rows for the same
            mutex. Pre-MySQL 5.7.8 <literal>Status</literal> field
            values include:

<literal>count</literal> indicates how many times the
                mutex was requested.

<literal>spin_waits</literal> indicates how many times
                the spinlock had to run.

<literal>spin_rounds</literal> indicates the number of
                spinlock rounds. (<literal>spin_rounds</literal> divided
                by <literal>spin_waits</literal> provides the average
                round count.)

<literal>os_waits</literal> indicates the number of
                operating system waits. This occurs when the spinlock
                did not work (the mutex was not locked during the
                spinlock and it was necessary to yield to the operating
                system and wait).
