<literal>os_yields</literal> indicates the number of
                times a thread trying to lock a mutex gave up its
                timeslice and yielded to the operating system (on the
                presumption that permitting other threads to run will
                free the mutex so that it can be locked).

<literal>os_wait_times</literal> indicates the amount of
                time (in ms) spent in operating system waits. In MySQL
                current-series timing is disabled and this value is
                always 0.

As of MySQL 5.7.8, the <literal>Status</literal> field
            reports the number of spins, waits, and calls. Statistics
            for low-level operating system mutexes, which are
            implemented outside of <literal>InnoDB</literal>, are not
            reported.
<literal>spins</literal> indicates the number of spins.

<literal>waits</literal> indicates the number of mutex
                waits.

<literal>calls</literal> indicates how many times the
                mutex was requested.

description.para:
<literal>SHOW ENGINE INNODB MUTEX</literal> skips the
        <link linkend="glos_mutex">mutexes</link> and
        <link linkend="glos_rw_lock">rw-locks</link> of
        <link linkend="glos_buffer_pool">buffer pool</link> blocks, as
        the amount of output can be overwhelming on systems with a large
        buffer pool. (There is one mutex and one rw-lock in each 16K
        buffer pool block, and there are 65,536 blocks per gigabyte.)
        <literal>SHOW ENGINE INNODB MUTEX</literal> also does not list
        any mutexes or rw-locks that have never been waited on
        (<literal>os_waits=0</literal>). Thus, <literal>SHOW ENGINE
        INNODB MUTEX</literal> only displays information about mutexes
        and rw-locks outside of the buffer pool that have caused at
        least one OS-level <link linkend="glos_wait">wait</link>.

Use <literal condition="show-engine" role="stmt">SHOW ENGINE
        PERFORMANCE_SCHEMA STATUS</literal> to inspect the internal
        operation of the Performance Schema code:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW ENGINE PERFORMANCE_SCHEMA STATUS\G</userinput>
...
*************************** 3. row ***************************
  Type: performance_schema
  Name: events_waits_history.size
Status: 76
*************************** 4. row ***************************
  Type: performance_schema
  Name: events_waits_history.count
Status: 10000
*************************** 5. row ***************************
  Type: performance_schema
  Name: events_waits_history.memory
Status: 760000
...
*************************** 57. row ***************************
  Type: performance_schema
  Name: performance_schema.memory
Status: 26459600
...

description.para:
This statement is intended to help the DBA understand the
        effects that different Performance Schema options have on memory
        requirements.

<literal>Name</literal> values consist of two parts, which name
        an internal buffer and a buffer attribute, respectively.
        Interpret buffer names as follows:

itemizedlist.para:
An internal buffer that is not exposed as a table is named
            within parentheses. Examples:
            <literal>(pfs_cond_class).size</literal>,
            <literal>(pfs_mutex_class).memory</literal>.

An internal buffer that is exposed as a table in the
            <literal>performance_schema</literal> database is named
            after the table, without parentheses. Examples:
            <literal>events_waits_history.size</literal>,
            <literal>mutex_instances.count</literal>.

A value that applies to the Performance Schema as a whole
            begins with <literal>performance_schema</literal>. Example:
            <literal>performance_schema.memory</literal>.

description.para: Buffer attributes have these meanings:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>size</literal> is the size of the internal record
            used by the implementation, such as the size of a row in a
            table. <literal>size</literal> values cannot be changed.

<literal>count</literal> is the number of internal records,
            such as the number of rows in a table.
            <literal>count</literal> values can be changed using
            Performance Schema configuration options.

For a table,
            <literal><replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>.memory</literal>
            is the product of <literal>size</literal> and
            <literal>count</literal>. For the Performance Schema as a
            whole, <literal>performance_schema.memory</literal> is the
            sum of all the memory used (the sum of all other
            <literal>memory</literal> values).

description.para:
In some cases, there is a direct relationship between a
        Performance Schema configuration parameter and a <literal>SHOW
        ENGINE</literal> value. For example,
        <literal>events_waits_history_long.count</literal> corresponds
        to
        <literal role="sysvar">performance_schema_events_waits_history_long_size</literal>.
        In other cases, the relationship is more complex. For example,
        <literal>events_waits_history.count</literal> corresponds to
        <literal role="sysvar">performance_schema_events_waits_history_size</literal>
        (the number of rows per thread) multiplied by
        <literal role="sysvar">performance_schema_max_thread_instances</literal>
        ( the number of threads).

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW ENGINE NDB STATUS;</userinput>
+------------+-----------------------+--------------------------------------------------+
| Type       | Name                  | Status                                           |
+------------+-----------------------+--------------------------------------------------+
| ndbcluster | connection            | cluster_node_id=7,
  connected_host=198.51.100.103, connected_port=1186, number_of_data_nodes=4,
  number_of_ready_data_nodes=3, connect_count=0                                         |
| ndbcluster | NdbTransaction        | created=6, free=0, sizeof=212                    |
| ndbcluster | NdbOperation          | created=8, free=8, sizeof=660                    |
| ndbcluster | NdbIndexScanOperation | created=1, free=1, sizeof=744                    |
| ndbcluster | NdbIndexOperation     | created=0, free=0, sizeof=664                    |
| ndbcluster | NdbRecAttr            | created=1285, free=1285, sizeof=60               |
| ndbcluster | NdbApiSignal          | created=16, free=16, sizeof=136                  |
| ndbcluster | NdbLabel              | created=0, free=0, sizeof=196                    |
| ndbcluster | NdbBranch             | created=0, free=0, sizeof=24                     |
| ndbcluster | NdbSubroutine         | created=0, free=0, sizeof=68                     |
| ndbcluster | NdbCall               | created=0, free=0, sizeof=16                     |
| ndbcluster | NdbBlob               | created=1, free=1, sizeof=264                    |
| ndbcluster | NdbReceiver           | created=4, free=0, sizeof=68                     |
| ndbcluster | binlog                | latest_epoch=155467, latest_trans_epoch=148126,
  latest_received_binlog_epoch=0, latest_handled_binlog_epoch=0,
  latest_applied_binlog_epoch=0                                                         |
+------------+-----------------------+--------------------------------------------------+

description.para:
The <literal>Status</literal> column in each of these rows
        provides information about the MySQL server's connection to
        the cluster and about the cluster binary log's status,
        respectively. The <literal>Status</literal> information is in
        the form of comma-delimited set of name/value pairs.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW ENGINES</literal> displays status
        information about the server's storage engines. This is
        particularly useful for checking whether a storage engine is
        supported, or to see what the default engine is.

For information about MySQL storage engines, see
        <xref linkend="innodb-storage-engine" />, and
        <xref linkend="storage-engines" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW ERRORS</literal> is a diagnostic
        statement that is similar to <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        WARNINGS</literal>, except that it displays information only for
        errors, rather than for errors, warnings, and notes.

The <literal>LIMIT</literal> clause has the same syntax as for
        the <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement. See
        <xref linkend="select" />.

The <literal condition="show-errors" role="stmt">SHOW COUNT(*)
        ERRORS</literal> statement displays the number of errors. You
        can also retrieve this number from the
        <literal role="sysvar">error_count</literal> variable:

<literal role="stmt">SHOW ERRORS</literal> and
        <literal role="sysvar">error_count</literal> apply only to
        errors, not warnings or notes. In other respects, they are
        similar to <literal role="stmt">SHOW WARNINGS</literal> and
        <literal role="sysvar">warning_count</literal>. In particular,
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW ERRORS</literal> cannot display
        information for more than
        <literal role="sysvar">max_error_count</literal> messages, and
        <literal role="sysvar">error_count</literal> can exceed the
        value of <literal role="sysvar">max_error_count</literal> if the
        number of errors exceeds
        <literal role="sysvar">max_error_count</literal>.

This statement displays information about Event Manager events,
        which are discussed in <xref linkend="event-scheduler" />. It
        requires the <literal role="priv">EVENT</literal> privilege for
        the database from which the events are to be shown.

In its simplest form, <literal role="stmt">SHOW EVENTS</literal>
        lists all of the events in the current schema:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT CURRENT_USER(), SCHEMA();</userinput>
+----------------+----------+
| CURRENT_USER() | SCHEMA() |
+----------------+----------+
| jon@ghidora    | myschema |
+----------------+----------+
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

mysql> <userinput>SHOW EVENTS\G</userinput>
*************************** 1. row ***************************
                  Db: myschema
                Name: e_daily
             Definer: jon@ghidora
           Time zone: SYSTEM
                Type: RECURRING
          Execute at: NULL
      Interval value: 1
      Interval field: DAY
              Starts: 2018-08-08 11:06:34
                Ends: NULL
              Status: ENABLED
          Originator: 1
character_set_client: utf8
collation_connection: utf8_general_ci
  Database Collation: latin1_swedish_ci

description.para:
To see events for a specific schema, use the
        <literal>FROM</literal> clause. For example, to see events for
        the <literal>test</literal> schema, use the following statement:

description.programlisting:
>
SHOW EVENTS FROM test;

description.para:
The <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if present,
        indicates which event names to match. The
        <literal>WHERE</literal> clause can be given to select rows
        using more general conditions, as discussed in
        <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

This statement is similar to <literal role="stmt">SHOW PROCEDURE
        CODE</literal> but for stored functions. See
        <xref linkend="show-procedure-code" />.

This statement is similar to <literal role="stmt">SHOW PROCEDURE
        STATUS</literal> but for stored functions. See
        <xref linkend="show-procedure-status" />.

This statement displays the privileges that are assigned to a
        MySQL user account, in the form of
        <literal role="stmt">GRANT</literal> statements that must be
        executed to duplicate the privilege assignments.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW GRANTS</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system database, except to display
        privileges for the current user.

To name the account for <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        GRANTS</literal>, use the same format as for the
        <literal role="stmt">GRANT</literal> statement (for example,
        <literal>'jeffrey'@'localhost'</literal>):

The host part, if omitted, defaults to <literal>'%'</literal>.
        For additional information about specifying account names, see
        <xref linkend="account-names" />.

To display the privileges granted to the current user (the
        account you are using to connect to the server), you can use any
        of the following statements:

If <literal>SHOW GRANTS FOR CURRENT_USER</literal> (or any
        equivalent syntax) is used in definer context, such as within a
        stored procedure that executes with definer rather than invoker
        privileges, the grants displayed are those of the definer and
        not the invoker.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW GRANTS</literal> does not display
        privileges that are available to the named account but are
        granted to a different account. For example, if an anonymous
        account exists, the named account might be able to use its
        privileges, but <literal role="stmt">SHOW GRANTS</literal> does
        not display them.

<literal>SHOW GRANTS</literal> output does not include
        <literal>IDENTIFIED BY PASSWORD</literal> clauses. Use the
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW CREATE USER</literal> statement
        instead. See <xref linkend="show-create-user" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW INDEX</literal> returns table index
        information. The format resembles that of the
        <literal>SQLStatistics</literal> call in ODBC. This statement
        requires some privilege for any column in the table.

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW INDEX FROM City\G</userinput>
*************************** 1. row ***************************
        Table: city
   Non_unique: 0
     Key_name: PRIMARY
 Seq_in_index: 1
  Column_name: ID
    Collation: A
  Cardinality: 4188
     Sub_part: NULL
       Packed: NULL
         Null:
   Index_type: BTREE
      Comment:
Index_comment:
*************************** 2. row ***************************
        Table: city
   Non_unique: 1
     Key_name: CountryCode
 Seq_in_index: 1
  Column_name: CountryCode
    Collation: A
  Cardinality: 232
     Sub_part: NULL
       Packed: NULL
         Null:
   Index_type: BTREE
      Comment:
Index_comment:

description.para:
An alternative to <literal><replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
        FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable></literal> syntax is
        <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>.<replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>.
        These two statements are equivalent:

The <literal>WHERE</literal> clause can be given to select rows
        using more general conditions, as discussed in
        <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW INDEX</literal> returns the following
        fields:

itemizedlist.para: <literal>Table</literal>
The name of the table.
<literal>Non_unique</literal>
0 if the index cannot contain duplicates, 1 if it can.
<literal>Key_name</literal>

The name of the index. If the index is the primary key, the
            name is always <literal>PRIMARY</literal>.
<literal>Seq_in_index</literal>
The column sequence number in the index, starting with 1.
<literal>Column_name</literal>
The name of the column.
<literal>Collation</literal>

How the column is sorted in the index. This can have values
            <literal>A</literal> (ascending) or <literal>NULL</literal>
            (not sorted).
<literal>Cardinality</literal>

An estimate of the number of unique values in the index. To
            update this number, run <literal role="stmt">ANALYZE
            TABLE</literal> or (for <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables)
            <command>myisamchk -a</command>.

<literal>Cardinality</literal> is counted based on
            statistics stored as integers, so the value is not
            necessarily exact even for small tables. The higher the
            cardinality, the greater the chance that MySQL uses the
            index when doing joins.
<literal>Sub_part</literal>

itemizedlist.note:
<para>
              Prefix <emphasis>limits</emphasis> are measured in bytes.
              However, prefix <emphasis>lengths</emphasis> for index
              specifications in <literal role="stmt">CREATE
              TABLE</literal>, <literal role="stmt">ALTER
              TABLE</literal>, and <literal role="stmt">CREATE
              INDEX</literal> statements are interpreted as number of
              characters for nonbinary string types
              (<literal role="type">CHAR</literal>,
              <literal role="type">VARCHAR</literal>,
              <literal role="type">TEXT</literal>) and number of bytes
              for binary string types
              (<literal role="type">BINARY</literal>,
              <literal role="type">VARBINARY</literal>,
              <literal role="type">BLOB</literal>). Take this into
              account when specifying a prefix length for a nonbinary
              string column that uses a multibyte character set.
            </para>

itemizedlist.para:
For additional information about index prefixes, see
            <xref linkend="column-indexes" />, and
            <xref linkend="create-index" />.
<literal>Packed</literal>

Indicates how the key is packed. <literal>NULL</literal> if
            it is not.
<literal>Null</literal>

Contains <literal>YES</literal> if the column may contain
            <literal>NULL</literal> values and <literal>''</literal> if
            not.
<literal>Index_type</literal>

The index method used (<literal>BTREE</literal>,
            <literal>FULLTEXT</literal>, <literal>HASH</literal>,
            <literal>RTREE</literal>).
<literal>Comment</literal>

Information about the index not described in its own column,
            such as <literal>disabled</literal> if the index is
            disabled.
<literal>Index_comment</literal>

Any comment provided for the index with a
            <literal>COMMENT</literal> attribute when the index was
            created.

description.para:
Information about table indexes is also available from the
        <literal>INFORMATION_SCHEMA</literal>
        <literal role="is">STATISTICS</literal> table. See
        <xref linkend="statistics-table" />.

You can list a table's indexes with the <command>mysqlshow -k
        <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>
        <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable></command> command.

This statement provides status information about the binary log
        files of the master. It requires either the
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">REPLICATION CLIENT</literal> privilege.
Example:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW MASTER STATUS\G</userinput>
*************************** 1. row ***************************
             File: master-bin.000002
         Position: 1307
     Binlog_Do_DB: test
 Binlog_Ignore_DB: manual, mysql
Executed_Gtid_Set: 3E11FA47-71CA-11E1-9E33-C80AA9429562:1-5
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">SHOW OPEN TABLES</literal> lists the
        non-<literal>TEMPORARY</literal> tables that are currently open
        in the table cache. See <xref linkend="table-cache" />. The
        <literal>FROM</literal> clause, if present, restricts the tables
        shown to those present in the <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>
        database. The <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if
        present, indicates which table names to match. The
        <literal>WHERE</literal> clause can be given to select rows
        using more general conditions, as discussed in
        <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW PLUGINS</literal> displays information
        about server plugins.
Example of <literal role="stmt">SHOW PLUGINS</literal> output:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW PLUGINS\G</userinput>
*************************** 1. row ***************************
   Name: binlog
 Status: ACTIVE
   Type: STORAGE ENGINE
Library: NULL
License: GPL
*************************** 2. row ***************************
   Name: CSV
 Status: ACTIVE
   Type: STORAGE ENGINE
Library: NULL
License: GPL
*************************** 3. row ***************************
   Name: MEMORY
 Status: ACTIVE
   Type: STORAGE ENGINE
Library: NULL
License: GPL
*************************** 4. row ***************************
   Name: MyISAM
 Status: ACTIVE
   Type: STORAGE ENGINE
Library: NULL
License: GPL
...

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">SHOW PRIVILEGES</literal> shows the list of
        system privileges that the MySQL server supports. The exact list
        of privileges depends on the version of your server.

This statement is a MySQL extension that is available only for
        servers that have been built with debugging support. It displays
        a representation of the internal implementation of the named
        stored procedure. A similar statement, <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        FUNCTION CODE</literal>, displays information about stored
        functions (see <xref linkend="show-function-code" />).

To use either statement, you must be the owner of the routine or
        have <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> access to the
        <literal>mysql.proc</literal> table.

If the named routine is available, each statement produces a
        result set. Each row in the result set corresponds to one
        <quote>instruction</quote> in the routine. The first column is
        <literal>Pos</literal>, which is an ordinal number beginning
        with 0. The second column is <literal>Instruction</literal>,
        which contains an SQL statement (usually changed from the
        original source), or a directive which has meaning only to the
        stored-routine handler.

This statement is a MySQL extension. It returns characteristics
        of a stored procedure, such as the database, name, type,
        creator, creation and modification dates, and character set
        information. A similar statement, <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        FUNCTION STATUS</literal>, displays information about stored
        functions (see <xref linkend="show-function-status" />).

The <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if present,
        indicates which procedure or function names to match. The
        <literal>WHERE</literal> clause can be given to select rows
        using more general conditions, as discussed in
        <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW PROCESSLIST</literal> shows which
        threads are running. If you have the
        <literal role="priv">PROCESS</literal> privilege, you can see
        all threads. Otherwise, you can see only your own threads (that
        is, threads associated with the MySQL account that you are
        using). If you do not use the <literal>FULL</literal> keyword,
        only the first 100 characters of each statement are shown in the
        <literal>Info</literal> field.

The <literal role="stmt">SHOW PROFILE</literal> and
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW PROFILES</literal> statements display
        profiling information that indicates resource usage for
        statements executed during the course of the current session.

To control profiling, use the
        <literal role="sysvar">profiling</literal> session variable,
        which has a default value of 0 (<literal>OFF</literal>). Enable
        profiling by setting <literal role="sysvar">profiling</literal>
        to 1 or <literal>ON</literal>:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SET profiling = 1;</userinput>

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">SHOW PROFILES</literal> displays a list of
        the most recent statements sent to the server. The size of the
        list is controlled by the
        <literal role="sysvar">profiling_history_size</literal> session
        variable, which has a default value of 15. The maximum value is
        100. Setting the value to 0 has the practical effect of
        disabling profiling.

All statements are profiled except <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        PROFILE</literal> and <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        PROFILES</literal>, so you will find neither of those statements
        in the profile list. Malformed statements are profiled. For
        example, <literal>SHOW PROFILING</literal> is an illegal
        statement, and a syntax error occurs if you try to execute it,
        but it will show up in the profiling list.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW PROFILE</literal> displays detailed
        information about a single statement. Without the <literal>FOR
        QUERY <replaceable>n</replaceable></literal> clause, the output
        pertains to the most recently executed statement. If
        <literal>FOR QUERY <replaceable>n</replaceable></literal> is
        included, <literal role="stmt">SHOW PROFILE</literal> displays
        information for statement <replaceable>n</replaceable>. The
        values of <replaceable>n</replaceable> correspond to the
        <literal>Query_ID</literal> values displayed by
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW PROFILES</literal>.

The <literal>LIMIT
        <replaceable>row_count</replaceable></literal> clause may be
        given to limit the output to
        <replaceable>row_count</replaceable> rows. If
        <literal>LIMIT</literal> is given, <literal>OFFSET
        <replaceable>offset</replaceable></literal> may be added to
        begin the output <replaceable>offset</replaceable> rows into the
        full set of rows.

By default, <literal role="stmt">SHOW PROFILE</literal> displays
        <literal>Status</literal> and <literal>Duration</literal>
        columns. The <literal>Status</literal> values are like the
        <literal>State</literal> values displayed by
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW PROCESSLIST</literal>, although there
        might be some minor differences in interpretion for the two
        statements for some status values (see
        <xref linkend="thread-information" />).

Optional <replaceable>type</replaceable> values may be specified
        to display specific additional types of information:

itemizedlist.para: <literal>ALL</literal> displays all information

<literal>BLOCK IO</literal> displays counts for block input
            and output operations

<literal>CONTEXT SWITCHES</literal> displays counts for
            voluntary and involuntary context switches

<literal>CPU</literal> displays user and system CPU usage
            times

<literal>IPC</literal> displays counts for messages sent and
            received
<literal>MEMORY</literal> is not currently implemented

<literal>PAGE FAULTS</literal> displays counts for major and
            minor page faults

<literal>SOURCE</literal> displays the names of functions
            from the source code, together with the name and line number
            of the file in which the function occurs
<literal>SWAPS</literal> displays swap counts

description.para:
Profiling is enabled per session. When a session ends, its
        profiling information is lost.

syntax.programlisting:
>
SHOW PROFILE [<replaceable>type</replaceable> [, <replaceable>type</replaceable>] ... ]
    [FOR QUERY <replaceable>n</replaceable>]
    [LIMIT <replaceable>row_count</replaceable> [OFFSET <replaceable>offset</replaceable>]]

<replaceable>type</replaceable>: {
    ALL
  | BLOCK IO
  | CONTEXT SWITCHES
  | CPU
  | IPC
  | MEMORY
  | PAGE FAULTS
  | SOURCE
  | SWAPS
}

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">SHOW PROFILES</literal> statement,
        together with <literal role="stmt">SHOW PROFILE</literal>,
        displays profiling information that indicates resource usage for
        statements executed during the course of the current session.
        For more information, see <xref linkend="show-profile" />.

Shows the events in the relay log of a replication slave. If you
        do not specify
        <literal>'<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>'</literal>, the
        first relay log is displayed. This statement has no effect on
        the master. <literal role="stmt">SHOW RELAYLOG EVENTS</literal>
        requires the <literal role="priv">REPLICATION SLAVE</literal>
        privilege.

Displays a list of replication slaves currently registered with
        the master.

<literal>SHOW SLAVE HOSTS</literal> should be executed on a
        server that acts as a replication master. <literal>SHOW SLAVE
        HOSTS</literal> requires the <literal role="priv">REPLICATION
        SLAVE</literal> privilege. The statement displays information
        about servers that are or have been connected as replication
        slaves, with each row of the result corresponding to one slave
        server, as shown here:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>Server_id</literal>: The unique server ID of the
            slave server, as configured in the slave server's
            option file, or on the command line with
            <option role="sysvar">--server-id=<replaceable>value</replaceable></option>.

<literal>Host</literal>: The host name of the slave server
            as specified on the slave with the
            <option role="sysvar">--report-host</option> option. This
            can differ from the machine name as configured in the
            operating system.

<literal>User</literal>: The slave server user name as,
            specified on the slave with the
            <option role="sysvar">--report-user</option> option.
            Statement output includes this column only if the master
            server is started with the
            <option role="mysqld">--show-slave-auth-info</option>
            option.

<literal>Password</literal>: The slave server password as,
            specified on the slave with the
            <option role="sysvar">--report-password</option> option.
            Statement output includes this column only if the master
            server is started with the
            <option role="mysqld">--show-slave-auth-info</option>
            option.

<literal>Port</literal>: The port on the master to which the
            slave server is listening, as specified on the slave with
            the <option role="sysvar">--report-port</option> option.

A zero in this column means that the slave port
            (<option role="sysvar">--report-port</option>) was not set.

<literal>Master_id</literal>: The unique server ID of the
            master server that the slave server is replicating from.
            This is the server ID of the server on which <literal>SHOW
            SLAVE HOSTS</literal> is executed, so this same value is
            listed for each row in the result.

<indexterm>
              <primary>auto.cnf file</primary>
              <secondary>and SHOW SLAVE HOSTS statement</secondary>
            </indexterm>

            <literal>Slave_UUID</literal>: The globally unique ID of
            this slave, as generated on the slave and found in the
            slave's <filename>auto.cnf</filename> file.

description.para:
This statement provides status information on essential
        parameters of the slave threads. It requires either the
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">REPLICATION CLIENT</literal> privilege.

If you issue this statement using the <command>mysql</command>
        client, you can use a <literal>\G</literal> statement terminator
        rather than a semicolon to obtain a more readable vertical
        layout:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW SLAVE STATUS\G</userinput>
*************************** 1. row ***************************
               Slave_IO_State: Waiting for master to send event
                  Master_Host: localhost
                  Master_User: repl
                  Master_Port: 13000
                Connect_Retry: 60
              Master_Log_File: master-bin.000002
          Read_Master_Log_Pos: 1307
               Relay_Log_File: slave-relay-bin.000003
                Relay_Log_Pos: 1508
        Relay_Master_Log_File: master-bin.000002
             Slave_IO_Running: Yes
            Slave_SQL_Running: Yes
              Replicate_Do_DB:
          Replicate_Ignore_DB:
           Replicate_Do_Table:
       Replicate_Ignore_Table:
      Replicate_Wild_Do_Table:
  Replicate_Wild_Ignore_Table:
                   Last_Errno: 0
                   Last_Error:
                 Skip_Counter: 0
          Exec_Master_Log_Pos: 1307
              Relay_Log_Space: 1858
              Until_Condition: None
               Until_Log_File:
                Until_Log_Pos: 0
           Master_SSL_Allowed: No
           Master_SSL_CA_File:
           Master_SSL_CA_Path:
              Master_SSL_Cert:
            Master_SSL_Cipher:
               Master_SSL_Key:
        Seconds_Behind_Master: 0
Master_SSL_Verify_Server_Cert: No
                Last_IO_Errno: 0
                Last_IO_Error:
               Last_SQL_Errno: 0
               Last_SQL_Error:
  Replicate_Ignore_Server_Ids:
             Master_Server_Id: 1
                  Master_UUID: 3e11fa47-71ca-11e1-9e33-c80aa9429562
             Master_Info_File: /var/mysqld.2/data/master.info
                    SQL_Delay: 0
          SQL_Remaining_Delay: NULL
      Slave_SQL_Running_State: Reading event from the relay log
           Master_Retry_Count: 10
                  Master_Bind:
      Last_IO_Error_Timestamp:
     Last_SQL_Error_Timestamp:
               Master_SSL_Crl:
           Master_SSL_Crlpath:
           Retrieved_Gtid_Set: 3e11fa47-71ca-11e1-9e33-c80aa9429562:1-5
            Executed_Gtid_Set: 3e11fa47-71ca-11e1-9e33-c80aa9429562:1-5
                Auto_Position: 1
         Replicate_Rewrite_DB:
                 Channel_name:
           Master_TLS_Version: TLSv1.2

description.para:
The Performance Schema provides tables that expose replication
        information. This is similar to the information available from
        the <literal role="stmt">SHOW SLAVE STATUS</literal> statement,
        but represented in table form. For details, see
        <xref linkend="performance-schema-replication-tables" />.

With a <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, the statement
        displays only rows for those variables with names that match the
        pattern:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW STATUS LIKE 'Key%';</userinput>
+--------------------+----------+
| Variable_name      | Value    |
+--------------------+----------+
| Key_blocks_used    | 14955    |
| Key_read_requests  | 96854827 |
| Key_reads          | 162040   |
| Key_write_requests | 7589728  |
| Key_writes         | 3813196  |
+--------------------+----------+

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">SHOW TABLE STATUS</literal> works likes
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW TABLES</literal>, but provides a lot
        of information about each non-<literal>TEMPORARY</literal>
        table. You can also get this list using the <command>mysqlshow
        --status <replaceable>db_name</replaceable></command> command.
        The <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if present,
        indicates which table names to match. The
        <literal>WHERE</literal> clause can be given to select rows
        using more general conditions, as discussed in
        <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW TABLES</literal> lists the
        non-<literal>TEMPORARY</literal> tables in a given database. You
        can also get this list using the <command>mysqlshow
        <replaceable>db_name</replaceable></command> command. The
        <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if present, indicates
        which table names to match. The <literal>WHERE</literal> clause
        can be given to select rows using more general conditions, as
        discussed in <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

Matching performed by the <literal>LIKE</literal> clause is
        dependent on the setting of the
        <literal role="sysvar">lower_case_table_names</literal> system
        variable.

This statement also lists any views in the database. The
        optional <literal>FULL</literal> modifier causes
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW TABLES</literal> to display a second
        output column with values of <literal>BASE TABLE</literal> for a
        table, <literal>VIEW</literal> for a view, or <literal>SYSTEM
        VIEW</literal> for an <literal>INFORMATION_SCHEMA</literal>
        table.

If you have no privileges for a base table or view, it does not
        show up in the output from <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        TABLES</literal> or <command>mysqlshow db_name</command>.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW TRIGGERS</literal> lists the triggers
        currently defined for tables in a database (the default database
        unless a <literal>FROM</literal> clause is given). This
        statement returns results only for databases and tables for
        which you have the <literal role="priv">TRIGGER</literal>
        privilege. The <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if
        present, indicates which table names (not trigger names) to
        match and causes the statement to display triggers for those
        tables. The <literal>WHERE</literal> clause can be given to
        select rows using more general conditions, as discussed in
        <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

For the <literal>ins_sum</literal> trigger defined in
        <xref linkend="triggers" />, the output of
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW TRIGGERS</literal> is as shown here:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW TRIGGERS LIKE 'acc%'\G</userinput>
*************************** 1. row ***************************
             Trigger: ins_sum
               Event: INSERT
               Table: account
           Statement: SET @sum = @sum + NEW.amount
              Timing: BEFORE
             Created: 2018-08-08 10:10:12.61
            sql_mode: ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY,STRICT_TRANS_TABLES,
                      NO_ZERO_IN_DATE,NO_ZERO_DATE,
                      ERROR_FOR_DIVISION_BY_ZERO,
                      NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER,NO_ENGINE_SUBSTITUTION
             Definer: me@localhost
character_set_client: utf8
collation_connection: utf8_general_ci
  Database Collation: latin1_swedish_ci

description.para:
With a <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, the statement
        displays only rows for those variables with names that match the
        pattern. To obtain the row for a specific variable, use a
        <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause as shown:

To get a list of variables whose name match a pattern, use the
        <literal>%</literal> wildcard character in a
        <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause:

Wildcard characters can be used in any position within the
        pattern to be matched. Strictly speaking, because
        <literal>_</literal> is a wildcard that matches any single
        character, you should escape it as <literal>\_</literal> to
        match it literally. In practice, this is rarely necessary.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW WARNINGS</literal> is a diagnostic
        statement that displays information about the conditions
        (errors, warnings, and notes) resulting from executing a
        statement in the current session. Warnings are generated for DML
        statements such as <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal>,
        <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal>, and
        <literal role="stmt">LOAD DATA</literal> as well as DDL
        statements such as <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal>
        and <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal>.

The <literal>LIMIT</literal> clause has the same syntax as for
        the <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement. See
        <xref linkend="select" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW WARNINGS</literal> is also used
        following <literal role="stmt">EXPLAIN</literal>, to display the
        extended information generated by
        <literal role="stmt">EXPLAIN</literal>. See
        <xref linkend="explain-extended" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW WARNINGS</literal> displays
        information about the conditions resulting from execution of the
        most recent nondiagnostic statement in the current session. If
        the most recent statement resulted in an error during parsing,
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW WARNINGS</literal> shows the resulting
        conditions, regardless of statement type (diagnostic or
        nondiagnostic).

The <literal condition="show-warnings" role="stmt">SHOW COUNT(*)
        WARNINGS</literal> diagnostic statement displays the total
        number of errors, warnings, and notes. You can also retrieve
        this number from the
        <literal role="sysvar">warning_count</literal> system variable:

A difference in these statements is that the first is a
        diagnostic statement that does not clear the message list. The
        second, because it is a <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal>
        statement is considered nondiagnostic and does clear the message
        list.

A related diagnostic statement, <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        ERRORS</literal>, shows only error conditions (it excludes
        warnings and notes), and
        <literal condition="show-warnings" role="stmt">SHOW COUNT(*)
        ERRORS</literal> statement displays the total number of errors.
        See <xref linkend="show-errors" />. <literal role="stmt">GET
        DIAGNOSTICS</literal> can be used to examine information for
        individual conditions. See <xref linkend="get-diagnostics" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW</literal> has many forms that provide
      information about databases, tables, columns, or status
      information about the server. This section describes those
      following:

description.programlisting:
>
SHOW {BINARY | MASTER} LOGS
SHOW BINLOG EVENTS [IN '<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>'] [FROM <replaceable>pos</replaceable>] [LIMIT [<replaceable>offset</replaceable>,] <replaceable>row_count</replaceable>]
SHOW CHARACTER SET [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW COLLATION [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW [FULL] COLUMNS FROM <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>] [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW CREATE DATABASE <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>
SHOW CREATE EVENT <replaceable>event_name</replaceable>
SHOW CREATE FUNCTION <replaceable>func_name</replaceable>
SHOW CREATE PROCEDURE <replaceable>proc_name</replaceable>
SHOW CREATE TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
SHOW CREATE TRIGGER <replaceable>trigger_name</replaceable>
SHOW CREATE VIEW <replaceable>view_name</replaceable>
SHOW DATABASES [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW ENGINE <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable> {STATUS | MUTEX}
SHOW [STORAGE] ENGINES
SHOW ERRORS [LIMIT [<replaceable>offset</replaceable>,] <replaceable>row_count</replaceable>]
SHOW EVENTS
SHOW FUNCTION CODE <replaceable>func_name</replaceable>
SHOW FUNCTION STATUS [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW GRANTS FOR <replaceable>user</replaceable>
SHOW INDEX FROM <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>]
SHOW MASTER STATUS
SHOW OPEN TABLES [FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>] [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW PLUGINS
SHOW PROCEDURE CODE <replaceable>proc_name</replaceable>
SHOW PROCEDURE STATUS [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW PRIVILEGES
SHOW [FULL] PROCESSLIST
SHOW PROFILE [<replaceable>types</replaceable>] [FOR QUERY <replaceable>n</replaceable>] [OFFSET <replaceable>n</replaceable>] [LIMIT <replaceable>n</replaceable>]
SHOW PROFILES
SHOW RELAYLOG EVENTS [IN '<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>'] [FROM <replaceable>pos</replaceable>] [LIMIT [<replaceable>offset</replaceable>,] <replaceable>row_count</replaceable>]
SHOW SLAVE HOSTS
SHOW SLAVE STATUS [FOR CHANNEL <replaceable>channel</replaceable>]
SHOW [GLOBAL | SESSION] STATUS [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW TABLE STATUS [FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>] [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW [FULL] TABLES [FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>] [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW TRIGGERS [FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>] [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW [GLOBAL | SESSION] VARIABLES [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW WARNINGS [LIMIT [<replaceable>offset</replaceable>,] <replaceable>row_count</replaceable>]

<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>:
    LIKE '<replaceable>pattern</replaceable>'
  | WHERE <replaceable>expr</replaceable>

description.para:
If the syntax for a given <literal role="stmt">SHOW</literal>
      statement includes a <literal condition="like" role="op">LIKE
      '<replaceable>pattern</replaceable>'</literal> part,
      <literal>'<replaceable>pattern</replaceable>'</literal> is a
      string that can contain the SQL <literal>%</literal> and
      <literal>_</literal> wildcard characters. The pattern is useful
      for restricting statement output to matching values.

Several <literal role="stmt">SHOW</literal> statements also accept
      a <literal>WHERE</literal> clause that provides more flexibility
      in specifying which rows to display. See
      <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

<literal role="stmt">BINLOG</literal> is an internal-use
        statement. It is generated by the <command>mysqlbinlog</command>
        program as the printable representation of certain events in
        binary log files. (See <xref linkend="mysqlbinlog" />.) The
        <literal>'<replaceable>str</replaceable>'</literal> value is a
        base 64-encoded string the that server decodes to determine the
        data change indicated by the corresponding event. This statement
        requires the <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

The <literal role="stmt">CACHE INDEX</literal> statement assigns
        table indexes to a specific key cache. It applies only to
        <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables, including partitioned
        <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables. After the indexes have been
        assigned, they can be preloaded into the cache if desired with
        <literal condition="load-index" role="stmt">LOAD INDEX INTO
        CACHE</literal>.

The following statement assigns indexes from the tables
        <literal>t1</literal>, <literal>t2</literal>, and
        <literal>t3</literal> to the key cache named
        <literal>hot_cache</literal>:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>CACHE INDEX t1, t2, t3 IN hot_cache;</userinput>
+---------+--------------------+----------+----------+
| Table   | Op                 | Msg_type | Msg_text |
+---------+--------------------+----------+----------+
| test.t1 | assign_to_keycache | status   | OK       |
| test.t2 | assign_to_keycache | status   | OK       |
| test.t3 | assign_to_keycache | status   | OK       |
+---------+--------------------+----------+----------+

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal> statement has several
        variant forms that clear or reload various internal caches,
        flush tables, or acquire locks. To execute
        <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal>, you must have the
        <literal role="priv">RELOAD</literal> privilege. Specific flush
        options might require additional privileges, as described later.

By default, the server writes
        <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal> statements to the binary
        log so that they replicate to replication slaves. To suppress
        logging, specify the optional
        <literal>NO_WRITE_TO_BINLOG</literal> keyword or its alias
        <literal>LOCAL</literal>.

The <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal> statement causes an
        implicit commit. See <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

The <command>mysqladmin</command> utility provides a
        command-line interface to some flush operations, using commands
        such as <literal>flush-hosts</literal>,
        <literal>flush-logs</literal>,
        <literal>flush-privileges</literal>,
        <literal>flush-status</literal>, and
        <literal>flush-tables</literal>. See
        <xref linkend="mysqladmin" />.

Sending a <literal>SIGHUP</literal> signal to the server causes
        several flush operations to occur that are similar to various
        forms of the <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal> statement. See
        <xref linkend="server-signal-response" />.

The <literal role="stmt">RESET</literal> statement is similar to
        <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal>. See
        <xref linkend="reset" />, for information about using the
        <literal role="stmt">RESET</literal> statement with replication.

syntax.programlisting:
>
FLUSH [NO_WRITE_TO_BINLOG | LOCAL] {
    <replaceable>flush_option</replaceable> [, <replaceable>flush_option</replaceable>] ...
  | <replaceable>tables_option</replaceable>
}

<replaceable>flush_option</replaceable>: {
    BINARY LOGS
  | DES_KEY_FILE
  | ENGINE LOGS
  | ERROR LOGS
  | GENERAL LOGS
  | HOSTS
  | LOGS
  | PRIVILEGES
  | OPTIMIZER_COSTS
  | QUERY CACHE
  | RELAY LOGS [FOR CHANNEL <replaceable>channel</replaceable>]
  | SLOW LOGS
  | STATUS
  | USER_RESOURCES
}

<replaceable>tables_option</replaceable>: {
    TABLES
  | TABLES <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>] ...
  | TABLES WITH READ LOCK
  | TABLES <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>] ... WITH READ LOCK
  | TABLES <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>] ... FOR EXPORT
}

description.para:
Each connection to <command>mysqld</command> runs in a separate
        thread. You can kill a thread with the <literal>KILL
        <replaceable>processlist_id</replaceable></literal> statement.

Thread processlist identifiers can be determined from the
        <literal>ID</literal> column of the
        <literal>INFORMATION_SCHEMA</literal>
        <literal role="is">PROCESSLIST</literal> table, the
        <literal>Id</literal> column of <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        PROCESSLIST</literal> output, and the
        <literal>PROCESSLIST_ID</literal> column of the Performance
        Schema <literal role="ps">threads</literal> table. The value for
        the current thread is returned by the
        <literal role="func">CONNECTION_ID()</literal> function.

<literal role="stmt">KILL</literal> permits an optional
        <literal>CONNECTION</literal> or <literal>QUERY</literal>
        modifier:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal condition="kill" role="stmt">KILL
            CONNECTION</literal> is the same as
            <literal role="stmt">KILL</literal> with no modifier: It
            terminates the connection associated with the given
            <replaceable>processlist_id</replaceable>, after terminating
            any statement the connection is executing.

<literal condition="kill" role="stmt">KILL QUERY</literal>
            terminates the statement the connection is currently
            executing, but leaves the connection itself intact.

description.para:
The ability to see which threads are available to be killed
        depends on the <literal role="priv">PROCESS</literal> privilege:

itemizedlist.para:
Without <literal role="priv">PROCESS</literal>, you can see
            only your own threads.

With <literal role="priv">PROCESS</literal>, you can see all
            threads.

description.para:
The ability to kill threads and statements depends on the
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege:

itemizedlist.para:
Without <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal>, you can kill
            only your own threads and statements.

With <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal>, you can kill all
            threads and statements.

description.para:
You can also use the <command>mysqladmin processlist</command>
        and <command>mysqladmin kill</command> commands to examine and
        kill threads.

The <literal condition="load-index" role="stmt">LOAD INDEX INTO
        CACHE</literal> statement preloads a table index into the key
        cache to which it has been assigned by an explicit
        <literal role="stmt">CACHE INDEX</literal> statement, or into
        the default key cache otherwise.

<literal condition="load-index" role="stmt">LOAD INDEX INTO
        CACHE</literal> applies only to <literal>MyISAM</literal>
        tables, including partitioned <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables.
        In addition, indexes on partitioned tables can be preloaded for
        one, several, or all partitions.

The <literal>IGNORE LEAVES</literal> modifier causes only blocks
        for the nonleaf nodes of the index to be preloaded.

<literal>IGNORE LEAVES</literal> is also supported for
        partitioned <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables.

syntax.programlisting:
>
LOAD INDEX INTO CACHE
  <replaceable>tbl_index_list</replaceable> [, <replaceable>tbl_index_list</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>tbl_index_list</replaceable>:
  <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    [PARTITION (<replaceable>partition_list</replaceable>)]
    [{INDEX|KEY} (<replaceable>index_name</replaceable>[, <replaceable>index_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    [IGNORE LEAVES]

<replaceable>partition_list</replaceable>: {
    <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable>[, <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable>] ...
  | ALL
}

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">RESET</literal> statement is used to
        clear the state of various server operations. You must have the
        <literal role="priv">RELOAD</literal> privilege to execute
        <literal role="stmt">RESET</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">RESET</literal> acts as a stronger version
        of the <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal> statement. See
        <xref linkend="flush" />.

The <literal role="stmt">RESET</literal> statement causes an
        implicit commit. See <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

The following list describes the permitted
        <literal role="stmt">RESET</literal> statement
        <replaceable>reset_option</replaceable> values:

itemizedlist.para: <literal>RESET MASTER</literal>

Deletes all binary logs listed in the index file, resets the
            binary log index file to be empty, and creates a new binary
            log file.
<literal>RESET QUERY CACHE</literal>
Removes all query results from the query cache.

itemizedlist.note:
<para>
              The query cache is deprecated as of MySQL 5.7.20, and is
              removed in MySQL next-series. Deprecation includes
              <literal condition="reset" role="stmt">RESET QUERY
              CACHE</literal>.
            </para>

itemizedlist.para: <literal>RESET SLAVE</literal>

Makes the slave forget its replication position in the
            master binary logs. Also resets the relay log by deleting
            any existing relay log files and beginning a new one.

description.para:
This statement stops the MySQL server. It requires the
        <literal role="priv">SHUTDOWN</literal> privilege.

<literal role="stmt">SHUTDOWN</literal> provides an SQL-level
        interface to the same functionality available using the
        <command>mysqladmin shutdown</command> command or the
        <literal role="cfunc">mysql_shutdown()</literal> C API function.

The binary log is a set of files that contain information about
        data modifications made by the MySQL server. The log consists of
        a set of binary log files, plus an index file (see
        <xref linkend="binary-log" />).

The <literal role="stmt">PURGE BINARY LOGS</literal> statement
        deletes all the binary log files listed in the log index file
        prior to the specified log file name or date.
        <literal>BINARY</literal> and <literal>MASTER</literal> are
        synonyms. Deleted log files also are removed from the list
        recorded in the index file, so that the given log file becomes
        the first in the list.

This statement has no effect if the server was not started with
        the <option role="mysqld">--log-bin</option> option to enable
        binary logging.

Deletes all binary log files listed in the index file, resets
        the binary log index file to be empty, and creates a new binary
        log file.

<literal>RESET MASTER</literal> also clears the values of the
        <literal role="sysvar">gtid_purged</literal> system variable as
        well as the global value of the
        <literal role="sysvar">gtid_executed</literal> system variable
        (but not its session value); that is, executing this statement
        sets each of these values to an empty string
        (<literal>''</literal>). In MySQL 5.7.5 and later, this
        statement also clears the
        <xref linkend="replication-gtids-gtid-executed-table" />.

This statement is intended to be used only when the master is
        started for the first time.

The <literal role="sysvar">sql_log_bin</literal> variable
        controls whether logging to the binary log is done. The default
        value is 1 (do logging). To change logging for the current
        session, change the session value of this variable. The session
        user must have the <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal>
        privilege to set this variable. Set this variable to 0 for a
        session to temporarily disable binary logging while making
        changes to the master which you do not want to replicate to the
        slave.

As of MySQL 5.5, <literal role="sysvar">sql_log_bin</literal>
        can be set as a global or session variable. Setting
        <literal role="sysvar">sql_log_bin</literal> globally is only
        detected when a new session is started. Any sessions previously
        running are not impacted when setting
        <literal role="sysvar">sql_log_bin</literal> globally.

In MySQL 5.7, it is not possible to set
        <literal>@@SESSION.sql_log_bin</literal> within a transaction or
        subquery. (Bug #53437)

<literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> changes the
        parameters that the slave server uses for connecting to the
        master server, for reading the master binary log, and reading
        the slave relay log. It also updates the contents of the master
        info and relay log info repositories (see
        <xref linkend="slave-logs" />).

If a slave is already running, in MySQL 5.7.4 and later, you can
        issue <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statements without
        stopping the slave, depending on the states of the slave SQL
        thread and slave I/O thread. The rules governing such use are
        provided later in this section. Prior to MySQL 5.7.4, the slave
        replication threads must be stopped, using
        <literal role="stmt">STOP SLAVE</literal> if necessary, before
        issuing this statement.

The simplest way to use this statement to configure a
        replication slave to use a specific master is:

description.programlisting: >CHANGE MASTER TO MASTER_HOST='<replaceable>master_host</replaceable>', MASTER_PORT=<replaceable>master_port</replaceable>

description.para:
where <replaceable>master_host</replaceable> is the
        master's IP or hostname and
        <replaceable>master_port</replaceable> is the port which is open
        on the master.

Options not specified retain their value, except as indicated in
        the following discussion. Thus, in most cases, there is no need
        to specify options that do not change. For example, if the
        password to connect to your MySQL master has changed, issue this
        statement to tell the slave about the new password:

description.programlisting:
>
CHANGE MASTER TO MASTER_PASSWORD='new3cret';

description.para:
The optional <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause added in
        MySQL 5.7.6 enables you to choose which replication channel the
        statement applies to. If no clause is set and no extra channels
        exist, the statement applies to the default channel and behaves
        the same as versions of MySQL prior to 5.7.6. Providing a
        <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause applies the
        <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement to a specific
        replication channel, and is used to add a new channel or modify
        an existing channel. For example, to add a new channel called
        channel2:

description.programlisting: >CHANGE MASTER TO MASTER_HOST=host1, MASTER_PORT=3002 FOR CHANNEL 'channel2'

description.para:
When using multiple replication channels, if a <literal>CHANGE
        MASTER TO</literal> statement does not have a channel defined
        using a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause an error is
        generated. See <xref linkend="replication-channels" /> for more
        information.

<literal>MASTER_CONNECT_RETRY</literal> specifies how many
        seconds to wait between connect retries. The default is 60.

<literal>MASTER_RETRY_COUNT</literal> limits the
        <emphasis>number</emphasis> of reconnection attempts and updates
        the value of the <literal>Master_Retry_Count</literal> column in
        the output of <literal role="stmt">SHOW SLAVE STATUS</literal>.
        The default value is 24 * 3600 = 86400.
        <literal>MASTER_RETRY_COUNT</literal> is intended to replace the
        older <option role="mysqld">--master-retry-count</option> server
        option, and is now the preferred method for setting this limit.
        You are encouraged not to rely on
        <option role="mysqld">--master-retry-count</option> in new
        applications and, when upgrading to MySQL current-series, to
        update any existing applications that rely on it, so that they
        use <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO ... MASTER_RETRY_COUNT</literal>
        instead.

<literal>MASTER_DELAY</literal> specifies how many seconds
        behind the master the slave must lag. An event received from the
        master is not executed until at least
        <replaceable>interval</replaceable> seconds later than its
        execution on the master. The default is 0. An error occurs if
        <replaceable>interval</replaceable> is not a nonnegative integer
        in the range from 0 to 2<superscript>31</superscript>minus1.
        For more information, see <xref linkend="replication-delayed" />.

In MySQL 5.7.4 and later, a <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>
        statement employing the <literal>MASTER_DELAY</literal> option
        can be executed on a running slave when the slave SQL thread is
        stopped.

<literal>MASTER_BIND</literal> is for use on replication slaves
        having multiple network interfaces, and determines which of the
        slave's network interfaces is chosen for connecting to the
        master.

The address configured with this option, if any, can be seen in
        the <literal>Master_Bind</literal> column of the output from
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW SLAVE STATUS</literal>. If you are
        using slave status log tables (server started with
        <literal role="sysvar">master_info_repository=TABLE</literal>),
        the value can also be seen as the <literal>Master_bind</literal>
        column of the <literal>mysql.slave_master_info</literal> table.

The ability to bind a replication slave to a specific network
        interface is also supported by NDB Cluster.

<literal>MASTER_HEARTBEAT_PERIOD</literal> sets the interval in
        seconds between replication heartbeats. Whenever the master's
        binary log is updated with an event, the waiting period for the
        next heartbeat is reset. <replaceable>interval</replaceable> is
        a decimal value having the range 0 to 4294967 seconds and a
        resolution in milliseconds; the smallest nonzero value is 0.001.
        Heartbeats are sent by the master only if there are no unsent
        events in the binary log file for a period longer than
        <replaceable>interval</replaceable>.

Prior to MySQL 5.7.4, not including
        <literal>MASTER_HEARTBEAT_PERIOD</literal> caused
        <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> to reset the heartbeat
        period
        (<literal role="statvar">Slave_heartbeat_period</literal>) to
        the default, and
        <literal role="statvar">Slave_received_heartbeats</literal> to
        0. (Bug #18185490)

If you are logging master connection information to tables,
        <literal>MASTER_HEARTBEAT_PERIOD</literal> can be seen as the
        value of the <literal>Heartbeat</literal> column of the
        <literal>mysql.slave_master_info</literal> table.

Setting <replaceable>interval</replaceable> to 0 disables
        heartbeats altogether. The default value for
        <replaceable>interval</replaceable> is equal to the value of
        <literal role="sysvar">slave_net_timeout</literal> divided by 2.

Setting <literal>@@GLOBAL.slave_net_timeout</literal> to a value
        less than that of the current heartbeat interval results in a
        warning being issued. The effect of issuing
        <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> on the heartbeat
        interval is to reset it to the default value.

Prior to MySQL 5.7.4, <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>
        deletes all relay log files and starts a new one, unless you
        specify <literal>RELAY_LOG_FILE</literal> or
        <literal>RELAY_LOG_POS</literal>. In that case, relay log files
        are kept; the <literal role="sysvar">relay_log_purge</literal>
        global variable is set silently to 0. In MySQL 5.7.4 and later,
        relay logs are preserved if at least one of the slave SQL thread
        and the slave I/O thread is running; if both threads are
        stopped, all relay log files are deleted unless at least one of
        <literal>RELAY_LOG_FILE</literal> or
        <literal>RELAY_LOG_POS</literal> is specified.

<literal>RELAY_LOG_FILE</literal> can use either an absolute or
        relative path, and uses the same base name as
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_FILE</literal>. (Bug #12190)

<literal>IGNORE_SERVER_IDS</literal> takes a comma-separated
        list of 0 or more server IDs. Events originating from the
        corresponding servers are ignored, with the exception of log
        rotation and deletion events, which are still recorded in the
        relay log.

In circular replication, the originating server normally acts as
        the terminator of its own events, so that they are not applied
        more than once. Thus, this option is useful in circular
        replication when one of the servers in the circle is removed.
        Suppose that you have a circular replication setup with 4
        servers, having server IDs 1, 2, 3, and 4, and server 3 fails.
        When bridging the gap by starting replication from server 2 to
        server 4, you can include <literal>IGNORE_SERVER_IDS =
        (3)</literal> in the <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER
        TO</literal> statement that you issue on server 4 to tell it to
        use server 2 as its master instead of server 3. Doing so causes
        it to ignore and not to propagate any statements that originated
        with the server that is no longer in use.

If a <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement
        is issued without any <literal>IGNORE_SERVER_IDS</literal>
        option, any existing list is preserved. To clear the list of
        ignored servers, it is necessary to use the option with an empty
        list:

description.programlisting:
>
CHANGE MASTER TO IGNORE_SERVER_IDS = ();

description.para:
Prior to MySQL 5.7.5,
        <literal condition="reset-slave" role="stmt">RESET SLAVE
        ALL</literal> has no effect on the server ID list. In MySQL
        5.7.5 and later, <literal>RESET SLAVE ALL</literal> clears
        <literal>IGNORE_SERVER_IDS</literal>. (Bug #18816897)

If <literal>IGNORE_SERVER_IDS</literal> contains the
        server's own ID and the server was started with the
        <option role="mysqld">--replicate-same-server-id</option> option
        enabled, an error results.

In MySQL current-series, the master info repository and the
        output of <literal role="stmt">SHOW SLAVE STATUS</literal>
        provide the list of servers that are currently ignored. For more
        information, see <xref linkend="slave-logs-status" />, and
        <xref linkend="show-slave-status" />.

In MySQL current-series, invoking <literal role="stmt">CHANGE
        MASTER TO</literal> causes the previous values for
        <literal>MASTER_HOST</literal>, <literal>MASTER_PORT</literal>,
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_FILE</literal>, and
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_POS</literal> to be written to the error
        log, along with other information about the slave's state
        prior to execution.

In MySQL current-series, <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>
        causes an implicit commit of an ongoing transaction. See
        <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

In MySQL 5.7.4 and later, the strict requirement to execute
        <literal role="stmt">STOP SLAVE</literal> prior to issuing any
        <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement (and
        <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> afterward) is
        removed. Instead of depending on whether the slave is stopped,
        the behavior of <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> depends (in
        MySQL 5.7.4 and later) on the states of the slave SQL thread and
        slave I/O threads; which of these threads is stopped or running
        now determines the options that can or cannot be used with a
        <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement at a given point
        in time. The rules for making this determination are listed
        here:

itemizedlist.para:
If the SQL thread is stopped, you can execute
            <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> using any combination
            that is otherwise allowed of
            <literal>RELAY_LOG_FILE</literal>,
            <literal>RELAY_LOG_POS</literal>, and
            <literal>MASTER_DELAY</literal> options, even if the slave
            I/O thread is running. No other options may be used with
            this statement when the I/O thread is running.

If the I/O thread is stopped, you can execute
            <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> using any of the options
            for this statement (in any allowed combination)
            <emphasis>except</emphasis>
            <literal>RELAY_LOG_FILE</literal>,
            <literal>RELAY_LOG_POS</literal>, or
            <literal>MASTER_DELAY</literal>, even when the SQL thread is
            running. These three options may not be used when the I/O
            thread is running.

Both the SQL thread and the I/O thread must be stopped
            before issuing a <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>
            statement that employs <literal>MASTER_AUTO_POSITION =
            1</literal>.

description.para:
You can check the current state of the slave SQL and I/O threads
        using <literal role="stmt">SHOW SLAVE STATUS</literal>.

For more information, see
        <xref linkend="replication-solutions-switch" />.

If you are using statement-based replication and temporary
        tables, it is possible for a <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>
        statement following a <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> statement to
        leave behind temporary tables on the slave. In MySQL 5.7.4 and
        later, a warning
        (<errorname>ER_WARN_OPEN_TEMP_TABLES_MUST_BE_ZERO</errorname>)
        is now issued whenever this occurs. You can avoid this in such
        cases by making sure that the value of the
        <literal role="statvar">Slave_open_temp_tables</literal> system
        status variable is equal to 0 prior to executing such a
        <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement.

<literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> is useful for
        setting up a slave when you have the snapshot of the master and
        have recorded the master binary log coordinates corresponding to
        the time of the snapshot. After loading the snapshot into the
        slave to synchronize it with the master, you can run
        <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO
        MASTER_LOG_FILE='<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>',
        MASTER_LOG_POS=<replaceable>log_pos</replaceable></literal> on
        the slave to specify the coordinates at which the slave should
        begin reading the master binary log.

The following example changes the master server the slave uses
        and establishes the master binary log coordinates from which the
        slave begins reading. This is used when you want to set up the
        slave to replicate the master:

description.programlisting:
>
CHANGE MASTER TO
  MASTER_HOST='master2.example.com',
  MASTER_USER='replication',
  MASTER_PASSWORD='bigs3cret',
  MASTER_PORT=3306,
  MASTER_LOG_FILE='master2-bin.001',
  MASTER_LOG_POS=4,
  MASTER_CONNECT_RETRY=10;

description.para:
The next example shows an operation that is less frequently
        employed. It is used when the slave has relay log files that you
        want it to execute again for some reason. To do this, the master
        need not be reachable. You need only use
        <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> and start the
        SQL thread (<literal>START SLAVE SQL_THREAD</literal>):

description.programlisting:
>
CHANGE MASTER TO
  RELAY_LOG_FILE='slave-relay-bin.006',
  RELAY_LOG_POS=4025;

syntax.programlisting:
>
CHANGE MASTER TO <replaceable>option</replaceable> [, <replaceable>option</replaceable>] ... [ <replaceable>channel_option</replaceable> ]

<replaceable>option</replaceable>:
    MASTER_BIND = '<replaceable>interface_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_HOST = '<replaceable>host_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_USER = '<replaceable>user_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_PASSWORD = '<replaceable>password</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_PORT = <replaceable>port_num</replaceable>
  | MASTER_CONNECT_RETRY = <replaceable>interval</replaceable>
  | MASTER_RETRY_COUNT = <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MASTER_DELAY = <replaceable>interval</replaceable>
  | MASTER_HEARTBEAT_PERIOD = <replaceable>interval</replaceable>
  | MASTER_LOG_FILE = '<replaceable>master_log_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_LOG_POS = <replaceable>master_log_pos</replaceable>
  | MASTER_AUTO_POSITION = {0|1}
  | RELAY_LOG_FILE = '<replaceable>relay_log_name</replaceable>'
  | RELAY_LOG_POS = <replaceable>relay_log_pos</replaceable>
  | MASTER_SSL = {0|1}
  | MASTER_SSL_CA = '<replaceable>ca_file_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_CAPATH = '<replaceable>ca_directory_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_CERT = '<replaceable>cert_file_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_CRL = '<replaceable>crl_file_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_CRLPATH = '<replaceable>crl_directory_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_KEY = '<replaceable>key_file_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_CIPHER = '<replaceable>cipher_list</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_VERIFY_SERVER_CERT = {0|1}
  | MASTER_TLS_VERSION = '<replaceable>protocol_list</replaceable>'
  | IGNORE_SERVER_IDS = (<replaceable>server_id_list</replaceable>)

<replaceable>channel_option</replaceable>:
    FOR CHANNEL <replaceable>channel</replaceable>

<replaceable>server_id_list</replaceable>:
    [<replaceable>server_id</replaceable> [, <replaceable>server_id</replaceable>] ... ]

description.para:
In MySQL 5.7.3 and later, <literal>CHANGE REPLICATION
        FILTER</literal> sets one or more replication filtering rules on
        the slave in the same way as starting the slave
        <command>mysqld</command> with replication filtering options
        such as <option role="mysqld">--replicate-do-db</option> or
        <option role="mysqld">--replicate-wild-ignore-table</option>.
        Unlike the case with the server options, this statement does not
        require restarting the server to take effect, only that the
        slave SQL thread be stopped using
        <literal condition="stop-slave" role="stmt">STOP SLAVE
        SQL_THREAD</literal> first (and restarted with
        <literal condition="start-slave" role="stmt">START SLAVE
        SQL_THREAD</literal> afterwards).

The following list shows the <literal>CHANGE REPLICATION
        FILTER</literal> options and how they relate to
        <option>--replicate-*</option> server options:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>REPLICATE_DO_DB</literal>: Include updates based on
            database name. Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-do-db</option>.

<literal>REPLICATE_IGNORE_DB</literal>: Exclude updates
            based on database name. Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-ignore-db</option>.

<literal>REPLICATE_DO_TABLE</literal>: Include updates based
            on table name. Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-do-table</option>.

<literal>REPLICATE_IGNORE_TABLE</literal>: Exclude updates
            based on table name. Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-ignore-table</option>.

<literal>REPLICATE_WILD_DO_TABLE</literal>: Include updates
            based on wildcard pattern matching table name. Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-wild-do-table</option>.

<literal>REPLICATE_WILD_IGNORE_TABLE</literal>: Exclude
            updates based on wildcard pattern matching table name.
            Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-wild-ignore-table</option>.

<literal>REPLICATE_REWRITE_DB</literal>: Perform updates on
            slave after substituting new name on slave for specified
            database on master. Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-rewrite-db</option>.

description.para:
The precise effects of <literal>REPLICATE_DO_DB</literal> and
        <literal>REPLICATE_IGNORE_DB</literal> filters are dependent on
        whether statement-based or row-based replication is in effect.
        See <xref linkend="replication-rules" />, for more information.

Multiple replication filtering rules can be created in a single
        <literal>CHANGE REPLICATION FILTER</literal> statement by
        separating the rules with commas, as shown here:

Issuing the statement just shown is equivalent to starting the
        slave <command>mysqld</command> with the options
        <option role="mysqld">--replicate-do-db=d1</option>
        <option role="mysqld">--replicate-ignore-db=d2</option>.

If the same filtering rule is specified multiple times, only the
        <emphasis>last</emphasis> such rule is actually used. For
        example, the two statements shown here have exactly the same
        effect, because the first <literal>REPLICATE_DO_DB</literal>
        rule in the first statement is ignored:

Names of tables and database not containing any special
        characters need not be quoted. Values used with
        <literal>REPLICATION_WILD_TABLE</literal> and
        <literal>REPLICATION_WILD_IGNORE_TABLE</literal> are string
        expressions, possibly containing (special) wildcard characters,
        and so must be quoted. This is shown in the following example
        statements:

Values used with <literal>REPLICATE_REWRITE_DB</literal>
        represent <emphasis>pairs</emphasis> of database names; each
        such value must be enclosed in parentheses. The following
        statement rewrites statements occurring on database
        <literal>dbA</literal> on the master to database
