        <literal>dbB</literal> on the slave:

description.programlisting:
>
CHANGE REPLICATION FILTER REPLICATE_REWRITE_DB = ((db1, db2));

description.para:
The statement just shown contains two sets of parentheses, one
        enclosing the pair of database names, and the other enclosing
        the entire list. This is perhap more easily seen in the
        following example, which creates two
        <literal>rewrite-db</literal> rules, one rewriting database
        <literal>dbA</literal> to <literal>dbB</literal>, and one
        rewriting database <literal>dbC</literal> to
        <literal>dbD</literal>:

This statement leaves any existing replication filtering rules
        unchanged; to unset all filters of a given type, set the
        filter's value to an explicitly empty list, as shown in
        this example, which removes all existing
        <literal>REPLICATE_DO_DB</literal> and
        <literal>REPLICATE_IGNORE_DB</literal> rules:

Setting a filter to empty in this way removes all existing
        rules, does not create any new ones, and does not restore any
        rules set at mysqld startup using <option>--replicate-*</option>
        options on the command line or in the configuration file.

Values employed with <literal>REPLICATE_WILD_DO_TABLE</literal>
        and <literal>REPLICATE_WILD_IGNORE_TABLE</literal> must be in
        the format
        <literal><replaceable>db_name</replaceable>.<replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable></literal>.
        Prior to MySQL 5.7.5, this was not strictly enforced, although
        using nonconforming values with these options could lead to
        erroneous results (Bug #18095449).
For more information, see <xref linkend="replication-rules" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
CHANGE REPLICATION FILTER <replaceable>filter</replaceable>[, <replaceable>filter</replaceable>][, ...]

<replaceable>filter</replaceable>:
    REPLICATE_DO_DB = (<replaceable>db_list</replaceable>)
  | REPLICATE_IGNORE_DB = (<replaceable>db_list</replaceable>)
  | REPLICATE_DO_TABLE = (<replaceable>tbl_list</replaceable>)
  | REPLICATE_IGNORE_TABLE = (<replaceable>tbl_list</replaceable>)
  | REPLICATE_WILD_DO_TABLE = (<replaceable>wild_tbl_list</replaceable>)
  | REPLICATE_WILD_IGNORE_TABLE = (<replaceable>wild_tbl_list</replaceable>)
  | REPLICATE_REWRITE_DB = (<replaceable>db_pair_list</replaceable>)

<replaceable>db_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>[, <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>][, ...]

<replaceable>tbl_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>db_name.table_name</replaceable>[, <replaceable>db_table_name</replaceable>][, ...]
<replaceable>wild_tbl_list</replaceable>:
    '<replaceable>db_pattern.table_pattern</replaceable>'[, '<replaceable>db_pattern.table_pattern</replaceable>'][, ...]

<replaceable>db_pair_list</replaceable>:
    (<replaceable>db_pair</replaceable>)[, (<replaceable>db_pair</replaceable>)][, ...]

<replaceable>db_pair</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>from_db</replaceable>, <replaceable>to_db</replaceable>

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> makes the slave
        forget its replication position in the master's binary log. This
        statement is meant to be used for a clean start: It clears the
        master info and relay log info repositories, deletes all the
        relay log files, and starts a new relay log file. It also resets
        to 0 the replication delay specified with the
        <literal>MASTER_DELAY</literal> option to <literal>CHANGE MASTER
        TO</literal>. To use <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal>,
        the slave replication threads must be stopped (use
        <literal role="stmt">STOP SLAVE</literal> if necessary).

The optional <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause added in
        MySQL 5.7.6 enables you to choose which replication channel the
        statement applies to. If no clause is set and no extra channels
        exist, the statement applies to the default channel and behaves
        the same as versions of MySQL prior to 5.7.6. Providing a
        <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause applies the
        <literal>RESET SLAVE</literal> statement to a specific
        replication channel. Combining a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause with the
        <literal>ALL</literal> option deletes the specified channel.
        Issuing a <literal condition="reset-slave" role="stmt">RESET
        SLAVE ALL</literal> statement without a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause when
        multiple replication channels exist deletes
        <emphasis>all</emphasis> replication channels and recreates only
        the default channel. See <xref linkend="replication-channels" />
        for more information.

<literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> does not change any
        replication connection parameters such as master host, master
        port, master user, or master password, which are retained in
        memory. This means that <literal role="stmt">START
        SLAVE</literal> can be issued without requiring a
        <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement
        following <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal>.

Connection parameters are reset by <literal>RESET SLAVE
        ALL</literal>. (<literal>RESET SLAVE</literal> followed by a
        restart of the slave <command>mysqld</command> also does this.)

In MySQL current-series <literal>RESET SLAVE</literal> causes
        an implicit commit of an ongoing transaction. See
        <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

If the slave SQL thread was in the middle of replicating
        temporary tables when it was stopped, and
        <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> is issued, these
        replicated temporary tables are deleted on the slave.

Prior to MySQL 5.7.5, <literal>RESET SLAVE</literal> also had
        the effect of resetting both the heartbeat period
        (<literal role="statvar">Slave_heartbeat_period</literal>) and
        <literal>SSL_VERIFY_SERVER_CERT</literal>. This issue is fixed
        in MySQL 5.7.5 and later. (Bug #18777899, Bug #18778485)

Prior to MySQL 5.7.5, <literal>RESET SLAVE ALL</literal> did not
        clear the <literal>IGNORE_SERVER_IDS</literal> list set by
        <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>. In MySQL 5.7.5
        and later, the statement clears the list. (Bug #18816897)

This statement skips the next <replaceable>N</replaceable>
        events from the master. This is useful for recovering from
        replication stops caused by a statement.

This statement is valid only when the slave threads are not
        running. Otherwise, it produces an error.

<literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> with no
        <replaceable>thread_type</replaceable> options starts both of
        the slave threads. The I/O thread reads events from the master
        server and stores them in the relay log. The SQL thread reads
        events from the relay log and executes them.
        <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

If <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> succeeds in
        starting the slave threads, it returns without any error.
        However, even in that case, it might be that the slave threads
        start and then later stop (for example, because they do not
        manage to connect to the master or read its binary log, or some
        other problem). <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> does
        not warn you about this. You must check the slave's error log
        for error messages generated by the slave threads, or check that
        they are running satisfactorily with <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        SLAVE STATUS</literal>.

In MySQL current-series, <literal>START SLAVE</literal> causes
        an implicit commit of an ongoing transaction. See
        <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

Beginning with MySQL 5.7.1,
        <literal role="sysvar">gtid_next</literal> must be set to
        <literal>AUTOMATIC</literal> before issuing this statement (Bug
        #16062608).

The optional <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause added in
        MySQL 5.7.6 enables you to choose which replication channel the
        statement applies to. If no clause is set and no extra channels
        exist, the statement applies to the default channel and behaves
        the same as versions of MySQL prior to 5.7.6. Providing a
        <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause applies the
        <literal>START SLAVE</literal> statement to a specific
        replication channel. If a <literal>START SLAVE</literal>
        statement does not have a channel defined when using multiple
        channels, this statement starts the specified threads for all
        channels. Beginning with MySQL 5.7.9, this statement is
        disallowed for the <literal>group_replication_recovery</literal>
        channel. See <xref linkend="replication-channels" /> for more
        information.

MySQL current-series supports pluggable user-password
        authentication with <literal>START SLAVE</literal> with the
        <literal>USER</literal>, <literal>PASSWORD</literal>,
        <literal>DEFAULT_AUTH</literal> and
        <literal>PLUGIN_DIR</literal> options, as described in the
        following list:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>USER</literal>: User name. Cannot be set to an
            empty or null string, or left unset if
            <literal>PASSWORD</literal> is used.
<literal>PASSWORD</literal>: Password.

<literal>DEFAULT_AUTH</literal>: Name of plugin; default is
            MySQL native authentication.
<literal>PLUGIN_DIR</literal>: Location of plugin.

description.para:
You cannot use the <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> option when
        specifying any of <literal>USER</literal>,
        <literal>PASSWORD</literal>, <literal>DEFAULT_AUTH</literal>, or
        <literal>PLUGIN_DIR</literal>, unless the
        <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> option is also provided.

See <xref linkend="pluggable-authentication" />, for more
        information.

If an insecure connection is used with any these options, the
        server issues the warning <errortext>Sending passwords in plain
        text without SSL/TLS is extremely insecure</errortext>.

<literal>START SLAVE ... UNTIL</literal> supports two additional
        options for use with global transaction identifiers (GTIDs) (see
        <xref linkend="replication-gtids" />). Each of these takes a set
        of one or more global transaction identifiers
        <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable> as an argument (see
        <xref linkend="replication-gtids-concepts-gtid-sets" />, for more
        information).

When no <replaceable>thread_type</replaceable> is specified,
        <literal>START SLAVE UNTIL SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS</literal> causes the
        slave SQL thread to process transactions until it has reached
        the <emphasis>first</emphasis> transaction whose GTID is listed
        in the <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>. <literal>START SLAVE
        UNTIL SQL_AFTER_GTIDS</literal> causes the slave threads to
        process all transactions until the
        <replaceable>last</replaceable> transaction in the
        <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable> has been processed by both
        threads. In other words, <literal>START SLAVE UNTIL
        SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS</literal> causes the slave SQL thread to
        process all transactions occurring before the first GTID in the
        <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable> is reached, and
        <literal>START SLAVE UNTIL SQL_AFTER_GTIDS</literal> causes the
        slave threads to handle all transactions, including those whose
        GTIDs are found in <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>, until
        each has encountered a transaction whose GTID is not part of the
        set. <literal>SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS</literal> and
        <literal>SQL_AFTER_GTIDS</literal> each support the
        <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> and <literal>IO_THREAD</literal>
        options, although using <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> with them
        currently has no effect.

For example, <literal>START SLAVE SQL_THREAD UNTIL
        SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS =
        3E11FA47-71CA-11E1-9E33-C80AA9429562:11-56</literal> causes the
        slave SQL thread to process all transactions originating from
        the master whose <literal role="sysvar">server_uuid</literal> is
        <literal>3E11FA47-71CA-11E1-9E33-C80AA9429562</literal> until it
        encounters the transaction having sequence number 11; it then
        stops without processing this transaction. In other words, all
        transactions up to and including the transaction with sequence
        number 10 are processed. Executing <literal>START SLAVE
        SQL_THREAD UNTIL SQL_AFTER_GTIDS =
        3E11FA47-71CA-11E1-9E33-C80AA9429562:11-56</literal>, on the
        other hand, would cause the slave SQL thread to obtain all
        transactions just mentioned from the master, including all of
        the transactions having the sequence numbers 11 through 56, and
        then to stop without processing any additional transactions;
        that is, the transaction having sequence number 56 would be the
        last transaction fetched by the slave SQL thread.

Prior to MySQL 5.7.3, <literal>SQL_AFTER_GTIDS</literal> did not
        stop the slave once the indicated transaction was completed, but
        waited until another GTID event was received (Bug #14767986).

When using a multithreaded slave, there is a chance of gaps in
        the sequence of transactions that have been executed from the
        relay log in the following cases:

itemizedlist.para: killing the coordinator thread
after an error occurs in the worker threads
<command>mysqld</command> shuts down unexpectedly

description.para:
Use the <literal condition="start-slave" role="stmt">START SLAVE
        UNTIL SQL_AFTER_MTS_GAPS</literal> statement to cause a
        multithreaded slave's worker threads to only run until no
        more gaps are found in the relay log, and then to stop. This
        statement can take an <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> option, but
        the effects of the statement remain unchanged. It has no effect
        on the slave I/O thread (and cannot be used with the
        <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> option).

Issuing <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> on a
        multithreaded slave with gaps in the sequence of transactions
        executed from the relay log generates a warning. In such a
        situation, the solution is to use
        <literal condition="start-slave" role="stmt">START SLAVE UNTIL
        SQL_AFTER_MTS_GAPS</literal>, then issue
        <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> to remove any
        remaining relay logs. See
        <xref linkend="replication-features-transaction-inconsistencies" />
        for more information.

To change a failed multithreaded slave to single-threaded mode,
        you can issue the following series of statements, in the order
        shown:

syntax.programlisting:
>
START SLAVE [<replaceable>thread_types</replaceable>] [<replaceable>until_option</replaceable>] [<replaceable>connection_options</replaceable>] [<replaceable>channel_option</replaceable>]

<replaceable>thread_types</replaceable>:
    [<replaceable>thread_type</replaceable> [, <replaceable>thread_type</replaceable>] ... ]

<replaceable>thread_type</replaceable>:
    IO_THREAD | SQL_THREAD

<replaceable>until_option</replaceable>:
    UNTIL {   {SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS | SQL_AFTER_GTIDS} = <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>
          |   MASTER_LOG_FILE = '<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>', MASTER_LOG_POS = <replaceable>log_pos</replaceable>
          |   RELAY_LOG_FILE = '<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>', RELAY_LOG_POS = <replaceable>log_pos</replaceable>
          |   SQL_AFTER_MTS_GAPS  }

<replaceable>connection_options</replaceable>:
    [USER='<replaceable>user_name</replaceable>'] [PASSWORD='<replaceable>user_pass</replaceable>'] [DEFAULT_AUTH='<replaceable>plugin_name</replaceable>'] [PLUGIN_DIR='<replaceable>plugin_dir</replaceable>']


<replaceable>channel_option</replaceable>:
    FOR CHANNEL <replaceable>channel</replaceable>

<replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>uuid_set</replaceable> [, <replaceable>uuid_set</replaceable>] ...
    | ''

<replaceable>uuid_set</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>uuid</replaceable>:<replaceable>interval</replaceable>[:<replaceable>interval</replaceable>]...

<replaceable>uuid</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>hhhhhhhh</replaceable>-<replaceable>hhhh</replaceable>-<replaceable>hhhh</replaceable>-<replaceable>hhhh</replaceable>-<replaceable>hhhhhhhhhhhh</replaceable>

<replaceable>h</replaceable>:
    [0-9,A-F]

<replaceable>interval</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>n</replaceable>[-<replaceable>n</replaceable>]

    (<replaceable>n</replaceable> >= 1)

description.para:
Stops the slave threads. <literal role="stmt">STOP
        SLAVE</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege. Recommended best
        practice is to execute <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> on the
        slave before stopping the slave server (see
        <xref linkend="server-shutdown" />, for more information).

<emphasis>When using the row-based logging format</emphasis>:
        You should execute <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> or
        <literal>STOP SLAVE SQL_THREAD</literal> on the slave prior to
        shutting down the slave server if you are replicating any tables
        that use a nontransactional storage engine (see the
        <citetitle>Note</citetitle> later in this section).

Like <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal>, this statement
        may be used with the <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> and
        <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> options to name the thread or
        threads to be stopped.

In MySQL current-series, <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> causes
        an implicit commit of an ongoing transaction. See
        <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

Beginning with MySQL 5.7.1,
        <literal role="sysvar">gtid_next</literal> must be set to
        <literal>AUTOMATIC</literal> before issuing this statement (Bug
        #16062608).

In MySQL 5.7.2 and later, you can control how long <literal>STOP
        SLAVE</literal> waits before timing out by setting the
        <literal role="sysvar">rpl_stop_slave_timeout</literal> system
        variable. This can be used to avoid deadlocks between
        <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> and other slave SQL statements
        using different client connections to the slave. When the
        timeout value is reached, the issuing client returns an error
        message and stops waiting, but the <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal>
        instruction remains in effect. Once the slave threads are no
        longer busy, the <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> statement is
        executed and the slave stops. (Bug #16856735)

Prior to MySQL 5.7.4, it was necessary to issue this statement
        on a running slave prior to executing
        <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>. In MySQL 5.7.4
        and later, this is no longer always the case; some
        <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statements are now allowed
        while the slave is running, depending on the states of the slave
        SQL and I/O threads. However, using <literal>STOP
        SLAVE</literal> prior to executing <literal>CHANGE MASTER
        TO</literal> in such cases is still supported. See
        <xref linkend="change-master-to" />, and
        <xref linkend="replication-solutions-switch" />, for more
        information.

The optional <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause added in
        MySQL 5.7.6 enables you to choose which replication channel the
        statement applies to. If no clause is set and no extra channels
        exist, the statement applies to the default channel and behaves
        the same as versions of MySQL prior to 5.7.6. Providing a
        <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause applies the
        <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> statement to a specific
        replication channel. If a <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal>
        statement does not have a channel defined when using multiple
        channels, this statement stops the specified threads for all
        channels. Beginning with MySQL 5.7.9, this statement cannot be
        used with the <literal>group_replication_recovery</literal>
        channel. See <xref linkend="replication-channels" /> for more
        information.

<emphasis>When using statement-based replication</emphasis>:
        changing the master while it has open temporary tables is
        potentially unsafe. This is one of the reasons why
        statement-based replication of temporary tables is not
        recommended. You can find out whether there are any temporary
        tables on the slave by checking the value of
        <literal role="statvar">Slave_open_temp_tables</literal>; when
        using statement-based replication, this value should be 0 before
        executing <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>. In MySQL 5.7.4
        and later, if there are any temporary tables open on the slave,
        issuing a <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement after
        issuing a <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> causes an
        <errorname>ER_WARN_OPEN_TEMP_TABLES_MUST_BE_ZERO</errorname>
        warning.

When using a multithreaded slave
        (<literal role="sysvar">slave_parallel_workers</literal> is a
        nonzero value), any gaps in the sequence of transactions
        executed from the relay log are closed as part of stopping the
        worker threads. If the slave is stopped unexpectedly (for
        example due to an error in a worker thread, or another thread
        issuing <literal role="stmt">KILL</literal>) while a
        <literal role="stmt">STOP SLAVE</literal> statement is
        executing, the sequence of executed transactions from the relay
        log may become inconsistent. See
        <xref linkend="replication-features-transaction-inconsistencies" />,
        for more information.

If the current replication event group has modified one or more
        nontransactional tables, STOP SLAVE waits for up to 60 seconds
        for the event group to complete, unless you issue a
        <literal condition="kill" role="stmt">KILL QUERY</literal> or
        <literal condition="kill" role="stmt">KILL CONNECTION</literal>
        statement for the slave SQL thread. If the event group remains
        incomplete after the timeout, an error message is logged.

syntax.programlisting:
>
STOP SLAVE [<replaceable>thread_types</replaceable>]

<replaceable>thread_types</replaceable>:
    [<replaceable>thread_type</replaceable> [, <replaceable>thread_type</replaceable>] ... ]

<replaceable>thread_type</replaceable>: IO_THREAD | SQL_THREAD

<replaceable>channel_option</replaceable>:
    FOR CHANNEL <replaceable>channel</replaceable>

description.para:
These statements provide control over use of
      <link linkend="glos_transaction">transactions</link>:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>START TRANSACTION</literal> or
          <literal>BEGIN</literal> start a new transaction.

<literal>COMMIT</literal> commits the current transaction,
          making its changes permanent.

<literal>ROLLBACK</literal> rolls back the current
          transaction, canceling its changes.

<literal>SET autocommit</literal> disables or enables the
          default autocommit mode for the current session.

description.para:
By default, MySQL runs with
      <link linkend="glos_autocommit">autocommit</link> mode enabled.
      This means that, when not otherwise inside a transaction, each
      statement is atomic, as if it were surrounded by <literal>START
      TRANSACTION</literal> and <literal>COMMIT</literal>. You cannot
      use <literal>ROLLBACK</literal> to undo the effect; however, if an
      error occurs during statement execution, the statement is rolled
      back.

To disable autocommit mode implicitly for a single series of
      statements, use the <literal>START TRANSACTION</literal>
      statement:

With <literal>START TRANSACTION</literal>, autocommit remains
      disabled until you end the transaction with
      <literal>COMMIT</literal> or <literal>ROLLBACK</literal>. The
      autocommit mode then reverts to its previous state.

<literal>START TRANSACTION</literal> permits several modifiers
      that control transaction characteristics. To specify multiple
      modifiers, separate them by commas.

itemizedlist.para:
The <literal>WITH CONSISTENT SNAPSHOT</literal> modifier
          starts a <link linkend="glos_consistent_read">consistent
          read</link> for storage engines that are capable of it. This
          applies only to <literal>InnoDB</literal>. The effect is the
          same as issuing a <literal>START TRANSACTION</literal>
          followed by a <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> from any
          <literal>InnoDB</literal> table. See
          <xref linkend="innodb-consistent-read" />. The <literal>WITH
          CONSISTENT SNAPSHOT</literal> modifier does not change the
          current transaction
          <link linkend="glos_isolation_level">isolation level</link>,
          so it provides a consistent snapshot only if the current
          isolation level is one that permits a consistent read. The
          only isolation level that permits a consistent read is
          <literal role="isolevel">REPEATABLE READ</literal>. For all
          other isolation levels, the <literal>WITH CONSISTENT
          SNAPSHOT</literal> clause is ignored. As of MySQL 5.7.2, a
          warning is generated when the <literal>WITH CONSISTENT
          SNAPSHOT</literal> clause is ignored.

The <literal>READ WRITE</literal> and <literal>READ
          ONLY</literal> modifiers set the transaction access mode. They
          permit or prohibit changes to tables used in the transaction.
          The <literal>READ ONLY</literal> restriction prevents the
          transaction from modifying or locking both transactional and
          nontransactional tables that are visible to other
          transactions; the transaction can still modify or lock
          temporary tables.

MySQL enables extra optimizations for queries on
          <literal>InnoDB</literal> tables when the transaction is known
          to be read-only. Specifying <literal>READ ONLY</literal>
          ensures these optimizations are applied in cases where the
          read-only status cannot be determined automatically. See
          <xref linkend="innodb-performance-ro-txn" /> for more
          information.

If no access mode is specified, the default mode applies.
          Unless the default has been changed, it is read/write. It is
          not permitted to specify both <literal>READ WRITE</literal>
          and <literal>READ ONLY</literal> in the same statement.

In read-only mode, it remains possible to change tables
          created with the <literal>TEMPORARY</literal> keyword using
          DML statements. Changes made with DDL statements are not
          permitted, just as with permanent tables.

For additional information about transaction access mode,
          including ways to change the default mode, see
          <xref linkend="set-transaction" />.

If the <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system
          variable is enabled, explicitly starting a transaction with
          <literal>START TRANSACTION READ WRITE</literal> requires the
          <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

description.para:
To disable autocommit mode explicitly, use the following
      statement:

description.programlisting:
>
SET autocommit=0;

description.para:
After disabling autocommit mode by setting the
      <literal role="sysvar">autocommit</literal> variable to zero,
      changes to transaction-safe tables (such as those for
      <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal> or
      <literal role="se">NDB</literal>) are not made permanent
      immediately. You must use <literal role="stmt">COMMIT</literal> to
      store your changes to disk or <literal>ROLLBACK</literal> to
      ignore the changes.

<literal role="sysvar">autocommit</literal> is a session variable
      and must be set for each session. To disable autocommit mode for
      each new connection, see the description of the
      <literal role="sysvar">autocommit</literal> system variable at
      <xref linkend="server-system-variables" />.

<literal>BEGIN</literal> and <literal>BEGIN WORK</literal> are
      supported as aliases of <literal>START TRANSACTION</literal> for
      initiating a transaction. <literal>START TRANSACTION</literal> is
      standard SQL syntax, is the recommended way to start an ad-hoc
      transaction, and permits modifiers that <literal>BEGIN</literal>
      does not.

The <literal>BEGIN</literal> statement differs from the use of the
      <literal>BEGIN</literal> keyword that starts a
      <literal condition="begin-end" role="stmt">BEGIN ... END</literal>
      compound statement. The latter does not begin a transaction. See
      <xref linkend="begin-end" />.

The optional <literal>WORK</literal> keyword is supported for
      <literal>COMMIT</literal> and <literal>ROLLBACK</literal>, as are
      the <literal>CHAIN</literal> and <literal>RELEASE</literal>
      clauses. <literal>CHAIN</literal> and <literal>RELEASE</literal>
      can be used for additional control over transaction completion.
      The value of the <literal role="sysvar">completion_type</literal>
      system variable determines the default completion behavior. See
      <xref linkend="server-system-variables" />.

The <literal>AND CHAIN</literal> clause causes a new transaction
      to begin as soon as the current one ends, and the new transaction
      has the same isolation level as the just-terminated transaction.
      The new transaction also uses the same access mode (<literal>READ
      WRITE</literal> or <literal>READ ONLY</literal>) as the
      just-terminated transaction. The <literal>RELEASE</literal> clause
      causes the server to disconnect the current client session after
      terminating the current transaction. Including the
      <literal>NO</literal> keyword suppresses <literal>CHAIN</literal>
      or <literal>RELEASE</literal> completion, which can be useful if
      the <literal role="sysvar">completion_type</literal> system
      variable is set to cause chaining or release completion by
      default.

syntax.programlisting:
>
START TRANSACTION
    [<replaceable>transaction_characteristic</replaceable> [, <replaceable>transaction_characteristic</replaceable>] ...]

<replaceable>transaction_characteristic</replaceable>: {
    WITH CONSISTENT SNAPSHOT
  | READ WRITE
  | READ ONLY
}

BEGIN [WORK]
COMMIT [WORK] [AND [NO] CHAIN] [[NO] RELEASE]
ROLLBACK [WORK] [AND [NO] CHAIN] [[NO] RELEASE]
SET autocommit = {0 | 1}

description.para:
<literal>InnoDB</literal> supports the SQL statements
      <literal role="stmt">SAVEPOINT</literal>,
      <literal condition="savepoint" role="stmt">ROLLBACK TO
      SAVEPOINT</literal>,
      <literal condition="savepoint" role="stmt">RELEASE
      SAVEPOINT</literal> and the optional <literal>WORK</literal>
      keyword for
      <literal condition="commit" role="stmt">ROLLBACK</literal>.

MySQL enables client sessions to acquire table locks explicitly
      for the purpose of cooperating with other sessions for access to
      tables, or to prevent other sessions from modifying tables during
      periods when a session requires exclusive access to them. A
      session can acquire or release locks only for itself. One session
      cannot acquire locks for another session or release locks held by
      another session.

Locks may be used to emulate transactions or to get more speed
      when updating tables. This is explained in more detail in
      <xref linkend="lock-tables-restrictions" />.

<literal role="stmt">LOCK TABLES</literal> explicitly acquires
      table locks for the current client session. Table locks can be
      acquired for base tables or views. You must have the
      <literal role="priv">LOCK TABLES</literal> privilege, and the
      <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege for each object to
      be locked.

For view locking, <literal role="stmt">LOCK TABLES</literal> adds
      all base tables used in the view to the set of tables to be locked
      and locks them automatically. If you lock a table explicitly with
      <literal role="stmt">LOCK TABLES</literal>, any tables used in
      triggers are also locked implicitly, as described in
      <xref linkend="lock-tables-and-triggers" />.

<literal condition="lock-tables" role="stmt">UNLOCK
      TABLES</literal> explicitly releases any table locks held by the
      current session. <literal role="stmt">LOCK TABLES</literal>
      implicitly releases any table locks held by the current session
      before acquiring new locks.

Another use for
      <literal condition="lock-tables" role="stmt">UNLOCK
      TABLES</literal> is to release the global read lock acquired with
      the <literal role="stmt">FLUSH TABLES WITH READ LOCK</literal>
      statement, which enables you to lock all tables in all databases.
      See <xref linkend="flush" />. (This is a very convenient way to get
      backups if you have a file system such as Veritas that can take
      snapshots in time.)

syntax.programlisting:
>
LOCK TABLES
    <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [[AS] <replaceable>alias</replaceable>] <replaceable>lock_type</replaceable>
    [, <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [[AS] <replaceable>alias</replaceable>] <replaceable>lock_type</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>lock_type</replaceable>: {
    READ [LOCAL]
  | [LOW_PRIORITY] WRITE
}

UNLOCK TABLES

description.para:
This statement specifies
      <link linkend="glos_transaction">transaction</link>
      characteristics. It takes a list of one or more characteristic
      values separated by commas. Each characteristic value sets the
      transaction <link linkend="glos_isolation_level">isolation
      level</link> or access mode. The isolation level is used for
      operations on <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal> tables. The
      access mode specifies whether transactions operate in read/write
      or read-only mode.

In addition, <literal role="stmt">SET TRANSACTION</literal> can
      include an optional <literal>GLOBAL</literal> or
      <literal>SESSION</literal> keyword to indicate the scope of the
      statement.

For <literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        START</literal>, the <literal>JOIN</literal> and
        <literal>RESUME</literal> clauses are recognized but have no
        effect.

For <literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        END</literal> the <literal>SUSPEND [FOR MIGRATE]</literal>
        clause is recognized but has no effect.

Each XA statement begins with the <literal>XA</literal> keyword,
        and most of them require an <replaceable>xid</replaceable>
        value. An <replaceable>xid</replaceable> is an XA transaction
        identifier. It indicates which transaction the statement applies
        to. <replaceable>xid</replaceable> values are supplied by the
        client, or generated by the MySQL server. An
        <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value has from one to three
        parts:

description.programlisting:
>
<replaceable>xid</replaceable>: <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> [, <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> [, <replaceable>formatID</replaceable> ]]

description.para:
<replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> is a global transaction
        identifier, <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> is a branch
        qualifier, and <replaceable>formatID</replaceable> is a number
        that identifies the format used by the
        <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> values. As indicated by the
        syntax, <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>formatID</replaceable> are optional. The default
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> value is <literal>''</literal>
        if not given. The default <replaceable>formatID</replaceable>
        value is 1 if not given.

<replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> must be string literals, each
        up to 64 bytes (not characters) long.
        <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> can be specified in several
        ways. You can use a quoted string (<literal>'ab'</literal>), hex
        string (<literal>X'6162'</literal>, <literal>0x6162</literal>),
        or bit value
        (<literal>b'<replaceable>nnnn</replaceable>'</literal>).
<replaceable>formatID</replaceable> is an unsigned integer.

The <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> values are interpreted in bytes
        by the MySQL server's underlying XA support routines. However,
        while an SQL statement containing an XA statement is being
        parsed, the server works with some specific character set. To be
        safe, write <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> as hex strings.

<replaceable>xid</replaceable> values typically are generated by
        the Transaction Manager. Values generated by one TM must be
        different from values generated by other TMs. A given TM must be
        able to recognize its own <replaceable>xid</replaceable> values
        in a list of values returned by the
        <literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        RECOVER</literal> statement.

<literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA START
        <replaceable>xid</replaceable></literal> starts an XA
        transaction with the given <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value.
        Each XA transaction must have a unique
        <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value, so the value must not
        currently be used by another XA transaction. Uniqueness is
        assessed using the <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> values. All following XA
        statements for the XA transaction must be specified using the
        same <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value as that given in the
        <literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        START</literal> statement. If you use any of those statements
        but specify an <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value that does
        not correspond to some existing XA transaction, an error occurs.

One or more XA transactions can be part of the same global
        transaction. All XA transactions within a given global
        transaction must use the same <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable>
        value in the <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value. For this
        reason, <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> values must be globally
        unique so that there is no ambiguity about which global
        transaction a given XA transaction is part of. The
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> part of the
        <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value must be different for each
        XA transaction within a global transaction. (The requirement
        that <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> values be different is a
        limitation of the current MySQL XA implementation. It is not
        part of the XA specification.)

The <literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        RECOVER</literal> statement returns information for those XA
        transactions on the MySQL server that are in the
        <literal>PREPARED</literal> state. (See
        <xref linkend="xa-states" />.) The output includes a row for each
        such XA transaction on the server, regardless of which client
        started it.

<literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        RECOVER</literal> output rows look like this (for an example
        <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value consisting of the parts
        <literal>'abc'</literal>, <literal>'def'</literal>, and
        <literal>7</literal>):
The output columns have the following meanings:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>formatID</literal> is the
            <replaceable>formatID</replaceable> part of the transaction
            <replaceable>xid</replaceable>

<literal>gtrid_length</literal> is the length in bytes of
            the <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> part of the
            <replaceable>xid</replaceable>

<literal>bqual_length</literal> is the length in bytes of
            the <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> part of the
            <replaceable>xid</replaceable>

<literal>data</literal> is the concatenation of the
            <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
            <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> parts of the
            <replaceable>xid</replaceable>

description.para:
XID values may contain nonprintable characters. As of MySQL
        5.7.5, <literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        RECOVER</literal> permits an optional <literal>CONVERT
        XID</literal> clause so that clients can request XID values in
        hexadecimal.

syntax.programlisting:
>
XA {START|BEGIN} <replaceable>xid</replaceable> [JOIN|RESUME]

XA END <replaceable>xid</replaceable> [SUSPEND [FOR MIGRATE]]

XA PREPARE <replaceable>xid</replaceable>

XA COMMIT <replaceable>xid</replaceable> [ONE PHASE]

XA ROLLBACK <replaceable>xid</replaceable>

XA RECOVER [CONVERT XID]

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">DESCRIBE</literal> and
      <literal role="stmt">EXPLAIN</literal> statements are synonyms. In
      practice, the <literal role="stmt">DESCRIBE</literal> keyword is
      more often used to obtain information about table structure,
      whereas <literal role="stmt">EXPLAIN</literal> is used to obtain a
      query execution plan (that is, an explanation of how MySQL would
      execute a query).

The <literal role="stmt">HELP</literal> statement returns online
      information from the MySQL Reference Manual. Its proper operation
      requires that the help tables in the <literal>mysql</literal>
      database be initialized with help topic information (see
      <xref linkend="server-side-help-support" />).

The <literal role="stmt">HELP</literal> statement searches the
      help tables for the given search string and displays the result of
      the search. The search string is not case-sensitive.

The search string can contain the wildcard characters
      <literal>%</literal> and <literal>_</literal>. These have the same
      meaning as for pattern-matching operations performed with the
      <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> operator. For example,
      <literal>HELP 'rep%'</literal> returns a list of topics that begin
      with <literal>rep</literal>.

The <literal role="stmt">USE</literal> statement tells MySQL to
      use the named database as the default (current) database for
      subsequent statements. This statement requires some privilege for
      the database or some object within it.

The named database remains the default until the end of the
      session or another <literal role="stmt">USE</literal> statement is
      issued:

The database name must be specified on a single line. Newlines in
      database names are not supported.

The <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> attribute can be used to
        generate a unique identity for new rows:
